**_The Notes will initially be held in book-entry form and therefore investors must rely on the_**
**_procedures of the relevant clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies._**

The Notes will initially only be issued in global certificated form and held through Euroclear and
Clearstream, as applicable.

Interests in the global notes representing the Notes will trade in book-entry form only, and Notes in
definitive registered form, or Definitive Registered Notes, will be issued in exchange for book-entry
interests only in very limited circumstances. Owners of book-entry interests will not be considered
owners or holders of Notes. The common depositary, or its nominee, for Euroclear and/or Clearstream,
as applicable, will be the registered holders of the global notes representing the Notes. Payments of
principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the global notes representing the Notes
will be made to the Paying Agent, which will make payments to Euroclear and/or Clearstream, as
applicable. Thereafter, these payments will be credited to participants’ accounts that hold book-entry
interests in the global Notes representing the Notes and credited by such participants to indirect
participants. After payment to the common depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream, as applicable, the
Issuer will have no responsibility or liability for the payment of interest, principal or other amounts to
the owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, if investors own a book-entry interest, they must rely
on the procedures of Euroclear and/or Clearstream, as applicable, and if investors are not participants
in Euroclear and/or Clearstream, as applicable, they must rely on the procedures of the participant
through which they own their interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of the Notes
under the Indenture.

Unlike the holders of the Notes themselves, owners of book-entry interests will not have the direct right
to act upon the Issuer’s solicitations for consents, requests for waivers or other actions from holders of
the Notes. Instead, if an investor owns a book-entry interest, it will be permitted to act only to the extent
it has received appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear and/or Clearstream, as applicable. The
procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies may not be sufficient to enable such investor
to vote on a timely basis.

Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Indenture, unless and until Definitive
Registered Notes are issued in respect of all book-entry interests, if investors own book-entry interests,
they will be restricted to acting through Euroclear and/or Clearstream, as applicable. The procedures to
be implemented through Euroclear and/or Clearstream may not be adequate to ensure the timely
exercise of rights under the Notes. See “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form.”

**_There may not be an active trading market for the Notes, in which case your ability to sell the Notes_**
**_will be limited._**

We cannot assure you as to:

- the liquidity of any market in the Notes;

- your ability to sell your Notes; or

- the prices at which you would be able to sell your Notes.

Future trading prices of the Notes will depend on many factors, including, among other things,
prevailing interest rates, our operating results and the market for similar securities. The liquidity of a
trading market for the Notes may be adversely affected by a general decline in the market for similar
securities. Historically, the market for non-investment grade securities has been subject to disruptions
that have caused substantial volatility in the prices of securities similar to the Notes. Any such disruption
may have a negative effect on you, as a holder of Notes, regardless of our prospects and financial
performance. The Initial Purchasers have advised that they intend to make a market in the Notes after
completing the Offering. However, they have no obligation to do so and may discontinue market making
activities at any time without notice. In addition, such market making activity will be subject to


-----

limitations imposed by the Securities Act and other applicable laws and regulations. As a result, there
may not be an active trading market for the Notes. If no active trading market develops, you may not
be able to resell your Notes at a fair value, if at all.

**_Investors may not be able to recover in civil proceedings for U.S. securities law violations._**

The Issuer and the Guarantors are organized or incorporated outside the United States, and their
business is substantially conducted outside the United States. The directors and executive officers of
the Issuer and the Guarantors are non-residents of, and substantially all of their assets are located outside
of, the United States. Although the Issuer and the Guarantors will submit to the jurisdiction of certain
New York courts in connection with any action under U.S. securities laws, you may be unable to effect
service of process within the United States on the directors and executive officers of the Issuer and the
Guarantors. In addition, as a substantial portion of the assets of the Issuer and the Guarantors and their
subsidiaries and those of their directors and executive officers are located outside of the United States,
you may be unable to enforce against them judgments obtained in U.S. courts. Moreover, in light of
recent decisions of the U.S. Supreme Court, actions of the Issuer and the Guarantors may not be subject
to the civil liability provisions of the federal securities laws of the United States.

Additionally, there is uncertainty as to whether the courts of foreign jurisdictions would enforce (i)
judgments of United States courts obtained against the Issuer and the Guarantors and the directors and
executive officers who are not residents of the United States predicated upon the civil liability
provisions of the United States federal and state securities laws or (ii) in original actions brought in such
foreign jurisdictions against us or such persons predicated upon the United States federal and state
securities laws.

The United States is not currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and
enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards rendered in civil and commercial matters, with
Netherlands, Belgium and Germany. For further information see “Service of Process and Enforcement
_of Civil Liabilities.”_

**_The Issuer may not be able to repurchase the Notes upon a change of control. In addition, under_**
**_certain circumstances, the Issuer may have the right to purchase all outstanding Notes in connection_**
**_with a tender offer, even if certain holders of the Notes do not consent to the tender offer._**

If a Change of Control (as defined under “Description of the Notes”) occurs, the Issuer may be required
to make an offer to purchase all the outstanding Notes at a price in cash equal to 101% of the principal
amount thereof, plus any accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding,
the date of purchase. In such a situation, the Issuer may not have enough funds to pay for all of the
Notes that are tendered under any such offer. If a significant principal amount of Notes is tendered, the
Issuer will likely have to obtain financing to pay for the tendered Notes. However, the Issuer may not
be able to obtain such financing on acceptable terms, if at all. A change of control would entitle each
lender under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, the Bridge Facility Agreement and the
Second Lien Facility Agreement (individually) to cancel its commitments and require prepayment of
amounts outstanding to it under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, the Bridge Facility
Agreement and the Second Lien Facility Agreement, respectively, and could trigger put rights,
mandatory prepayments or accelerations under other existing or future financing arrangements of the
Group. Any failure by the Issuer to offer to purchase the Notes upon a change of control would
constitute a default under the Indenture, which would, in turn, constitute a default under the Senior
Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, the Bridge Facility Agreement and the Second Lien Facility
Agreement.

The change of control provision contained in the Indenture may not necessarily afford you protection
in the event of certain important corporate events, including reorganizations, restructurings, mergers,
recapitalizations or other similar transactions involving us that may adversely affect you, because such
corporate events may not involve a shift in voting power or beneficial ownership or, even if they do,


-----

may not constitute a change of control as defined in the Indenture. Furthermore, the occurrence of
certain events that might otherwise constitute a change of control under the Indenture will be deemed
not to be a change of control if a specified consolidated net leverage ratio is met. See “Description of
_the Notes—Change of Control.”_

In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in
aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such
Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the
Issuer, purchases, all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or
such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in
part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes. See
“Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

**_The term “all or substantially all” in the context of a change of control has no clearly established_**
**_meaning under relevant law and is subject to judicial interpretation such that it may not be certain_**
**_that a change of control has occurred or will occur._**

Upon the occurrence of a transaction that constitutes a change of control under the Indenture, the Issuer
will be required to make an offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes tendered. The definition of “change
of control” in the Indenture will include (with certain exceptions) a disposition of all or substantially all
of the assets of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries (taken as a whole), to any person. Although
there is a limited body of case law interpreting the phrase “all or substantially all,” it has no clearly
established meaning under relevant law, varies according to the facts and circumstances of the subject
transaction and is subject to judicial interpretation. Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there may be
a degree of uncertainty in ascertaining whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition of
“all or substantially all” of the assets of a person, and therefore it may be unclear whether a change of
control has occurred and whether the relevant Issuer is required to make an offer to repurchase the
Notes.

**_We may dispose of certain assets or capital stock of entities in the Group._**

We may have an interest in pursuing acquisitions, divestitures, financings, or other transactions that, in
our judgment, would be beneficial to us, even if such transactions might involve risks to you as
noteholders. For example, pursuant to the asset disposition covenant and other provisions of the Senior
Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, the Bridge Facility Agreement, the Second Lien Facility
Agreement and the Indenture, we may, under certain circumstances, sell, convey, transfer or otherwise
dispose of material assets of the Group and, if meeting certain leverage ratios on an as adjusted basis or
otherwise having restricted payments capacity, distribute some or all of the proceeds therefrom to our
shareholders. Such a transaction would not constitute a change of control or a default under the terms
of the Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Restricted Payments.”
Additionally, we may issue, sell transfer or otherwise dispose of the capital stock of entities in the Group
for purposes of taking a dividend or distribution that would benefit us but not benefit you as the
noteholders.

**_Holders of the Notes may have adverse tax consequences in the event of an IPO Debt Pushdown._**

Under certain circumstances, we may undertake an IPO Debt Pushdown (as described in “Description
_of the Notes—IPO Debt Pushdown”), pursuant to which the Issuer is entitled to give notice that the_
terms of the Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement (or any Additional Intercreditor Agreement (as
defined in “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Additional Intercreditor Agreements”)) will
automatically operate so that, among other things, the references to the Issuer and Restricted
Subsidiaries (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions”) (and all related provisions)
shall apply only to the IPO Pushdown Entity (as defined in “Description of the Notes—IPO Debt
_Pushdown”) and its Restricted Subsidiaries. In such event, each holding company of the IPO Pushdown_
Entity would be released from its obligations under the Indenture.


-----

Such modifications to the terms of the Notes could be treated for U.S. federal income tax purposes as a
deemed exchange of (i) the Notes as in place prior to such modifications for (ii) new Notes as in place
after such modifications (the “New Notes”). If such modifications result in a deemed exchange for U.S.
federal income tax purposes, it would generally be treated as a taxable transaction for U.S. federal
income tax purposes in which beneficial owners of the Notes would be required to recognize any gain
or loss. Furthermore, for U.S. federal income tax purposes, the New Notes deemed issued in such a
deemed exchange could be treated as issued with OID. In such event, U.S. Holders (as defined under
“Certain Taxation Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations”) would
generally be required to include the OID in their income (as ordinary income) as it accrues, in advance
of the receipt of cash corresponding to such income. In addition, the determination of whether the New
Notes are treated as “contingent payment debt instruments” as a result of the possibility of additional
payments, as further described under “Certain Taxation Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income
_Tax Considerations—Additional Payments,” would be made at the time of the modification. U.S._
Holders should consult their own tax advisors as to the U.S. federal income tax considerations relating
to potential modifications of the Notes in connection with the IPO Debt Pushdown, including the U.S.
federal income tax considerations of a deemed exchange and resulting OID, if any.

It is also possible that the IPO Debt Pushdown could result in a taxable event for tax purposes other
than U.S. federal income tax purposes.

**_Certain covenants and events of default will be suspended if we receive investment grade ratings._**

The Indenture will provide that, if at any time following the date of the Indenture, the Notes issued
under such Indenture receive any two of the following ratings: Baa3 or higher from Moody’s, BBB- or
higher from S&P or BBB- or higher from Fitch, and no default or event of default has occurred and is
continuing, then beginning that day and continuing until such time as such Notes are no longer rated
investment grade by either rating agency, certain covenants will cease to be applicable to such Notes.
See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of
_Investment Grade Status.” At any time when these covenants are suspended, we will be able to, among_
other things, incur additional indebtedness, pay cash dividends and redeem subordinated indebtedness
without restriction, each of which may conflict with the interests of holders of the Notes. There can be
no assurance that the Notes will ever achieve an investment grade rating or that any such rating if
achieved will be maintained.

**_Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may_**
**_be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time._**

One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The credit ratings
address our ability to perform our obligations under the terms of the Notes and credit risks in
determining the likelihood that payments will be made when due under the Notes. The ratings may not
reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed
above and other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation
to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating
agency at any time. No assurances can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given
period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating
agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal
at any time of the credit rating assigned to the Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may
adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of our financings and could adversely affect the value
and trading of the Notes.

**_The Notes may not become or remain listed on the Official List of the Exchange._**

Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the
Official List of the Exchange. However, there can be no assurance that the Notes will become or remain
listed. If the Issuer cannot maintain the listing on the Exchange and the admission to dealing on the
Official List thereof, or if it becomes unduly burdensome to make or maintain such listing, the Issuer


-----

may cease to make or maintain such listing on the Official List of the Exchange. Listing of any of the
Notes on the Official List of the Exchange does not imply that a public offering of any of the Notes in
the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man has been authorized. Although no assurance is made as to the
liquidity of the Notes as a result of listing on the Official List of the Exchange or another recognized
listing exchange for comparable issuers, failure to be approved for listing of the Notes on the Official
List of the Exchange or another recognized listing exchange or the delisting of the Notes from the
Official List of the Exchange or another listing exchange may have an adverse effect on a holder’s
ability to resell Notes in the secondary market.

**_You may face foreign currency exchange as a result of investing in the Notes._**

The Notes will be denominated and payable in euro. If you are a U.S. investor, an investment in the
Notes will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes
in the value of the euro relative to the U.S. dollar because of economic, political and other factors over
which we have no control. Depreciation of the euro against the U.S. dollar could cause a decrease in
the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you on a
U.S. dollar basis. Investments in the notes by U.S. investors may also have important tax consequences
as a result of foreign exchange gains, if any.

**_The Indenture will not be qualified under the TIA (as defined below)._**

The Indenture will not be required to, and will not be, qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of
1939, as amended (the “TIA”) and will not incorporate or include and will not be subject to any of the
provisions of the TIA. Consequently, the holders of Notes will not be entitled to the protections provided
under the TIA to holders of debt securities issued under a qualified indenture, including those respecting
preferential collections by the Trustee or conflicting interests of the Trustee. See “Description of the
_Notes.”_

**_The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes._**

If the stated principal amount of the Notes exceeds their issue price by an amount greater than or equal
to a statutorily defined de minimis amount, then the Notes will be considered to be issued with OID for
U.S. federal income tax purposes. If the Notes are issued with OID, then, in addition to the stated interest
on a note, a U.S. Holder (as defined under “Certain Taxation Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal
_Income Tax Considerations”) generally would be required to include such OID in gross income (as_
ordinary income) as it accrues on a constant yield basis for U.S. federal income tax purposes in advance
of the receipt of cash payments to which such income is attributable and regardless of the holder’s
method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. See “Certain Taxation Considerations—
_Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations--Original Issue Discount.”_

**THE TRANSACTIONS**

**The Acquisition**

On May 28, 2022, the Issuer entered into the Acquisition Agreement, by and among, inter alios, the
Issuer and the Sellers relating to the transfer by the Sellers and the acquisition by the Issuer, directly
and/or indirectly, of all of the issued and outstanding share capital of House of HR. The Acquisition
was consummated on November 3, 2022.

The Purchase Price for the Acquisition, including the repayment of the Existing Notes and the Existing
Facilities, was €2,676.7 million. In addition, the Acquisition Agreement contains certain agreed earnouts which may subsequently become payable to the Sellers in the event that certain conditions are met
in the future, including an earn-out of up to €110.0 million depending on the level of the Group’s
EBITDA for the fiscal years 2022 and 2023.

Pursuant to the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, on the Acquisition Closing Date, Naxicap Partners,
Ms. Vandendriessche, House of HR’s co-founder, and certain reinvesting managers and other minority
shareholders reinvested a certain portion of their Acquisition proceeds (or rolled over all or part of the
shares they held, directly or indirectly, in House of HR), through either (i) contributions in cash, (ii)
roll-up contributions of part of the receivables they would come to hold against the purchaser (or any
of its affiliates) in the context of the Acquisition (in respect of the purchase price due to them) or (iii)
contributions in kind of their respective shares in House of HR or the Dutch management vehicle in
exchange for ordinary shares and fixed-return preferred shares issued by Holdco, an indirect parent of
the Issuer. See “—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure” below. The contributions (in cash or
in kind) referred to in this paragraph are collectively referred herein as the “Shareholders’
Reinvestment.”

Although the Sellers have given certain customary representations, warranties and indemnities as to,
_inter alia, capacity, title and certain business matters in the Acquisition Agreement, the Issuer may not_
be able to enforce claims against the Sellers relating to breaches of these representations, warranties
and indemnities. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Transactions—We may not be able to enforce
_claims relating to a breach of the representations and warranties that the Sellers have provided to the_
_Issuer under the Acquisition Agreement.”_

Existing Facilities and certain other debt, and the payment of related fees and expenses and other costs
related to the Transactions consisted of proceeds from the following sources:

ordinary shares and fixed-return preferred shares issued by Holdco (the “Pari passu Shares”)
equaling approximately €596.8 million and contributed to the Issuer through intermediate
holding companies (the “Shareholder Equity Contribution”); and (ii) the Shareholders’
Reinvestment and investment from new managers of approximately €488.2 million, which

the Second Lien Facility in an aggregate amount of €310.0 million; and

**Overview**

We are a leading provider of HR solutions in key European staffing markets, offering end-to-end
temporary recruiting and outsourcing services. We supply specialized and niche staffing to primarily
small and medium-sized enterprise (“SME”) clients in a diversified range of end-markets. We offer and
tailor our services to the staffing needs of our clients through our engineering and consulting segment
and specialized talent solutions segment, which are comprised of a well-developed portfolio of ten
specialized business units, which we call Powerhouses, across various countries. We also offer digital
recruiting through our dedicated platforms, using our digital tools, including, NOWJOBS, SWOP and
Gighouse app, targeting low-skilled, high-volume markets with significant roll-out potential.

Since our founding, we have expanded from a presence in only Belgium to more than 10 countries in
Europe. Corresponding to our geographic expansion, we have also become more diversified in the endmarkets we serve, primarily through our acquisitions in recent years, which provide us with staffing
capabilities in additional areas such as pharmaceutical, healthcare, life sciences, government and public
administration and technology. As of September 30, 2022, we had 72,296 job candidates at work and
approximately 40,858 productive people at work (meaning the number of our job candidates adjusted
to reflect a 38 hour per week workweek) and 4,734 in-house full-time equivalent employees. For the
twelve months ended September 30, 2022, we had 31,456 unique clients, our Pro Forma Management
Adjusted Revenue was €2,770.0 million and our _Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA was_
€330.5 million.

Our engineering and consulting segment represents 53.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted
EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended
September 30, 2022. This segment supplies staffing of highly-skilled professionals, such as engineering
consultants and financial and insurance specialists, to fill specialized roles in a variety of end-markets,
such as financial, industrial, logistics, infrastructure, public administration and construction, and, more
recently, fast-evolving and highly resilient sectors such as energy, telecommunications,
pharmaceuticals and technology. This segment is comprised of our Abylsen, Continu Professionals,
Redmore, GRITT, Cohedron and SOLCOM Powerhouses and has the broadest geographic footprint,
with its primary operations in France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany. The engineering and
consulting segment assists clients in the search and selection of the right candidate, including for interim
management and secondments, and such temporary client assignments generally last for months. The
below chart illustrates in blue the type of client needs, worker qualifications and placement duration for
our engineering and consulting segment.


-----

Our specialized talent solutions segment represents 46.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted
EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended
September 30, 2022. This segment supplies specialized staffing of high-demand mid-skilled workers
for specialized positions, such as clerical positions, carpenters, nurses and machine engineers, as well
as blue-collar workers to companies in certain sectors, including construction, retail, finance, food,
healthcare and construction. This segment is comprised of our Accent, Covebo, TIMEPARTNER and
TMI Powerhouses, with their primary operations in Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany, as well as
branches in countries that form part of their international recruiting networks, which currently operate
principally for this segment though we are planning to expand them for our engineering and consulting
segment. These international branches provide us with the capability to source foreign candidates to
bridge the large gap between the demand for qualified job candidates and the supply of such candidates,
especially as the labor market in our Addressable Markets has tightened over the past few years. The
Specialized Talent Solution segment generally delivers job candidates through temporary agencies to
clients in a fast and flexible way when they are shorthanded, with duration of job placements typically
lasting for weeks, but they could also last hours or months depending on the needs of our clients. The
below chart illustrates in pink the type of client needs, worker qualifications and placement duration for
our Specialized Talent Solution segment.

We serve as an intermediary between job candidates and their ultimate employer by matching up
candidates that are looking to find a job, gain experience or find variety or flexibility with our clients
that are looking for specialist skills, flexible employee arrangements, time and cost efficiencies or to
cover peaks or sourcing for particular projects. We source and screen candidates, provide candidate
matching services and present candidates to the client. We also assist with the hiring of the candidates
by customers, client and candidate retention, provide timesheet, invoicing and payroll services, and
regularly follow up with clients. We aim to help our clients at all stages of the recruiting process to
relieve their management from the burden of having to seek appropriate job candidates for available
positions. To ensure that we are able to tap into skilled workforces, we offer career coaching to job
candidates in order to help them find career paths that align with their professional goals, and we provide
in-house training to equip them to match the job profiles in which they are interested or that are scarce
in the market to increase job candidates’ employability. We also offer support to foreign job candidates,
including housing, transport options, opening a bank account and other integration assistance.

We enter into employment contracts with the candidates and pay their salaries. We enter into placement
contracts with our clients and bill our clients for our services. Our bill-pay spread is a key driver of our
profitability and supports our industry-leading gross margins. We maximize bill-pay spread as a result
of candidate scarcity, our niche focus, our SME and local customer focus, our premium service offering,
our excellence in marketing candidates to jobs and non-solicitation or minimum fee/period protection
for candidates in respect of clients. We have strong pricing power driven by contractual dynamics that
ensure pass-through of salary increases. Our specialized talent solutions segment benefits from
contractual dynamics which allow for an automatic pass-through to clients of price increases, and our
business model also allows for limited bench risk because staffing contracts are back-to-back. In our


-----

engineering and consulting segment, price increases are typically passed through via negotiations with
our clients, and we effectively manage to keep our bench time low by matching confirmed upcoming
client assignments to candidates. The business model of these two segments has enabled us to establish
a track record of margin stability even during challenging economic conditions such as the Covid-19
pandemic and in the inflationary environment in 2022.

For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, we generated 27.6%, 39.8%, 26.0% and 5.5% of our
_Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue in Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and France,_
respectively. We have branches in the countries where we source job candidates, including Poland,
Romania, Spain, Czech Republic, Moldova and Portugal. As of September 30, 2022, we had a network
of 742 branches and 18 recruitment offices. To complement our physical network of branches and reach
new markets, we have pioneered several successful disruptor technologies, including our SWOP
application, our SWOP Recruiter application and our NOWJOBS platform. We have increased our
focus on developing digital support growth initiatives for our primary operations to enable us to reach
additional job candidates or serve new end-markets in a fully digital manner.

We support businesses by providing flexible staffing solutions that are used throughout all stages of the
economic cycle, resulting in our resilience during economic downturns. While the economy is strong,
the job market tightens meaning that our clients need help sourcing candidates. As markets soften,
companies typically shift to a more temporary workforce and need staffing solutions and flexibility.
When markets reach the bottom of the cycle, temporary staffing suffers but then is characterized by a
quick recovery as temporary employment tends to recover faster than permanent employment. For
example, during the outset of the Covid-19 pandemic, our business recovered from the early losses in
approximately three to six weeks. We also have a highly variable cost base and the ability to pass on
wage inflation, which supports the stability of our gross margins. For example, our Like-for-Like
Revenue growth (based on the December 31, 2021 perimeter) for 2019, 2020 and 2021 fluctuated
significantly due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and were 2%, (9)% and 19%, respectively,
but we were able to maintain a gross margin of approximately 28% throughout this period. Flexible
staffing solutions proved instrumental in the global economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic,
resulting in a full recovery of our sales during the year ended December 31, 2021. During the Covid-19
pandemic, the retail, food retail and hospitality sectors were severely impacted across all our key
markets due to lockdowns and other restrictive measures, which led to a significant reduction in our
staffing activities in these sectors. Certain sectors, such as logistics and education, however, proved to
be less sensitive to the impacts of the Covid-19 pandemic, and clients in these sectors continued to seek
our services, particularly for high-skilled, specialized roles. In addition, demand for staffing services
from municipalities and government agencies during the Covid-19 pandemic increased due to, among
other developments, work related to the administration of government support measures, which we were
able to capitalize on given our specialization in this end-market provided by the Cohedron Powerhouse
in our engineering and consulting segment.

We were founded in 1995 by Philip Cracco and Conny Vandendriessche along with a financial sponsor
as a Belgium-based recruiting firm. Originally called Accent, we changed our name to House of HR in
2012. Over the course of 2012 to 2014, Naxicap, a French private equity firm, acquired a majority stake
in our business, and we have expanded significantly to become a leading provider of specialized HR
solutions in multiple European markets. On November 3, 2022, Bain Capital acquired a majority stake
in the Group, with Naxicap, Conny Vandendriessche and management maintaining stakes. See “The
_Transactions.”_

Our acquisitions have resulted in increased revenue and increased geographical coverage, as well as
improved diversification of our services and the number of clients and end-markets that we serve. On
account of the number of acquisitions that we have undertaken and intend to continue to undertake, our
results of operations from period to period may not be comparable.

Acquisitions, which include the acquisition of majority stakes in equity investments or joint ventures
that were previously not accounted for as part of our consolidation perimeter, affect our results of
operations on inclusion in our consolidation perimeter. For example, during the year ended December
31, 2019, we accounted for Book’u as an associate; however, on May 19, 2020, we acquired a majority
stake in Book’u, and as a result, a full consolidation has been recorded for Book’u in the year ended
December 31, 2020. In addition, as acquired businesses are consolidated from the date of their
acquisition, the full impact of an acquisition is only reflected in our consolidated income statement and
statement of cash flows in the subsequent financial year.

Our cost of services, selling expenses and other general and administrative expenses have typically
increased in proportion to the size of the acquisitions we have undertaken. Certain acquisitions,
however, have created opportunities for margin improvements, particularly where such acquisitions
have shifted the services mix we offer from more general to more specialized, or where such
acquisitions have been in our engineering and consulting services segment, since more specialized job
candidates are typically in greater demand and can thus result in our Group having greater pricing power
when placing job candidates.

Because of the number of acquisitions we have undertaken and the nature of the businesses we acquire,
we carry a significant amount of goodwill on our balance sheet. As of September 30, 2022, goodwill
represented €1.2 billion or 49.5% of our total assets. Our goodwill is reduced by any accumulated
impairment losses. Goodwill is not amortized but it is tested for impairment annually, or more
frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate that it might be impaired. If an impairment
charge were made, we may record significant charges in our income statement under IFRS. For


-----

example, we performed an impairment test during the second quarter of 2022 given the rising interest
rate in the current market, which we consider to be an impairment indicator. Goodwill impairment in
relation to the GRITT Powerhouse was identified, as the recoverable amount was €40.9 million
compared to the carrying value of €54.2 million. We performed another impairment test during the third
quarter of 2022 due to further increases in interest rates, and identified no additional impairments. We
therefore recorded a goodwill impairment of €13.3 million for the nine months ending September 30,
2022, as we consider this change to have a long-term impact. Our margin based on current goodwill
impairment tests appears to be sufficient to avoid any material impairment risk in the near future. We
have historically financed acquisitions through a combination of borrowings, equity and excess cash
generated within the Group. We structure our acquisitions to include, from time to time, contingent and
deferred considerations that are included in the cost of the business combination at the fair value on the
date of the acquisitions. Apart from a number of earn-outs for which the remaining price to be paid by
us to sellers is currently estimated to be approximately €19.9 million if conditions precedent are reached,
we do not have any material financial or legal claims under the stock purchase agreements for the
acquisitions during the period under review. If the ABMI acquisition closes, an additional estimated
earn-out of €10.0 million may become payable if certain conditions precedents are reached. In addition,
under ABMI’s Put Option Agreement, we may be required to make certain payments up to an amount
of approximately €5.8 million if certain events occur, such as if we receive certain credits from the
French authorities.

We expect to continue to pursue smaller, margin-accretive, complementary bolt-on acquisitions, which
will become our Boutiques following the acquisitions, mainly in our existing markets, and we also
occasionally consider larger acquisitions that are otherwise consistent with our investment criteria. We
will continue to focus on acquisitions of highly specialized businesses (such as IT, legal and finance),
business focusing on bottleneck jobs and engineering and consulting services, as well as new
geographic. We are also targeting, in particular, certain new end-markets such as healthcare and
pharmaceuticals and new geographic markets such as the Nordic countries and other countries, such as
Austria and Switzerland. For further discussion regarding our acquisitions strategy, please refer to
“Business—Our Strategies—Continue to target accretive acquisition opportunities to achieve
_European leadership.”_

**_Changes in Segment Reporting Beginning in 2021_**

We had historically structured our business across three segments: engineering and consulting,
specialized staffing and general staffing. In the first quarter of 2021, we integrated our legacy
specialized staffing and general staffing segments into the current specialized talent solutions segment,
and we have been presenting our results in two segments since then to reflect the integration.

This change in segment reporting better reflects our strategy towards becoming further specialized in
the human resources solutions market, as well as allows us to more clearly present our portfolio of
services to our client base.

Our financial information disclosed in this Offering Memorandum is presented under this new dual
segment structure for the periods under review. Our financial information for the specialized talent
solutions segment as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 represent the sum of the
results of the legacy specialized staffing and general staffing segments. As a result, such information
may not be directly comparable with the information included in our 2020 Financial Statements.

See note 6 to our 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements for further information.

**_Our Interim Results Fluctuate as a result of Seasonality in our Business_**

Our revenue is subject to seasonal fluctuations in many of the end-markets in which we operate. We
have in the past experienced, and expect in the future to experience, fluctuations in our results of
operations due to seasonal demand in our current end-markets. Seasonality means that our results vary


-----

from quarter to quarter, and therefore the results of one quarter may not be indicative of results for the
full year. Seasonality varies depending on a number of different factors and can impact our two staffing
segments differently. The underlying end-markets we serve are subject to various drivers that impact
overall end-market demand and therefore demand from our clients for staffing. For example, the
construction end-market may experience inclement weather on a worksite, which can decrease demand
for our job candidates. As a result of the mix of services we provide, seasonal work can also cause peaks
in demand during a specific period, such as around harvest time in the food production sector or around
holiday periods, such as the Christmas holidays, Easter and summer holidays, especially for the
businesses that are active in the event, hospitality and food sectors. Historically as a general matter, our
revenue fluctuates, with higher levels of revenue typically generated in the second quarter of the year,
then decreases during the summer holidays and increases again in the second half of the year beginning
just after the summer holidays, which then lasts for a sustained period before decreasing again in
December due to Christmas holidays. Due to this seasonality effect, we do not expect our Unaudited
Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements to be reflective of the results we anticipate for
the full year to which they apply. The 2020 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements were
additionally impacted by Covid-19, which impacted the traditional seasonality patterns experienced by
the Group with respect to revenue and working capital (with a number of governments granting
postponements to certain tax or other expenses and providing grants for certain unemployment support
that temporarily decreased the Group’s working capital needs) compared to previous years, though the
working capital dynamics of our business are such we are largely able to match payables with
receivables for job candidates at work at SMEs, which provides us with some counter cyclicality.

Moreover, we also experience seasonality with regard to our working capital requirements. We
generally experience larger working capital requirements in the first half of the year due to increased
holiday pay, bonus pay and tax payments. While our working capital requirements are generally lower
in the second half of the year, our working capital requirements also experience an increase at the end
of the year for end-of year bonuses and holiday pay, particularly as certain of our businesses institute
mandatory holidays at the end of the year.

For additional information see “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our
_interim results fluctuate as a result of seasonality in our business.”_

**Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations**

Our results of operations have been affected in the periods under review, and are expected to continue
to be affected, by various key factors relating to our business and industry, which we describe below.

**_General economic conditions_**

Economic and trading conditions in the countries in which we operate, or which we plan to enter, have
impacted our business in the past and will likely impact our business going forward in various ways.
While our business has historically generally been able to mitigate the fluctuations of the business cycle
due to a flexible cost structure, economic downturns can lead to a decrease in demand for our services.
Similarly, growth in national and international economies (i.e., GDP growth), particularly in the sectors
in which we specialize, can lead to increased demand for our services. Among our two business
segments, specialized talent solutions has historically, due to the temporary and flexible staffing
element in this segment, been more sensitive to economic fluctuations, which has led to decreases in
demand for such services in connection with economic downturns, but has often exhibited an early
resurgence after a recession as companies often reach for this resource as they invest in the growth of
their operations. Conversely, our engineering and consulting segment has historically been more
“defensive,” and as a result may show the effects of economic fluctuations less intensely and may take
longer after any economic downturn to recover. We have observed this same pattern in both 2020 and
2021, as the temporary and flexible staffing activities of the specialized talent segment had by the end
of 2020 returned to levels comparable to, and in 2021 surpassed, those seen in 2019, as measured by
weekly productive job candidates, outpacing the activity level of that for the engineering and consulting
segment during the same period. For most of our Boutiques, “productive job candidates” are defined as
job candidates working at the customer premises, expressed in full-time equivalents for the time they
are on client assignments.

The Covid-19 pandemic impacted the demand for our staffing services in 2020, and any resurgence of
Covid-19 or emergence of new variants or other pandemics could lead to potential future impact. At the
same time, there were a number of government initiatives introduced during the Covid-19 pandemic
that positively contributed to the Group’s ability to manage cash flows. A number of these measures,
however, ended in the course of 2021 or will end in the near future. Historically, following periods of
crisis the Group has demonstrated an ability to rebound, in part based on its decentralized structure,
allowing for flexible decision-making based on local needs and legislation, including revisions to
incentive-based structures to adapt to the changing environment. Management believes that the Group’s
strong geographical, segment and sector diversification has allowed it to smooth the impact and
recovery across the business as demonstrated by the positive EBITDA it recorded every month
throughout the Covid-19 crisis. Economic activities in our primary geographic markets normalized and
recovered to pre-Covid-19 levels in 2021 and this trend was carried into 2022. Despite the outbreak of
the new strain of Covid-19 virus Omicron in the last weeks of 2021 and at the beginning of 2022, we
are recording a higher number of productive job candidates at work each of the weeks in 2022 to date
as compared to 2019, 2020 and 2021.

The outbreak of the war in Ukraine in February 2022 has caused an immediate impact on global
economic conditions, and the uncertain resolution of this conflict could result in protracted and severe
damage to the global economy. Although we do not have direct economic activities in Russia and
Ukraine, it is difficult to predict the scope and extent of any potential impacts the war could have on
our operations, especially given we source candidates from Eastern Europe. The war has also caused
supply shortage of, and therefore increased prices of, gas, energy and other raw materials, further
disrupted the global supply chain, which had already been impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, and
added to inflation, all of which are significantly impacting many companies, industries and sectors
directly and indirectly, resulting in us incurring increased operating costs and our clients reconsidering


-----

their recruitment efforts of domestic and foreign talents, which may, in turn, impact our results of
operations. Some customers, mainly those in Germany, have ended their requests for flexible staffing
solutions due to the shortage of goods or the challenges of exporting goods to Ukraine and Russia. At
the same time, the labor cost inflation as a result of the overall inflation is expected to lead to higher
costs of labor in relation to both our in-house employees and our people at work, which in turn will lead
to an increase in the Group’s operating costs, especially in Belgium where labor cost inflation is linked
to consumer price index increases. Such impact is not as significant to our specialized talent solutions
segment, as the cost of people at work within this segment can be passed through almost immediately
to the majority of our clients; however, this does not always apply to our engineering and consulting
segment as the contracts we enter into with our clients in this segment do not typically include automatic
wage pass-through provisions. Notwithstanding the above, we are generally able to pass through the
increased costs due to labor shortage and inflation to our clients.

In addition to these general trends, our results of operations have been impacted and we expect will
continue to be impacted by certain other key macroeconomic conditions, such as the changing
demographic mix as the number of people retiring outpaces the number of people entering the labor
force, unemployment rates and staffing penetration, in the geographic markets in which we operate.
Low unemployment rates often indicate a shortage of available workers in an economy, which can
increase the demand for our job candidates, whom we often recruit from other countries and
increasingly through our digital initiatives in an effort to establish a steady inflow. Furthermore,
increases in staffing penetration can indicate a greater prevalence or acceptance of temporary staffing
in an economy, which increases the market for our services. We generally operate in geographic markets
that are characterized by high average salaries, low unemployment and which are well developed and
mature in the temporary staffing and consulting fields. As a result of these trends, the demand for our
services has increased significantly over the last decade.

For further information relating to the outlook for the staffing solutions industry in our main
geographical markets, see “Industry and Market Data.”

Macroeconomic trends within each of our primary markets also contribute to the performance of our
operations in each of these countries:

_Belgium_

Data from the European Commission shows that annual real GDP growth in Belgium was 2.1%, (5.7)%
and 6.2% in 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively. Belgium has also continued to experience a tightening
in the labor market as the population ages and there are fewer local workers to take the place of retirees.
Furthermore, Belgium has also been experiencing high employment rates due to employment
outgrowing the active population. Unemployment in Belgium has gone from 7.5% in 2007 to 6.4% in
2021, according to data from the World Bank. Staffing penetration has also increased in response to
this tightening of the labor market and decrease in unemployment. In the near term, while growth
saturation of employment will likely slow our growth in Belgium in the private sector, the opening of
certain public sector opportunities may offset this slowdown to a certain degree.

Management believes that the impact of potential client default is limited. As an illustration, the
historical rate of insolvencies (as a percentage of company stock) in Belgium from 2007 to 2016, based
on third party market data, has ranged between 0.5% to a maximum of 2.2% for small and medium
sized firms and below 0.5% for larger firms with over 250 employees, including during the financial
crisis of 2008-2009. Accordingly, bad debt provisions as a percentage of sales in Accent have ranged
steadily between 0% to 0.3% of sales, on an LTM basis, from 2017 through September 30, 2022.

_The Netherlands_

Data from the European Commission shows that annual real GDP growth was 2.0%, (3.8)% and 5.0%
in 2019, 2020 and 2021 respectively, in the Netherlands. As is the case elsewhere, GDP growth in the


-----

Netherlands affects us primarily through its effect on the end-markets in which our clients operate. Our
engineering and consulting and specialized staffing segments in the Netherlands are affected by growth
in the construction and engineering markets, which in turn are driven by overall domestic economic
growth. Long-term demographic and economic trends are also driving a demand for construction
workers. After a downturn from 2009 until 2012, the Dutch construction end-market has been growing
significantly due in part to general economic resurgence, low interest rates, as well an increase in
environmentally-focused project or larger infrastructure projects. These trends contribute to demand for
job candidates with specialties and skills that operate in the construction end-market.

The Netherlands also has a number of jobs that are driven by regulatory developments in addition to
GDP fluctuations. For example, demand for job candidates in the financial services sector is impacted
by the growth in financial regulation. This impacts demand for our services, due to the fact that, within
our engineering and consulting segment, our Powerhouse Redmore provides job candidates with
technical, specialized skills to the financial sector. This also happens in the public and government
sector, an end-market that our Powerhouse Cohedron addresses.

The Netherlands, similarly to Belgium, has historically had low unemployment rates which impacts our
business positively. Between 2007 and 2014, the unemployment rate in the Netherlands rose from 4.2%
to 7.4%, but then decreased to 4.0% in 2021 (according to data from the World Bank). This low
unemployment rate has led to fewer local individuals going into the strenuous working conditions of
the logistics workforce, which has supported demand for our job candidates, including our foreign job
candidates, who have experience in this sector and can meet demand for such jobs.

_Germany_

Data from the European Commission shows that annual real GDP growth in Germany was 1.1%, (4.6)%
and 2.9% in 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively. In Germany, our general staffing activity is GDPsensitive and exposes us more directly to fluctuations in GDP and economic change. As GDP slows,
market value grows at a slower pace and the number of hours worked by an individual decreases. Lowskilled, mainly blue-collar workers are, however, in structural shortage in Germany, which provides
opportunities for our services.

Unemployment in Germany between 2007 and 2021 fell from 8.7% to 3.5% (according to data from
the World Bank). Companies are, therefore, expected to continue to address staff shortages through
temporary staffing. Moreover, we believe that generally lower-skilled workers do not travel as much,
which can lead to significantly localized shortages in demand. Some companies, including ours,
overcome this barrier through sourcing in Eastern Europe where lower skilled workers are willing to
travel. Decreasing unemployment and shortages of low-skilled blue-collar workers has driven an
increased reliance on temp workers leading to an increase in demand for our services.

Finally, the staffing industry specifically was impacted by certain German regulatory reforms, including
the Act on Staffing (Arbeitnehmerüberlassungsgesetz) (“AÜG”), which has been substantially amended
over the years, most recently in 2017. The focus of the 2017 amendment was to strengthen permanent
employment; as a result, a maximum period for temporary staffing has been introduced and formal
requirements have been tightened up as has the equal pay principle. Providing staffing services in the
construction industry in Germany is also generally prohibited by law, although it is possible for a
staffing solutions provider who is active in the construction industry to obtain a specific permit.
Additionally, beginning in 2021 the German government has generally forbidden staffing companies to
work in the meat industry as a result of the sanitary crisis in 2020. See “—Changes in regulation—
_Temporary Employment Regulations.”_

_France_

Data from the European Commission shows that annual real GDP growth in France was 1.8%, (7.9)%
and 7.0% in 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively. In France, we only provide engineering consulting


-----

under our engineering and consulting segment, which has historically been insulated to a significant
degree from GDP fluctuations.

The unemployment rate in France has increased from 7.7% to 8.1% between 2007 and 2021 (according
to data from the World Bank), which is higher than the other countries in which we work. As we operate
in a specialized sector in France, the structurally high unemployment in France, however, has not
impacted demand for our services in a material manner, nor do we expect it to do so in the future.

_Brexit_

On January 1, 2021, the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement entered into force provisionally and
entered into force on May 1, 2021. Despite the implementation of the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation
Agreement, there remains significant uncertainty as to how the agreement will affect relations between
the United Kingdom and the European Union. Significant political and economic uncertainty remains
about whether the terms of the relationship will differ materially in practice from the terms before
withdrawal. Lack of clarity about future laws and regulations in the United Kingdom as the United
Kingdom determines which European Union laws to replace or replicate could depress economic
activity and restrict our access to capital. The economic outlook could be further adversely affected by:
(i) the risk arising from changes in laws and regulations in the U.K.; (ii) the risk that movements in the
pound sterling exchange rates related to Brexit could damage competitiveness or profitability; (iii) the
risk that goods moving between the U.K. and any member of the EU will be subject to duties and tariffs;
and (iv) the risk that goods moving between the U.K. and any member of the EU will be subject to
additional inspections and documentation checks, leading to possible delays at ports of entry and
departure.

As the U.K. represents a key export market for several of the countries in which we operate, particularly
Belgium and the Netherlands, adverse trade terms between the U.K. and the countries in which we
operate could have an adverse effect on the economies of these countries, which could by extension
adversely affect our business.

Furthermore, Brexit has limited the ability of individuals from various foreign countries to work in the
U.K., which increased the supply of job candidates in several of the countries in which we operate, but
we believe that this trend has not significantly impacted our Gross Margin.

See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our results of operations could be
_materially adversely affected by volatile or uncertain economic conditions.”_

**_Changes in regulation_**

While the markets in which we operate tend to be fairly stable from a legal and regulatory perspective,
from time to time there are changes that may impact the performance of our business. Our industry is
extensively regulated by regulatory authorities in each of the countries in which we operate and at an
EU level. These regulations impact how we structure our employment agreements with job candidates
and our service agreements with clients. See “Regulation.” During the period under review, certain
changes in the regulatory frameworks, particularly the new legislations on payroll that took effect in the
Netherlands from January 1, 2020 which, among other things, mandated that payroll employees are
entitled to all terms and conditions as the client’s employees in similar positions, impacted our results
of operations.

_Temporary Employment Regulation_

Regulations around temporary employment can impact the clients and opportunities that are available
to us. For example, as from the 2017 to 2018 period, the Belgian region of Flanders and the Belgian
federal government authorized temporary employment in the public sector for periods of up to twelve
months, which has provided additional opportunities to place temporary employees within these sectors.
While this practice is still not permitted in the Belgian region of Wallonia, if in the future and to the


-----

extent that this region adopts a similar policy, it could further increase our ability to provide our services
in that region.

Moreover, regulations can affect the duration of our services. In Germany, since the last reform of the
AÜG in April 2017, the assignment period of temporary workers was limited to 18 months (with
exceptions) after which the employee either needs to be let go from the company where they were
working or accepted on to the general payroll of that company. As a result, as our job candidates
approach the end of their assignment period they will either need to be replaced, which can be difficult
during times of scarcity of qualified job candidates, or are taken over by the client resulting in lower
volumes for us. Furthermore, wages and benefits of temporary workers are aligned to those of the
employees of the company after nine months of uninterrupted assignment (through the “EqualPay”
mechanism), but must be paid by the staffing solutions provider, which increases the administrative
burden on us. In addition, beginning in 2021 the German government has generally forbidden staffing
companies to work in the meat industry as a result of the sanitary crisis in 2020.

In the Netherlands, there have been low-wage benefits regulations (“LIV”) which create subsidies for
the employment of low-wage workers since January 2017. This law is aimed at incentivizing employers
to hire employees who have a vulnerable position in the labor market. A review of these incentives,
however, resulted in cuts to the maximum compensation to the normal LIV in 2020, which resulted in
lower subsidies obtained in 2020 as compared to prior years, especially in Covebo, despite comparable
turnover. In November 2022, this law was further revised and it was decided that, only for 2022, the
LIV benefit for 2022 will be increased retroactively, while the LIV benefit for 2023 will be remain at
the normal level and the LIV benefit for 2024 will be reduced. If the planned pension reform goes ahead
in 2025, the LIV will end in 2024. Moreover, under the Wet Aanpak Schijnconstructies (“WAS”)
regulation, cost related to workers, can be withheld from workers’ wages only if the wage remains
above net minimum wage (since January 2016). However, deductions are still allowed below minimum
wage for pension and healthcare insurance. All other deductions are not allowed if the net salary then
becomes below minimum wage. For these non-deducted costs, we send invoices to the workers. If
workers do not pay their invoices and return to their country of origin, we are left with the costs. This
regulation has no impact for the clients.

Significant Dutch law changes came into effect with respect to temporary agency work and payrolling,
among others. From January 1, 2020, the Balanced Labor Market Act (Wet Arbeidsmarkt in balans)
(“WAB”) came into effect. For example, there will be increased social security charges for temporary
staffing agencies in their capacity as employer. Furthermore, payroll employees will be entitled to all
terms and conditions as the client’s employees in similar positions. These regulations came into effect
in 2020 and our cost of services has increased, but simultaneously also our sales prices increased. We
currently see that we have been able to pass on the majority of these increases in costs to our clients
through higher fees charged for our services.

Furthermore, new legislation has come into effect requiring employment housing to remain available
for four weeks following the end of employment of foreign workers. Currently, the majority of foreign
workers leave employment housing immediately following the end of their employment, or during the
weekend thereafter. Foreign workers that do remain in employment housing are required to pay weekly
rent, and we send them weekly invoices. There is increasing attention in the Netherlands on separation
between employment providers and housing providers. While this separation is not currently legally
required, our Covebo Powerhouse has already implemented relevant measures to address it. We expect
a contractual separation will be enforced in the future; however, there is currently no clear indication as
to the extent of what the required separation will be, and we cannot be certain at this time whether a
complete separation, or a full ban on the provision of housing to temporary workers by employment
agencies, will be legally required in the future.

For a further discussion of the regulatory framework in which we conduct our business in our principal
geographic end-markets, see “Regulation.”


-----

_Tax Regulation_

Changes in tax law can impact our current and future tax liabilities, and can also lead to reversals of
certain deferred tax income balances. For example, the Belgian Corporate Income Tax regime has been
modified by the Belgian Government by means of the Corporate Income Tax Reform Act of December
25, 2017 (Official Gazette of December 29, 2017). As a result of the reform, we remeasured our deferred
income tax balances. Deferred income tax expected to be reversed in the year to December 31, 2021
and December 31, 2020 has been measured using the effective rate that will apply in Belgium for the
period (29.58%). Deferred income tax expected to be reversed beyond December 31, 2021 has been
measured with an effective rate of 25%.

Further, the Dutch corporate income tax rates and brackets have been modified. As of January 1, 2022,
the Netherlands levies Dutch corporate income tax at a rate of 15% with respect to taxable profits up to
€395,000 and 25.8% with respect to taxable profits in excess of that amount.

_Financial regulation_

While regulations on banking, insurance and the financial industry as a whole only have an indirect
material effect on our business, recent regulatory developments in the financial industry between 2016
and 2019, including the updates to the financial supervision amendment Act, the Packaged Retail and
Insurance-based Investment Products regulation, the Capital Markets Union, the International Financial
Reporting Standards, final documents on the Reform of Basel III (“Basel IV”), Customer DD/Know
your Customer regulations, the Uniform Calculation Method-Uniform pension calculation, and the new
EU Directive on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision
(“IORP II”), have created a heightened need for specialized employees, which can create additional
demand for our job candidates who focus on compliance and legal matters in the financial industry.

_ESG Regulation_

On April 21, 2021, the European Commission adopted a proposal for the CSRD, which would amend
the existing reporting requirements of the Non-Financial Reporting Directive and encourage corporate
spending towards sustainable activities across the EU. The European Council approved the CSRD on
November 28, 2022 and the application of the regulation is expected to take place in four stages, the
first of which will require companies that already fall under the CSRD to complete their first CSRD
reporting on the financial year 2024, with expected reporting deadlines in 2025. We expect that we will
be required to comply with the CSRD. We cannot guarantee how the CSRD will impact our governance
structure and our day-to-day business activities. We have a formalized ESG charter to guide us on
achieving our targeted ESG KPIs and complying with relevant ESG regulations. See “Business—
_Environmental, Social and Governance” for information on our ESG initiatives._

**_Drivers of sales and pricing_**

_Organic Growth_

In addition to the sales growth created through the acquisitions discussed above (see “—Factors
_Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Statements—Acquisitions, Disposals and the_
_Comparability of our Financial Statements”), our sales are impacted by the Organic Growth of our_
business. We measure Organic Growth by analyzing revenue growth between one financial period and
the comparable prior period, excluding the impact of acquisitions on revenue as follows:

- in respect of revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 (compared against the nine
months ended September 30, 2021), we have excluded the impact of acquisitions on revenue
by assuming that no acquisitions have occurred after January 1, 2021;


-----

- in respect of revenue for 2021 (compared against 2020), we have excluded the impact of
acquisitions on revenue by assuming that no acquisitions have occurred after January 1, 2020;
and

- in respect of revenue for 2020 (compared against 2019), we have excluded the impact of
acquisitions on revenue by assuming that no acquisitions have occurred after January 1, 2019
or that divestments have taken place as of January 1, 2019.

The key drivers of the Organic Growth of our business are:

- increasing our geographic footprint by opening new branches with our “cell division” approach;

- continuing our growth in stronghold sectors and niches;

- winning new contracts with clients;

- expanding our work with existing clients;

- sourcing additional job candidates that can fill scarce assignments held by our clients;

- increasing candidate sourcing through international recruitment;

- digitalization;

- expanding into new business lines; and

- pricing growth.

We seek to minimize the financial risk of new offices by focusing on securing new sales in a geographic
region before committing to additional costs of a new office there. Historically, we have successfully
hired additional sales employees onto our payroll to win new contracts with clients; our Powerhouse
Continu Professionals has notably employed this approach successfully. Furthermore, our business
integration in Germany and the expansion of our business through the opening of new branches of our
existing Powerhouses in 2022 have accelerated our Organic Growth. When doing bolt-on acquisitions
in new but matching sectors, we have successfully expanded these services to existing branches, as
proven by Continu Professionals with the acquisition of mténv.

Moreover, our Organic Growth is impacted by our ability to improve the utilization of job candidates
and reduce our bench time, see “—Gross Margin—Bench time/Utilization,” increasing our sales in time
and material contracts over any given period.

Our ability to expand our business geographically by opening offices in new locations also functions as
an incentive to reward employees who have demonstrated strong results and initiative and would be
well-suited to lead new offices. We typically open new offices when we receive a significant number
of requests from existing clients or prospective clients to provide services in new locations or when we
see increasing demand for our services coming from a specific region. Expansion through opening new
offices has positively impacted and is expected to continue to impact our operating profits.

_Staffing volume_

The key drivers of staffing volume in any given market are the macro-economic and sector specific
growth, and the labor tightness, see “—General economic conditions” discussed above and the
regulatory environment, see “—Changes in regulation” above.

**_Pricing_**


-----

The substantial majority of our service agreements are structured to give us the ability to pass-through
wage increases from inflation to customers in both of our segments. See “Business—Our Strengths—
_Ability to pass through wage increases to customers, including through automatic contractual_
_mechanisms, and stable margins.”_

In the specialized talent solutions segment, which accounted for 46.5% of our Pro Forma Management
Adjusted EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended
September 30, 2022, price increases are automatically passed through to our clients. For this segment,
our contract model is centered on matching the length of our candidate’s employment contract with us
to the length of our placement contract with our client, the ultimate employer, in order to limit bench
time risk and prevent lag time between inflation of gross salary paid to the candidate and the cost we
charge to our clients, which results in an automatic pass-through of any salary increases. Under these
types of contracts, the utilization risk of the job candidates in between contracts is reduced. In Germany,
temporary workers are, however, required to be on the temporary employment company’s payroll,
which creates bench time risk for us with regard to our temporary job candidates in our specialized
talent solutions segment. In many cases, bench time is limited, as temporary workers’ contracts can
usually be terminated in, on average, two weeks’ notice given during the time of the job candidate’s
last assignment, unless we decide to retain them. At the end of our contracts, we renegotiate them, which
has historically resulted in an ability to increase our prices in line with wage inflation. Our revenues
typically correlate with nominal GDP rather than real GDP due to our stables margins and ability to
pass through wage increases in an inflationary environment. We base our contract pricing on a
candidate’s gross salary multiplied by a coefficient factor, with the split typically being transparent to
the client. The key pricing drivers for the coefficient factor are the scarcity of candidates and the value
of any additional services we offer. Key costs for us include salaries and work accident insurance. At
the end of the contract period, typically one week or one month in length, if the salary increases, then
we charge the cost of the higher salary to the client. In the specialized talent solutions segment,
regulations in Belgium and the Netherlands require that job candidates through our services are paid
the same as local or company-sourced workers, while this applies in Germany only after a job candidate
has worked for the employer for a certain period of time. The following chart illustrates our revenue
per billed hour for the specialized talent solutions segment.

In our engineering and consulting segment, which accounted for 53.5% of our Pro Forma Management
Adjusted EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended
September 30, 2022, price increases are typically passed through via negotiations with clients. The
contracts are typically time and material contracts, which means we are compensated for the time that
our job candidates spend with a client on assignment, and have no obligations for any specific result.
Most of our candidates in our engineering and consulting segment are permanently hired by us on
employment contracts that typically have three- to six-week notice periods and we have placement
contracts with our clients that typically last nine to twelve months, which allows us to effectively
manage bench time and match our candidates with the upcoming mandates from clients. In most cases,
we plan for salary increases in advance and negotiate rate increases with our clients accordingly. Our
pricing model in our engineering and consulting segment centers on charging the client an hourly or


-----

daily rate. Our billing rate is typically based on an hourly wage and a mark-up where the split is usually
not transparent to clients. Key drivers of the hourly or daily rates are skills, seniority and scarcity of
candidates. Our key costs include salary, potentially including a company car. At the end of a placement
contract, renewal either entails replacing the candidate with a new or more junior person at a new price
or by placing the same candidate, at a more senior level with a higher salary. Margin growth in our
engineering and consulting segment is driven by increasing the cost per hour paid and billed. The hourly
and daily pricing model for engineering and consulting positions generally produces higher Gross
Margins than factor pricing based on the job candidates’ gross salaries. In our engineering and
consulting segment, there is a higher risk of bench time than in our specialized talent solutions segment,
as a result of our job candidates being on our payroll but not being used on a paid job assignment. As
their employer, we are still responsible for their costs even if they are not generating money for our
operations. To mitigate the bench time risk, we carefully monitor our job candidates that are our
employees with indefinite term contracts and seek to minimize their bench time by lining up
assignments to transition to once a current one is complete, or by terminating employment agreements
as appropriate should transition to another assignment be not feasible or desirable. The following chart
illustrates our revenue per billed hour for the engineering and consulting segment.
