We also perform a limited amount of work under search and selection contracts in both of our business
segments through our Accent (through the Ctrl-F brand), Redmore (through the Ctrl-F brand),
TIMEPARTNER, Continu Professionals, Covebo, GRITT and TMI Powerhouses. This can be done
either by the Powerhouses themselves or through one of their Boutiques. Unlike for other types of
contracts, the full amount of the commissions typically remains with us as it is not subject to cost of
services or other deductions. In such arrangements, we do not benefit from a share of the on-going
revenue during the duration of the employment as we do in other contracts.

We also perform certain amount of work placing freelancers. In the case of freelancers, rather than
receiving a salary from us, the freelancers submit invoices to us for the services they have provided to
the relevant client. Freelancers produce smaller Gross Margins for us as they are generally more
experienced and are therefore more expensive to hire, but this is partially compensated by the fact that
freelancers present no bench risk for us.

**_Competition_**

Our results of operations are impacted by the levels of competition that we experience in each of the
markets in which we operate and in any new markets that we may enter. We compete with other firms
offering HR solutions to both clients and job candidates to varying degrees in each of the geographical
markets and staffing segments in which we operate. Competition for both of these groups is based on a
variety of factors, and such competition has intensified following the Covid-19 pandemic due to the
general labor shortage. Competitive factors in obtaining and retaining clients can include the ability to
find job candidates with the appropriate skills and/or experience, brand awareness, quality, speed of
client service, proximity to the client and particularly in relation to temporary staffing services, and
price. Competitive factors in obtaining and retaining job candidates can include wages, quality of
engagement, number of hours of work available, responsiveness to work schedules, job content and
type of project, personal validation of the job candidates and brand image.


-----

On large contracts, which are more common in temporary staffing services under our specialized talent
solutions segment, there is often pressure on pricing due to the increased competitiveness in the
industry. There is often less pricing pressure in our engineering and consulting segment, due to the
scarcity of candidates to fill certain roles. As a result, this segment and the higher margins associated
with these fields are becoming increasingly attractive to firms in the industry.

In certain of our key geographic markets, such as the Netherlands, the specialized HR solutions market
is relatively mature with comparatively established pricing. Across all four of our key geographic
markets the industry is fragmented. In individual markets and specialist sectors, we compete with
smaller, more localized or more specialized firms. As a result of the trend towards consolidation in the
specialized HR solutions industry, we also compete with larger full-service and specialized competitors
in the international, national, regional and local markets. In addition, some current and prospective
clients, particularly among larger corporates, may elect not to fill their staffing requirements from
outside sources, and may instead hire independent contractors directly on a temporary basis or provide
similar services internally. Many clients use more than one staffing services provider, and the majority
of client relationships are non-exclusive.

Websites, search engines and online job boards, such as Google for Jobs, monsterboard.nl and Indeed
are improving their matching capabilities, potentially affecting part of our business. Pricing,
promotional and marketing actions of our competitors may also impact our business, such that our price
levels could be impacted or that we need to invest more in marketing and advertising to obtain the right
candidates.

For a further discussion of our competitors in each of our divisions, see “Industry and Market Data.”

_Cost of Services_

Cost of services comprises costs directly attributable to revenue, which mainly relate to costs associated
with our job candidates, such as their wages and salaries, social security charges, training costs, other
benefits (including housing expenses, car leases, mobility costs, vouchers for meals and other
incentives, such as reimbursements to job candidates for utilizing environmentally friendly
transportation solutions as well as other benefits for job candidates), and costs associated with
freelancers. A small portion of these costs relates to material costs for projects performed in GRITT
Projects, which was divested in 2020. Our job candidates’ wages and salaries, social security and other
benefits amounted to our largest cost of services during the period under review. The principal factor
that affects these costs is the number of job candidates that we employ. As a result, these costs increase


-----

as we add additional job candidates either through growing our business organically or through
acquisitions. Our overall number of job candidates, however, may not be representative of our expected
cost of services since these costs will be impacted by the level of compensation each job candidate
receives, which is in turn linked to inflation, specializations, qualifications and positions filled by each
job candidate.

During the period of Covid-19, which had a particularly severe impact on the global economy in 2020,
attracting foreign nationals entailed additional costs, given restrictions on crossing borders and
additional quarantine measures and isolation requirements which led to increased numbers of days of
unproductivity, with the result of increased housing expenses, hygienic and sanitary costs and provision
of groceries for candidates arriving from abroad. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our cost of
services decreased by 7.8%, from €1,288.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €1,188.2
million. This was in parallel with an 8.2% decrease in revenue during the same period, from €1,738.4
million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €1,596.3 million for the year ended December 31,
2020. This illustrates the largely variable nature of our cost base, as Accent, Continu Professionals and
Covebo mainly employ workers whose contracts can be terminated immediately, or who can be put on
the bench without cost, as well as freelancers. For workers with less flexible conditions, typically
because they are on our payroll with an indefinite term contract, such as the specialists employed by
GRITT, Abylsen and TIMEPARTNER (including AERO and IBB) under permanent contracts and
whose costs of services are therefore semi-variable, we were able to rely on economic unemployment
measures to decrease the related costs. In some cases, even when companies could terminate contracts
immediately, they chose not to do so and instead opted to rely on certain government economic
unemployment initiatives so they could scale up quickly when the Covid-19 restrictive measures eased.
These companies also employ freelancers, for whom costs are fully variable. Such additional costs
reduced in 2021 as lockdown measures eased, which consequentially also led to a higher level of
staffing activities compared to 2020. For the year ended December 31, 2021, our cost of services
increased by 26.6%, from €1,188.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €1,504.3 million.
This was in parallel with a 28.4% increase in revenue during the same period, from €1,596.3 million
for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €2,050.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021.

Given the nature of our operations, which typically results in us placing our job candidates on our
payroll while they are on assignment, we are required to insure a significant number of persons against
work accidents, which impacts our cost of services. Since 2021, a variable premium rate has been
applied to our work accident insurance, with a base premium rate of 2.918%, a mid-case rate of 3.064%
and worst-case rate of 3.097%, depending on the number of work accidents we have. This premium is
calculated based on the gross salary mass of our temporary workers. Such cost will be partly offset by
customer compensations and efforts to lower accident occurrence and further offset by other cost
reductions, following efficiencies realized in other departmental costs within Accent.

Ransomware and other cyber risks have increased in general during Covid-19 and also require us to
invest in a higher standard of back-up procedures as work from home and remote working practices
predominate, especially in relation to compliance with data protection laws, avoidance of
misappropriation and cyber theft, leading to higher operating costs for our information technologies, as
additional work, licenses and expertise is needed to detect and prevent adverse occurrences. This also
increased our cost of services since 2020.

_Gross Margin_

Our Gross Margin represents our gross profit (our revenue less our cost of services) divided by our
revenue. Our Gross Margin was 25.9%, 25.6% and 26.6% for the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020
and 2021, and 26.0% and 26.3% for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 and 2022, respectively.

There are two primary drivers of our Gross Margin: the bill-pay spread and the bench time/utilization
of our job candidates (particularly our job candidates in our engineering and consulting segment):


-----

- _Bill-pay spread: We will typically enter into an employment agreement with the job candidate_
(often for the duration of an assignment or longer in the case of certain business units) and we
will enter into a placement contract or project contract with the client. We then bill the client
for the services performed by the job candidate who are on time and material contracts and pay
the salary of the job candidate. The percentage difference between what we bill our clients and
what we pay as salary to the job candidates is referred to as the “bill-pay spread” and it is the
key driver of our profitability.

- _Bench time/Utilization: Job candidates in most of our engineering and consulting business units_
as well as our job candidates in Germany are our permanent employees on our payroll whether
or not they are on assignment with a client. As a result, our engineering and consulting segment
in particular carefully monitors the end date of all job candidates’ assignments and aims to line
up the next assignment before their current ones come to an end. This monitoring seeks to
minimize “bench time,” which is the time for which job candidates are paid but cannot be billed
to a client assignment. Our bench time for 2021 was approximately 0.3%. By minimizing a job
candidate’s bench time, we aim to ensure the job candidate is being utilized on a project that
requires his or her skill set, so there is a match between what we bill the client for the job
candidate’s services and what we pay the job candidate. New assignments also ensure future
career development of the job candidate. Furthermore, the impact of utilization upon our Gross
Margin will also depend on the mix of job candidates whose utilization is impacted, with the
more specialized job candidates typically performing work under contracts with higher bill-pay
spreads as a result of their scarcity and specialization. As most of our contracts are on a time
and materials basis, increased utilization rates will typically improve our Gross Margin.

The Covid-19 pandemic has presented an additional impact on our Gross Margin as a result of various
local government measures providing partial compensation for temporary unemployment, such as
furlough schemes. In certain cases, for example in France, we retained job candidates on our payroll
but the government measures did not provide full compensation for such candidates; therefore, the
company responsible for the candidate still had to pay a portion of the compensation. In addition, in
certain cases we also retained job candidates on our payroll in order to accommodate our customers
more quickly when the isolation measures were over, without having to wait for additional hires. For
some companies that typically have higher bench time, we saw a reduction in their bench time as a
result of placing job candidates on government economic unemployment initiatives.

Due to the difference in Gross Margin between our various segments, our segment mix, and within each
segment, our industry, sector or candidate mix can affect our overall Gross Margin. For example, in
Accent, the construction end-market generates a higher Gross Margin than the hospitality end-market,
and student candidates generate a lower Gross Margin compared to the experienced candidates. Below

_Selling Expenses_

Selling expenses comprise the wages and salaries (including variable pay), social security charges and
other benefits (such as accommodation expenses) for in-house employees responsible for operational
activities at our branches, as well as advertising and marketing (including internal marketing),
amortization of customer relationships and brand names that were originally valued in the context of
various business combinations and other selling expenses. Selling expenses are primarily impacted by
the number of in-house employees we employ. As a result, selling expenses will increase when we grow
our operations and the number of in-house employees that we have who manage the recruiting lifecycle
and oversee the sourcing, selection and placement of our job candidates on assignment. In 2020, the
Covid-19 pandemic also resulted in an increase in such selling expenses. In particular, in Accent we
paid a one-time additional bonus to members of our commercial team during the second and third
quarters of 2020, in recognition of extraordinary continuing contributions during the Covid-19 period.
As the impact of Covid-19 lessened in 2021, selling expenses increased primarily in correspondence
with revenue.

_Other general and administrative expenses_

Other general and administrative expenses comprise personnel and accommodation expenses of head
offices, IT expenses, depreciation expenses largely relating to charges on capitalized buildings, cars and
software, and other general and administrative expenses at the headquarters level, as well as share-based
payments. During the period under review, our share-based payments consisted of several ratchet
schemes offered to key management at different acquired Powerhouses (Abylsen, Covebo, Continu
Professional, TIMEPARTNER and GRITT) (“ratchet schemes”) and our former long-term incentive
plan at the level of shareholders of House of HR (“long-term incentive plan”), which we settled in
connection with the Acquisition. In 2019, 2020 and 2021, we recognized €4.6 million, €3.9 million and
€1.5 million, respectively, in share-based payments connected to option grants made under our longterm incentive plan launched in 2018. In the nine months ended September 30, 2022, we recognized
€3.7 million in share-based payments connected to option grants made under the same long-term
incentive plan. See note 19 to each of our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and note 21 to
our Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial
Statements for additional information. On the Acquisition Closing Date, we established the structure
for a management equity participation program pursuant to which certain managers of the Group are
able to acquire, subscribe for or otherwise receive MIP Securities. See “Certain Relationships and
_Related Party Transactions—Management Incentive Plan.”_

**_Impact of Covid-19 and our Response_**

Concomitant with its global and market-wide impact, the Covid-19 pandemic negatively affected our
business, results of operations and financial condition in 2020. Our revenues for the year ended
December 31, 2020, decreased by 8.2%, from €1,738.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019
to €1,596.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily as a result of Covid-19.

In response to this unprecedented situation, we modified certain of our operational practices and
changed how we communicate both internally and with customers; we implemented additional
protective procedures; and we accessed temporary government measures that were advantageous to us.


-----

In respect of sales in our markets, our response included keeping branches open to the extent possible,
such that the large majority of our branch network continues to exist post-lockdowns, as management
sought to preserve stability in terms of access to customers. Temporary Unemployment measures were
utilized in order to retain experienced and trained staff members, while we undertook various initiatives
and loyalty programs for staff of platforms and operating companies, including motivational training.
We also awarded special bonuses in respect of extraordinary efforts with new customers, and for
boosting sales in the initial months after the first lock-down. In particular, in Accent, special regional
growth bonuses, which were structured to allow for increased collaboration on a region-wide basis, and
speed bonuses, for those offices that were the first to return to financial performance in line with 2019
figures, were awarded.

During the Covid-19 pandemic, we managed our costs of services, where possible, by placing
consultants or temporary workers on temporary unemployment or similar schemes (depending on
available government assistance in each of our markets) in order to keep our workforce intact to the
extent possible, so as to be able to place these candidates back on customer assignment once customers
resumed hiring. In Continu Professionals, consultants were also kept on the payroll, and were kept on
the bench so as to allow them to return to work after the virus’s first wave. This approach paid off during
the summer, when the large majority of people on the bench were back at work with a customer.

We also reduced expenses by placing internal staff on temporary unemployment where we deemed
appropriate, such as in branches that were inactive because the sector had closed (such as the retail nonfood and hotel, retail and café (“horeca”) segments). In Accent, we placed internal staff on temporary
unemployment on March 18, 2020, the first day this was allowed by the authorities. In Abylsen, internal
staff were not put on temporary unemployment, thereby permitting them to remain close to those
consultants that were still at the customer, allowing us to continue to detect further opportunities with
those customers that were still active during the first lock-down.

We reduced marketing expenses and other expenses to the minimum required in 2020, while retooling
in an effort to draw interest, such as webinars we organized for customers to explain the impact of
government measures. Management also reduced capital expenditures compared to recent prior years
in order to protect cash levels during the Covid-19 pandemic and as a precautionary measure also drew
on its Existing Revolving Credit Facility in March 2020, which was subsequently repaid in June 2020.

Our sales fully recovered during 2021, achieving above pre-Covid-19 pandemic levels, mostly due to
the economic recovery and the overall digitalization trends that are expected to continue going forward.
With global economy having been revived in 2021, there is a talent crunch as companies are looking to
fill positions that were cut in 2020 due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. Moreover, the Covid19 pandemic has led to many job candidates re-evaluating their careers, work conditions and long-term
professional goals, resulting in an increased rate of employees switching jobs and transitioning between
different job modes. This has led employers to focus more intensely than ever on employee retention
and job mobility, which has created substantial opportunities for us to offer our services.

In response to the evolving market trends, we are increasingly more focused on the bottleneck
professions and specialized jobs, and our M&A strategy is strengthening our capability to capitalize on
such trends. For example, our acquisitions of TMI and Cohedron helped us to expand and compete in
the healthcare and public sectors. Also, Accent partnered with a regional public employment service,
the VDAB (the Flemish Institution for Employment Mediation and Training), to participate in
CareerFlow, a government-initiated project in Belgium that facilitates job mobility between employers
and provides alternatives to employees. Through this project, employees can temporarily or
permanently work for different employers, which allows them to develop skill sets that would best
match their professional goals. This creates a benefit for both employers and job candidates, as
employers have a larger and more diverse talent pool to tap into for their various staffing needs, while
job candidates have a better chance to stay employed and more flexibility in shaping their careers.


-----

Although the spread of the new strain of Covid-19, Omicron, in the last weeks of 2021 and at the
beginning of 2022 did not visibly impact our recovery in terms of sales, increased sickness and isolation
measures did put pressure on our Gross Margin. Furthermore, we are navigating a new market landscape
as the expectations and preferences of employers and job candidates have changed drastically during
the Covid-19 pandemic. There is no clear indication whether there will be an ongoing resurgence in the
spread of Covid-19 in our primary markets in the future, and together with the war in Ukraine, we are
experiencing increased costs of labor, services and raw materials as a result of inflation and are facing
the prospect of another recession. We generally have the ability to, however, pass through wage
increases from inflation to customers in both our engineering and consulting segment and our
specialized talent solutions segment, which, coupled with our flexible cost structure, has resulted in
resilient Gross Margins. Our revenues typically correlate with nominal GDP rather than real GDP due
to our stable margins and ability to pass through wage increases in an inflationary environment.

**Staffing Solutions Industry Trends**

In addition to the key factors above, there are also certain trends that could play a significant role in our
results of operations in the future as these trends become more prevalent or as our operations in such
areas develop and grow. See also “Industry—Staffing Solutions Secular Industry Drivers.” These
include: aging population; technological changes; career mobility and the need to reskill; diversity,
inclusion and corporate social responsibility; increased premium on quality of life; and outsourcing and
offshoring.

**_Aging populations_**

As the population of our target markets ages and workers exit the labor pool, there has been an increase
in competition among employers to fill the gaps left behind. This has left an opening for staffing
intermediaries, especially those like us that have a proven track record of identifying and matching the
right candidates to the right jobs, to fill these vacant positions with qualified talent. Additionally, a
scarcity of talent for certain roles is driving wages up, which in turn can increase the pricing power of
staffing firms for the solutions and staffing we provide.

**_Technological changes_**

In recent years, candidates are increasingly turning to online job boards when seeking out a position,
particularly through traffic generated by mobile devices. At the same time, clients expect more efficient
services at a lower cost that can only be delivered through the use of digital tools. We have also seen
an increase in the number of passive job seekers who apply through targeted advertisements on social
media when they were not actively searching for a position at the time. The market has also experienced
the development of new platforms, such as Uber Works in the United States, which however announced
in May 2020 the closure of their operations in light of the Covid-19 pandemic, according to their official
press release. Such platforms may be considered competitors, since they sometimes are able to attract
people directly to be employed for them via freelance or independent status. Nevertheless, such
platforms lack a human touch in the services they provide, and authorities in different countries monitor
fair treatment of workers by these platforms and are looking to ensure that there is no unfair competition
with other forms of labor. Such monitoring is especially common in the EU, where regulation and labor
unions are stronger than in other countries.

**_Career mobility and the need to re-skill_**

Millennial workers, especially highly skilled ones, are increasingly mobile and seeking a varied career
path, driving the need for re-skilling. This re-skilling can be provided through both formal and on-thejob training that is typically provided as part of temporary work agreements.

**_Diversity, inclusion and corporate social responsibility_**


-----

As the diversity trend becomes mainstream across clients, service providers have an opportunity to
provide increasing value to their clients by tapping into broad, international pools of candidates.

**_Increased premium on quality of life_**

It is increasingly difficult to find qualified candidates to fill some roles that offer long hours and difficult
conditions, as younger generations of workers are placing a fairly large premium on happiness in their
personal and professional lives. This has contributed to a supply-and-demand gap in certain end-markets
and as a result, staffing solutions providers with the ability to source and place candidates successfully,
are in greater demand.

**_Outsourcing and offshoring_**

Financial pressures on companies, especially the SMEs, have incentivized them to outsource many of
their non-core functions. Further, due to accelerated business rhythms, companies are increasingly
looking to obtain immediately available resources. This has led to an increased need for temporary
staffing and outsourced support that can be provided rapidly on short notice.

**_Better economics_**

Especially for freelance workers, the prospect of better economics in spite of lower job security has
been a driver of demand in the recent years.

**Description of Certain Income Statement Line Items**

**_Revenue_**

Revenue consists of the fair value of the consideration received or receivable for the services rendered
during the year to third parties. We mainly derive revenue from the transfer of services over time and
at a point in time in our engineering and consulting and specialized talent solutions segments.

We mainly generate revenue from offering HR staffing solutions to our clients. The duration of these
HR staffing solutions may vary between a couple of hours up to a period of two years (without minimum
volumes attached to these contracts).

In a small number of cases, we also provide solutions to customers active in larger project-oriented
businesses (such as the telecommunications or the construction end-markets) where apart from staffing,
specific deliverables also have to be provided. Such engagements may take one week up to two to three
months. We do not have a single major customer from which we generate revenue. The size of this
business is also reduced following the divestment of GRITT Projects.

**_Cost of services_**

Cost of services comprises expenses directly attributable to revenue. These costs mainly include
expenses related to job candidates, such as wages, salaries, and social charges but also include costs
associated with freelancers and subcontractors, referred to as “insourced costs.” Cost of services also
includes the housing expenses for foreign and other job candidates referred to as “services costs.”

**_Selling expenses_**

Selling expenses comprise personnel and accommodation expenses in relation to operational activities
at the branches, advertising and marketing, and other selling expenses, as well as the amortization and
impairment of acquisition-related intangible assets and goodwill. Trademarks, licenses and customer
relationship contracts acquired in a business combination have a finite useful life. They are recognized
at fair value at the acquisition date and are subsequently carried at cost less accumulated amortization


-----

and impairment losses. The amortization of customer relationships is based on the projected useful life
of the client (between seven and 15 years).

**_Other general and administrative expenses_**

General and administrative expenses comprise personnel and accommodation expenses of head offices,
IT expenses, and other general and administrative expenses. The depreciation expenses component
under this line item largely relates to charges on capitalized buildings, cars and software, among others.

**_Finance income_**

Finance income includes interest income on short-term bank deposits, interest income on loans to
related parties, gains on derecognition of non-convertible bonds, cross-charges to related parties and
swaps.

**_Finance expenses_**

Finance expenses include the interest on borrowings from related parties, banks, bonds, as well as the
refinancing costs and bank fees related to costs associated with the refinancing of bank loans and other
recurring bank fees.

**_Share in profit/(loss) of equity accounted investments_**

Share in profit/(loss) of equity accounted investments is comprised of gains and losses from equity
accounted investments, such as joint ventures.

As of September 30, 2022, Accent held a 50% stake in Sixie BV and House of HR held a minority stake
in Ariad and a minority stake in Happy Recruiter. We do not consider these joint ventures and associates
to be individually material to us. During 2021, we had a loss from an equity accounted investment in
Happy Recruiter, as both the shares in and the loans towards Happy Recruiter were impaired to nil in
the third quarter of 2021, resulting in a loss of €1.5 million for us.

In May 2022, ETA, a subsidiary of the Abylsen group, established a joint venture with DFI, a
subcontractor that ETA works with on specific projects. ETA holds 50% of the shares of this joint
venture for an amount of €25,000. The purpose of this investment is to reduce the amount of insurance
expenses of the projects that ETA and DFI work on. No activity is planned for this joint venture until
2023. In June 2022, Abylsen acquired 35.1% additional shares in Greenworking for a consideration of
€9.8 million and we currently hold 95.1% of the shares in Greenworking.

**_Income tax expense_**

Income tax expense is comprised of current tax and deferred tax. Current and deferred tax is recognized
in profit or loss, except to the extent that it relates to items recognized in other comprehensive income
or directly in equity. The components of and the recognition policies for current tax and deferred tax
are set out below:

_Current tax_

Current tax is comprised of the current tax on profits for the year, as well as adjustments made in respect
of prior years. The current tax charge is calculated on the basis of the tax laws that are enacted or
substantially enacted at the reporting date in the countries where we operate and generate taxable
income. Management periodically evaluates positions taken in our tax returns with regard to situations
in which applicable tax regulations are subject to interpretation. It establishes provisions where
appropriate on the basis of amounts expected to be paid to the relevant tax authority.

_Deferred tax_


-----

Deferred tax is recognized in full, using the liability method, on temporary differences arising between
the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their carrying amounts in the Consolidated Financial
Statements. Deferred tax liabilities are, however, not recognized if they arise from the initial recognition
of goodwill. Deferred tax is also not accounted for if it arises from initial recognition of an asset or
liability in a transaction other than a business combination that at the time of the transaction affects
neither accounting nor taxable profit or loss. Deferred tax is determined using tax rates (and laws) that
have been enacted or substantially enacted by the end of the reporting period and are expected to apply
when the related deferred income tax asset is realized or the deferred tax liability is settled.

Deferred tax primarily arises from the valuation of customer relationships and brand names and the
allocation of amortization on them, as well as from fair value adjustments relating to the then existing
senior facilities.

**_Impairment of goodwill_**

Our impairment of goodwill increased to €13.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022,
from nil in the nine months ended September 30, 2021. This was due to an impairment test performed
during the second quarter of 2022 given the rising interest rate in the current market, which we consider
to be an impairment indicator. Pursuant to this impairment test, we identified a goodwill impairment in
relation to the GRITT Powerhouse of €13.3 million, as the recoverable amount was €40.9 million
compared to the carrying value of €54.2 million. We performed another impairment test during the third
quarter of 2022 due to further increases in interest rates, which identified no additional impairments.
We therefore recorded a goodwill impairment of €13.3 million for the nine months ending September
30, 2022, as we consider this change to have a long-term impact.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

**_Overview_**

Our principal cash requirements consist of investments in acquisitions, capital expenditures, servicing
financial indebtedness, payroll costs and paying taxes.

Our principal sources of liquidity are cash flows from operating activities and financing cash flows from
drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility, availability under the Delayed Draw Term Facility and
committed and uncommitted lines. The availability of the Revolving Credit Facility is subject to certain
conditions. See “Description of Other Indebtedness.”

Our ability to generate operating cash flows depends on operating performance, which in turn depends
to some extent on general economic, financial, industry, regulatory and other factors, many of which
are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in “Risk Factors.” We believe that, based on
our current level of operations as reflected in its results of operations for the nine months ended
September 30, 2022, cash flows from operating activities, cash on hand and the availability of
borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility and committed and uncommitted lines will be sufficient
to fund operations and capital expenditures and to debt service for at least the next twelve months. The
ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends and make other payments to us may be restricted by, among
other things, the amount of distributable reserves and legal prohibitions on such payments or otherwise
distributing funds to us, including for the purpose of servicing debt. Losses or other events could further
reduce the net equity and distributable reserves of our subsidiaries.

In 2020 and 2021, we undertook a number of measures to preserve our liquidity during the Covid-19
pandemic, including managing our costs of services, where possible, by placing consultants or
temporary workers on temporary unemployment or similar schemes (depending on available
government assistance in each of our markets) in order to keep our workforce intact to the extent
possible, so as to be able to place these candidates back on customer assignment once customers
resumed hiring. Expenses were reduced by placing internal staff on temporary unemployment where
revenue necessitated this, for example in branches that were inactive because the sector had closed (such
as the retail non-food and horeca segments). In Accent, this was done as of March 18, 2020, the first
day this was allowed by the authorities. In Abylsen, internal staff were not put on temporary
unemployment, thereby permitting them to remain close to those consultants that were still at the
customer, allowing us to continue to detect further opportunities with those customers that were still
active during the first lock-down. Further, marketing expenses and other expenses were reduced to the
minimum required in 2020, while also being retooled in an effort to draw interest, such as webinars we
organized for customers to explain the impact of government measures. Management also reduced
capital expenditures compared to recent prior years in order to protect cash levels during Covid-19 and


-----

as a precautionary measure also drew on its Existing Revolving Credit Facility in March 2020, which
was subsequently repaid in June 2020.

The proceeds from the Offering of the Notes will be used as set forth under “Use of Proceeds.”

**_Working Capital_**

Our resilience is further supported by the cash protective nature of our working capital dynamics. Our
working capital largely consists of receivables (client billings) and payables (job candidate wages,
social security, etc.) tied to individual job candidate placements. For each job candidate placement, the
receivable is higher than the payable with the difference roughly representing the bill-pay spread or
gross margin embedded in the client service agreement and job candidate agreements. This means that
(all else being equal) when we place fewer job candidates, our working capital declines, resulting in a
positive cash balance offsetting the loss of post-tax cash profit. Usually in the last quarter of the year,
our working capital shows a decrease, which is reflected as cash inflow in the cashflow statement. This
is because usually in the second and third quarters of the year working capital is at its highest due to
ramp-up of sales growth in receivables and high payables that tend to occur during this period, such as
holiday payments, accident insurance, and employers liability insurance. The working capital dynamics
and corresponding downside protection for our cash flows are also evident in our recent performance
during the Covid-19 pandemic. In 2020, we had a positive change in working capital, while in 2019 and
2021 we had a negative change in working capital. This demonstrates the counter cyclical nature of our
working capital profile which typically unwinds during periods of economic downturn, thereby
generating larger cash inflow. For the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021, our change in
working capital as a percentage of revenue was (1.1)%, 4.2% and (0.1)%, respectively.

Working capital changes amounted to negative €66.4 million for the nine months ended September 30,
2022, compared to negative €18.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, primarily
impacted by the timing of payments of wages and salaries and VAT.

compared to €67.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to the increased usage

_Invoicing_

In order to minimize our credit risk, we follow practices in relation to the issuance and timing of invoices
to customers.

In the specialized talent solutions segment, invoicing is typically done on a weekly basis to customers,
with payment terms ranging from zero up to 60 days, but with a majority on a 30 day payment term.
Customers with no credit history or very small customers receive a zero or seven day credit, allowing
us to closely monitor payment behavior, and to withhold rendering services (i.e., people at work) if a
payment is not made when due.

In the engineering & consulting segment, customers are on average typically somewhat larger SMEs or
are large companies such as financial, transportation or industrial firms. In this segment, invoicing
cycles are most often on a monthly basis, with payment terms between 30 to 60 days, or in France, up
to 90 days.

It should be noted that the company has a credit insurance policy in place covering all Group entities,
up to a limit of €250.0 million.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk**

Our activities expose us to a variety of financial risks: market risk (including limited foreign exchange
risk, cash flow and fair value interest rate risk), credit risk and liquidity risk.

Our overall risk management program focuses on the unpredictability of financial markets and seeks to
minimize potential adverse effects on our financial performance. Our objective is to identify, quantify,
manage and then monitor events or actions that could lead to financial losses. We use derivative
financial instruments to hedge certain interest risk exposures. In particular, we protect the variable
interest rate on loans via the use of caps that limit the exposure to fluctuations of EURIBOR.

Risk management is carried out by our treasury department. Group’s treasury identifies, evaluates and
hedges financial risks with approval from the Board of Directors.

See note 4.1 of the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements for further information.

**_Market Risk_**

_Foreign exchange risk_

Our exposure to foreign exchange risk is very limited as our operations are essentially denominated in
euro. Therefore, the impact of fluctuations of these currencies of +/-10% is considered as immaterial.


-----

_Interest rate risk_

Our interest rate risk arises from long-term borrowings. Borrowings issued at variable rates expose our
cash flow to an interest rate risk which is offset by the interest rate caps. On an as adjusted basis for the
Offering, most of our indebtedness will consists of the Notes and borrowings under the Facilities and
the Bridge Facility. The Notes will be issued at, and following the Conversion Date, the Bridge Facility
will bear, a fixed interest rate. The Facilities bear, and prior to the Conversion Date the Bridge Facility
bears, variable interest rates, which for loans denominated in euros is essentially fixed when the
reference interest rate is below zero, due to the interest rate floor.

Following the Acquisition Closing Date, we entered into hedging instruments covering approximately
50% of the Facilities at the level of the Issuer to hedge interest rate risk exposure under the Facilities,
and we plan to enter into additional hedging agreements to cover 75% to 100% of the Facilities to hedge
our interest rate risk exposure. The floating rate on the borrowings under the Facilities will be entirely
accounted for at amortized cost, and therefore the impact of changes in the market interest rate on the
fair value of these floating rate borrowings at the closing date will have no impact on the income
statement or on the equity. The Group does not apply hedge accounting.

EURIBOR floating rate borrowings which are not covered by the swaps are subject to interest rate risk.

**_Credit risk_**

Our credit risk mainly arises from credit exposures to customers, including outstanding receivables, as
well as from cash and cash equivalents, favorable derivative financial instruments, and deposits with
banks and financial institutions.

**_Risk management_**

We have no significant concentrations of credit risk other than that for ordinary debtors. We have
policies to ensure that the services are provided to customers with an appropriate credit history. Credit
risk is managed locally by each subgroup (brand) and certain companies have credit insurance in place.
Credit risk mainly arises as credit exposures to customers, including outstanding receivables.

The credit quality of customers, considering the financial position of customers, past experience and
other factors, is closely assessed by the credit department on a regular basis. During 2020, a credit
insurance program was set-up throughout the Group to enable us to have control over open receivables
during the challenging Covid-19 pandemic. Individual risk limits are set based on internal or external
ratings in accordance with limits set by the finance committee. The utilization of credit limits is
regularly monitored.

Management does not expect any losses from non-performance by our counterparties.

_Impairment of financial assets_

We have three types of financial assets that are subject to the expected credit loss model:

- trade receivables for sales of services;

- contract assets resulting from project services in progress; and

- debt investments carried at amortized cost.

While cash and cash equivalents are also subject to the impairment requirements of IFRS 9, there was
no identified impairment loss.

_Trade receivables_


-----

We apply the IFRS 9 simplified approach to measure expected credit losses which uses a lifetime
expected loss allowance for all trade receivables.

To measure the expected credit losses, trade receivables and contract assets have been grouped based
on shared credit risk characteristics and the days past due.

The expected loss rates are based on the payment profiles of sales over a period of 36 months before
each reporting year-end, and the corresponding historical credit losses experienced within this period.
The historical loss rates are adjusted to reflect current and forward-looking information on macroeconomic factors affecting the ability of the customers to settle the receivables.

Forward-looking information has been considered in assessing the Expected Credit Loss impairment
under IFRS 9, taken into consideration the possible downside resulting from the Covid-19 pandemic.
This did not result in a significant impact on the Expected Credit Loss model assumptions.

Trade receivables and project related receivables are written off when there is no reasonable expectation
of recovery. Indicators that there is no reasonable expectation of recovery include, among others, the
failure of a debtor to engage in a repayment plan with us, and a failure to make contractual payments
for a period of greater than 120 days past due. Several factors are considered in assessing the likelihood
of impairment which is assessed on a case-by-case basis.

Impairment losses on trade receivables and contract assets are presented as net impairment losses within
operating profit. Subsequent recoveries of amounts previously written off are credited against the same
line item.

We first apply the policy relating to impairment of the trade receivables under the incurred loss model,
and then, for the rest of receivables which are not provided for, we apply the expected credit loss model,
and recognize an additional provision. As of December 31, 2021, 78% of our trade receivables were
less than one month old, 13% were between one month and two months old and the remaining 8% were
between two months and one year or two or more years old. As of December 31, 2021, 97% of the trade
receivables were not impaired, while 3% were impaired.

**_Liquidity risk_**

Prudent liquidity risk management implies maintaining sufficient cash, the availability of funding
through an adequate amount of committed credit facilities and use of trade supplier credit terms.


-----

Cash flow forecasting is performed in our operating entities and aggregated by the Group treasury.
Group treasury monitors rolling forecasts of our liquidity requirements to ensure we have sufficient
cash to meet operational needs while maintaining sufficient headroom on our undrawn committed
borrowing facilities at all times so that we do not breach borrowing limits or covenants (where
applicable) on any of our borrowing facilities. Such forecasting takes into consideration our debt
financing plans, covenant compliance, compliance with internal balance sheet ratio targets and, if
applicable, external regulatory or legal requirements. We also use factoring agreements with certain
banks in order to obtain early access to cash flows. See also “—Liquidity and Capital Resources—
_Overview” above._

**_Capital risk management_**

Our objectives when managing capital are to safeguard our ability to continue as a going concern in
order to provide returns for shareholders and for other stakeholders and to maintain an optimal capital
structure to reduce the cost of capital.

**Overview of the Staffing Solutions Industry**

We are a diversified human resources solutions provider serving clients located primarily in Belgium,
France, Germany and the Netherlands through ten business units. We operate through two distinct
segments: engineering and consulting and specialized talent solutions. Our engineering and consulting
segment is focused on supplying clients with high-skilled white-collar consultants and mid to highskilled professionals to meet clients’ specialized needs in a variety of end-markets including financial,
industrial and construction end-markets. Through this segment, we also staff one to three-year
construction projects, mainly through secondment or time and materials contracts.

Our specialized talent solutions typically supplies a small number of high demand mid-and lower skilled
blue-collar and white-collar workers to clients for specialized positions on a temporary basis. We source
our candidates both from our primary markets and also increasingly from our international recruitment
network. Across both segments, in addition to the positive secular trends supporting the whole staffing
solutions industry, the diversity of our clients’ end-markets and geographic markets supports our
business resiliency and outlook.

Staffing solutions providers fall into one of three categories: mono-specialists, multi-specialists and
generalists. A specialty in this sense is a combination of at least two out of three types of expertise: (i)
functional expertise, or a focus on a specific skill level or specific job functions (such as lawyers,
engineers, low-skilled blue-collar workers); (ii) industrial expertise, a focus on a specific end-market
(such as food production or construction); and (iii) local expertise, a focus on a given region or city.
Mono- and multi-specialists (which only differ from each other based on the number of specialties they
serve) provide a focus on a given specialty with a dedicated sales force, specific processes and tailored
value proposition focused typically on smaller volumes per client and a possible focus on a specific
client size. Generalists, on the other hand serve a broad range of activities, clients, contract sizes and
contract types with generalist sales forces, similar processes and offer less tailored solutions to a wide
range of clients.

**Staffing Solutions Industry Size and Outlook**

The total market size for the staffing market in Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and France was
approximately €95 billion in revenue in 2019. After dropping to approximately €81 billion in 2020 due
to the pandemic, the market recovered in 2021, totaling approximately €94 billion (the “Total Market”).

These four key geographic markets are characterized by high average salaries, low unemployment and
a high demand for scarcity-driven profiles and are well developed and mature in the temporary staffing
and consulting fields. As a result of these trends, the number of temporary workers in these markets has
increased significantly over the last decade. Our Total Market reflects the type of staffing markets for
which we provide services in our primary geographies on a country basis, but it does not reflect the


-----

narrower type of job candidates that many of our business units recruit and supply to clients or the
specific end-market niches on which they concentrate.

As shown above, the staffing market in the countries in which we operate are expected to grow from

**Staffing Solutions Secular Industry Drivers**

Demand for the types of solutions we provide has increased and is expected to continue growing in the
future, once markets have recovered from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, due to a number of
positive secular trends:

_Aging populations. As the population of our target markets ages and workers exit the labor pool, there_
has been an increase in competition among employers to fill the gaps left behind. This has left an
opening for staffing intermediaries, especially those like our Group that have a proven track record of
identifying and matching the right candidates to the right jobs, to fill these vacant positions with
qualified talent. Additionally, a scarcity of talent for certain roles is driving wages up, which in turn can
increase the pricing power of staffing firms for the solutions and staffing we provide.

_Technological changes. In recent years, candidates are increasingly turning to online job boards when_
seeking out a position, particularly through traffic generated by mobile devices. At the same time,
clients expect more efficient services at a lower cost that can only be delivered through the use of digital
tools. We have also seen an increase in the number of passive job seekers who apply through targeted
advertisements on social media when they were not actively searching for a position at the time. The
market has also experienced the development of new platforms, such as Uber Works in the United
States, which, however, announced in May 2020 the closure of their operations in light of the Covid-19
pandemic, according to their official press release. Such platforms may be considered competitors, since


-----

they sometimes are able to attract people directly to be employed for them via freelance or independent
status. Nevertheless, such platforms lack a human touch in the services they provide, and authorities in
different countries monitor fair treatment of workers by these platforms and are looking to ensure that
there is no unfair competition with other forms of labor. Such monitoring is especially common in the
EU, where regulation and labor unions are stronger than in other countries.

_Career mobility and the need to re-skill._ Millennial workers, especially highly skilled ones, are
increasingly mobile and seeking a varied career path, driving the need for re-skilling. This re-skilling
can be provided through both formal and on-the-job training that is typically provided as part of
temporary work agreements.

_Diversity, inclusion and corporate social responsibility. As the diversity trend becomes mainstream_
across clients, service providers have an opportunity to provide increasing value to their clients by
tapping into broad, international pools of candidates.

_Increased premium on quality of life. It is increasingly difficult to find qualified candidates to fill some_
roles that offer long hours and difficult conditions, as younger generations of workers are placing a
fairly large premium on happiness in their personal and professional lives. This has contributed to a
supply and demand gap in certain end-markets and as a result, staffing solutions providers with a more
flexible and agile organization and the ability to source and place candidates successfully, are in greater
demand.

_Outsourcing and offshoring. Financial pressures on companies, especially the small- to medium-sized_
enterprises (“SMEs”), have incentivized them to outsource many of their non-core functions. Further,
due to accelerated business rhythms, companies are increasingly looking to obtain immediately
available resources. This has led to an increased need for temporary staffing and outsourced support
that can be provided rapidly on short notice.

_Better economics. Especially for freelance workers, the prospect of better economics in spite of lower_
job security has been a driver of demand in the recent years.

As a result of these secular trends, both employers and workers increasingly turn towards flexible
staffing models, driving demand for extended workforce solutions. According to an external consultant
analysis, in Belgium, Netherlands and France, the number of workers that are part of the extended
workforce (i.e., contractors and other freelancers) has grown from 2016 to 2021 at a CAGR of 3.9%,
2.5% and 4.4%, respectively. These growth rates are above those registered in the total working
population, which over the same period has grown at a CAGR of 1.0% in Belgium, 1.3% in the
Netherlands and 0.4% in France. This is also evidenced by the growth in penetration of the extended
workforce as part of the total workforce, with penetration rates in 2021 ranging from 7.2% in France to
10.2% in the Netherlands.

_Source: External consultant analysis. [1] % of total working population_

**Our Total Market**

We operate primarily in Belgium, France, Germany and the Netherlands in a variety of specialties with
a combined total market of approximately €94 billion in revenue as of 2021. We expect our Total
Market to grow at a rate of approximately 5% per annum in revenues to an estimated €107 billion by
2024, a growth rate above that of the broader staffing solutions industry, driven by a variety of favorable
end-market dynamics leading to increases in outsourcing and billing rates. We operate through ten
business units in two segments: engineering and consulting and specialized talent solutions. The
discussion below focuses on the key factors affecting each of our business units.

**Engineering and Consulting**

**_Abylsen_**

Abylsen is an engineering and consulting Powerhouse headquartered in France, with operations in
France, Belgium, Germany, Switzerland, Italy and Luxembourg. Abylsen operates in a competitive but
fragmented market, where it is a relatively small company which challenges primarily large global
consulting or mid-sized global companies or brands, as well as regional companies or brands.

_End-market overview and drivers_

Historically, growth in Abylsen’s Addressable Market has been driven by companies’ spending on
research and development. It is expected that, once markets have recovered from the Covid-19
pandemic, such spending will increase again going forwards and will be the key driver of growth in
Abylsen’s Addressable Market, as end-markets reliant on research and development (such as the
automotive, energy, pharmaceutical and aerospace industries) respond and adapt to changing
technologies for their sustained growth. Additional factors such as increased outsourcing penetration
(France is already one of the most mature countries for outsourcing of research and development) and
increasing billing rates (moderate due to pre-existing difficulties in sourcing engineers in France) are
likely to further drive market growth in the future.

According to external consultant analysis, Abylsen’s addressable market is expected to grow at low to
mid-single digit in the next five years.

_Competitive landscape_

According to external consultant analysis, competition in Abylsen’s Addressable Market includes a lot
of players but is highly fragmented, with the four largest players capturing less than 30% of the market
in 2021. According to external consultant analysis, the market is defined by three types of competitors:
(i) large global consulting firms (including Capgemini Engineering (formerly Altran), Alten, Akka and
Assystem), (ii) mid-size global/regional firms (such as Sii, MCA, agap2 and Davidson) and (iii) smaller
regional/local firms. Abylsen falls into the mid-size global/regional category, with a smaller market
share than the four large global consulting firms. Nevertheless, Abylsen has been growing faster and
achieved a higher EBITDA margin than its larger competitors, reaching 17.5% in 2021, compared to
competitors such as Alten, which had an EBITDA margin of 12.3%.

**_Redmore_**

Redmore is a provider of specialized secondment and consulting services in our engineering and

newly opened international branch in Spain (Triple A – Risk Finance) and Portugal (ITDS). We
typically provide consulting and secondment services to clients through job candidates with university
degrees or applied university degrees who are predominantly but not exclusively on indefinite term
contracts with us. Redmore and its boutiques operate primarily in the banking and insurance sectors,
but also in the public sector and work with companies seeking financial staffing in enterprise recourse


-----

planning (“ERP”) implementation, with competitors of a variety of sizes, including large global
companies and the “Big Four” accountancy firms.

_End-market overview and drivers_

Redmore’s Addressable Market consists mainly of three markets in the Netherlands: the market for

its business into other European countries such as Poland and Belgium (15% of 2021 _Pro Forma_
Management Adjusted Revenue per management estimates) and to a lesser extent Germany,
Luxembourg, Portugal and Spain (less than 3% of 2021 Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue
per management estimates).

Over the past 15 years an increase in secondment penetration in the market has been the main driver of
growth in the Netherlands. Post Covid-19 pandemic, growth in Redmore’s specific client end-markets
in the coming years is expected to be driven by an increasing need for specialist positions in the financial
sector as a result of changing regulations, compliance, digitization and consolidation.

According to external consultant analysis, Redmore’s addressable market is expected to grow at low to
mid-single digit in the next five years.

_Competitive landscape_

Redmore competes with various entities in the financial services end-market including the big four
accounting firms (namely, Deloitte, Ernst & Young, KPMG and PricewaterhouseCoopers), which
accounted for approximately 40-50% of the market in 2021, as well as other professional services and
consultancy firms. Although the competitive environment for each of Redmore’s niches is different,
strong consolidation of the market in recent years has resulted in significant growth for both Redmore
and its competitors. We believe that Redmore’s businesses are leaders in their respective Addressable
Markets in terms of revenue.

Redmore is built around five labels with each serving a specific niche:

- _Talent&Pro focuses on secondments in the banking, insurance, pensions and actuarial end-_
markets. Talent&Pro is a significant player in the financial secondment market in the
Netherlands, facing competition from a variety of other firms, including Brunel, which has a
broad focus across IT, finance, engineering and law, Welten, which is specialized in candidate
training with project based work, and Young Capital, which is a digital disruptor across the
finance, sales, IT and marketing end-markets.

- _Triple A_ focuses on financial consulting in actuarial and risk management, with actuarial
consultancy firms, including Willis Tower Watson, Mercer, and Milliman, and the big four

- _Profource_ focuses on finance staffing, ERP consulting and provides business process

- _ITDS_ provides specialist consulting for insurance companies, pension funds and banks,

driven by growing economies in both regions and end-markets in which House of HR’s Powerhouses

**_Accent_**

Covebo had an Addressable Market consisting of the staffing market in the Netherlands in the trade,

-----

Covebo competes with smaller, regional or local competitors and larger generalists. Regional peers
include: Otto Workforce, a direct competitor and that has a similar end-market focus and sourcing
strategy to Covebo, though it is smaller in geographical scope; and Olympia, which is a mid-sized firm,
larger than Covebo, serving most end-markets throughout the Netherlands. Smaller competitors, such
as VDB, Sherpa and McDOIT, typically compete on smaller assignments but find it difficult to match
Covebo on price as they provide candidates in lower volumes. The larger generalists, such as Randstad
and Adecco compete heavily in volume driven projects, yet find it difficult to serve the small-volume,
specialized niches where we excel and do not offer a full service package or training.

According to external consultant analysis, Covebo’s Addressable Market is expected to grow at low to
mid-single digit in the next five years.

**_TIMEPARTNER_**

TIMEPARTNER specializes in the staffing of high-demand blue-collar workers in Germany and offers
tailor-made and integrated flexible HR-solutions in the field of temporary staffing, personnel placement,
provision of temporary workers and on-site management. In June 2021, we acquired avanti, which
complements TIMEPARTNER’s service portfolio by adding a presence in the medical and healthcare
segment. In addition, Zaquensis, previously a Powerhouse in our legacy general staffing segment, is
now part of the TIMEPARTNER operation following the partial merger between TIMEPARTNER and
Zaquensis in the second quarter of 2021.

_German general staffing market drivers_

In the future, it is expected that growth in this market will be driven by an increase in the number of
hours worked and overall temporary staffing penetration as decreasing unemployment and a shortage
of low-skilled blue-collar workers will force companies to seek out alternatives to source qualified
candidates. Billing rates are also expected to increase driven by the increase in minimum wages for
temporary workers established as a result of regulatory reform.

According to external consultant analysis, TIMEPARTNER’s Addressable Market is expected to
remain flat in the next five years.

**_TMI_**

On March 3, 2022, we acquired TMI, our new Powerhouse in our specialized talent solutions segment.
TMI specializes in providing staffing service for the healthcare sector in the Netherlands, assisting with
the recruitment of candidates for healthcare providers such as hospitals, public care institutions,
ambulance staff and nursing homes. TMI also supplies temporary staff, intermediates for freelancers,
and offers flexible jobs. Their job candidates usually include doctors, nursing staff, psychologists, and
pharmacists.

_End-market overview and drivers_

TMI is active in the attractive and growing Dutch healthcare staffing market which benefits from longterm healthcare trends where demand for healthcare professionals is high and ever-increasing.
According to an external analysis, TMI’s focus markets are (size of total healthcare workforce being
approximately 1.4 million employees):

- nursing, care and home care (representing approximately 470,000 employees in 2020);

- hospitals and other expert care & university medical centers (representing approximately
300,000 employees in 2020);

- disabled care & youth care (representing approximately 200,000 employees in 2020); and


-----

- mental healthcare (representing approximately 100,000 employees in 2020).

Continued shortages of healthcare personnel are expected to last until 2030, driven by Netherland’s
aging population and aging healthcare workforce:

- Demand for healthcare and cure until 2030 is expected to increase due to the aging Dutch
population:

    - Older than 55: 37% of the Dutch population expected by 2030 (CAGR increase of 1.6%
(2016-30)).

    - Between 35 and 55: 24% of the Dutch population expected by 2030 (CAGR decrease of
0.7% (2016-30)).

    - Younger than 35: 40% of the Dutch population expected by 2030 (CAGR increase of
2016- 0.2% (2016-30)).

- The Dutch healthcare workforce is expected to grow older with a CAGR increase of 4% for
population above 55 (2010-30).

According to external consultant analysis, TMI’s Addressable Market is expected to grow at mid to
high single digit in the next five years.
