**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are a leading provider of HR solutions in key European staffing markets, offering end-to-end
temporary recruiting and outsourcing services. We supply specialized and niche staffing to primarily
small and medium-sized enterprise (“SME”) clients in a diversified range of end-markets. We offer and
tailor our services to the staffing needs of our clients through our engineering and consulting segment
and specialized talent solutions segment, which are comprised of a well-developed portfolio of ten
specialized business units, which we call Powerhouses, across various countries. We also offer digital
recruiting through our dedicated platforms, using our digital tools, including, NOWJOBS, SWOP and
Gighouse app, targeting low-skilled, high-volume markets with significant roll-out potential.

Since our founding, we have expanded from a presence in only Belgium to more than 10 countries in
Europe. Corresponding to our geographic expansion, we have also become more diversified in the endmarkets we serve, primarily through our acquisitions in recent years, which provide us with staffing
capabilities in additional areas such as pharmaceutical, healthcare, life sciences, government and public
administration and technology. As of September 30, 2022, we had 72,296 job candidates at work and
approximately 40,858 productive people at work (meaning the number of our job candidates adjusted
to reflect a 38 hour per week workweek) and 4,734 in-house full-time equivalent employees. For the
twelve months ended September 30, 2022, we had 31,456 unique clients, our Pro Forma Management
Adjusted Revenue was €2,770.0 million and our _Pro Forma Management Adjusted EBITDA was_
€330.5 million.

Our engineering and consulting segment represents 53.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted
EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended
September 30, 2022. This segment supplies staffing of highly-skilled professionals, such as engineering
consultants and financial and insurance specialists, to fill specialized roles in a variety of end-markets,
such as financial, industrial, logistics, infrastructure, public administration and construction, and, more
recently, fast-evolving and highly resilient sectors such as energy, telecommunications,
pharmaceuticals and technology. This segment is comprised of our Abylsen, Continu Professionals,
Redmore, GRITT, Cohedron and SOLCOM Powerhouses and has the broadest geographic footprint,
with its primary operations in France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany. The engineering and
consulting segment assists clients in the search and selection of the right candidate, including for interim
management and secondments, and such temporary client assignments generally last for months. The
below chart illustrates in blue the type of client needs, worker qualifications and placement duration for
our engineering and consulting segment.

Our specialized talent solutions segment represents 46.5% of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted
EBITDA (excluding corporate costs and intragroup eliminations) for the twelve months ended
September 30, 2022. This segment supplies specialized staffing of high-demand mid-skilled workers
for specialized positions, such as clerical positions, carpenters, nurses and machine engineers, as well
as blue-collar workers to companies in certain sectors, including construction, retail, finance, food,
healthcare and construction. This segment is comprised of our Accent, Covebo, TIMEPARTNER and
TMI Powerhouses, with their primary operations in Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany, as well as
branches in countries that form part of their international recruiting networks, which currently operate
principally for this segment though we are planning to expand them for our engineering and consulting
segment. These international branches provide us with the capability to source foreign candidates to
bridge the large gap between the demand for qualified job candidates and the supply of such candidates,


-----

especially as the labor market in our Addressable Markets has tightened over the past few years. The
Specialized Talent Solution segment generally delivers job candidates through temporary agencies to
clients in a fast and flexible way when they are shorthanded, with duration of job placements typically
lasting for weeks, but they could also last hours or months depending on the needs of our clients. The
below chart illustrates in pink the type of client needs, worker qualifications and placement duration for
our Specialized Talent Solution segment.

We serve as an intermediary between job candidates and their ultimate employer by matching up
candidates that are looking to find a job, gain experience or find variety or flexibility with our clients
that are looking for specialist skills, flexible employee arrangements, time and cost efficiencies or to
cover peaks or sourcing for particular projects. We source and screen candidates, provide candidate
matching services and present candidates to the client. We also assist with the hiring of the candidates
by customers, client and candidate retention, provide timesheet, invoicing and payroll services, and
regularly follow up with clients. We aim to help our clients at all stages of the recruiting process to
relieve their management from the burden of having to seek appropriate job candidates for available
positions. To ensure that we are able to tap into skilled workforces, we offer career coaching to job
candidates in order to help them find career paths that align with their professional goals, and we provide
in-house training to equip them to match the job profiles in which they are interested or that are scarce
in the market to increase job candidates’ employability. We also offer support to foreign job candidates,
including housing, transport options, opening a bank account and other integration assistance.

We enter into employment contracts with the candidates and pay their salaries. We enter into placement
contracts with our clients and bill our clients for our services. Our bill-pay spread is a key driver of our
profitability and supports our industry-leading gross margins. We maximize bill-pay spread as a result
of candidate scarcity, our niche focus, our SME and local customer focus, our premium service offering,
our excellence in marketing candidates to jobs and non-solicitation or minimum fee/period protection
for candidates in respect of clients. We have strong pricing power driven by contractual dynamics that
ensure pass-through of salary increases. Our specialized talent solutions segment benefits from
contractual dynamics which allow for an automatic pass-through to clients of price increases, and our
business model also allows for limited bench risk because staffing contracts are back-to-back. In our
engineering and consulting segment, price increases are typically passed through via negotiations with
our clients, and we effectively manage to keep our bench time low by matching confirmed upcoming
client assignments to candidates. The business model of these two segments has enabled us to establish
a track record of margin stability even during challenging economic conditions such as the Covid-19
pandemic and in the inflationary environment in 2022.

For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, we generated 27.6%, 39.8%, 26.0% and 5.5% of our
_Pro Forma_ Management Adjusted Revenue in Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and France,
respectively. We have branches in the countries where we source job candidates, including Poland,
Romania, Spain, Czech Republic, Moldova and Portugal. As of September 30, 2022, we had a network
of 742 branches and 18 recruitment offices. To complement our physical network of branches and reach
new markets, we have pioneered several successful disruptor technologies, including our SWOP
application, our SWOP Recruiter application and our NOWJOBS platform. We have increased our
focus on developing digital support growth initiatives for our primary operations to enable us to reach
additional job candidates or serve new end-markets in a fully digital manner.


-----

We support businesses by providing flexible staffing solutions that are used throughout all stages of the
economic cycle, resulting in our resilience during economic downturns. While the economy is strong,
the job market tightens meaning that our clients need help sourcing candidates. As markets soften,
companies typically shift to a more temporary workforce and need staffing solutions and flexibility.
When markets reach the bottom of the cycle, temporary staffing suffers but then is characterized by a
quick recovery as temporary employment tends to recover faster than permanent employment. For
example, during the outset of the Covid-19 pandemic, our business recovered from the early losses in
approximately three to six weeks. We also have a highly variable cost base and the ability to pass on
wage inflation, which supports the stability of our gross margins. For example, our Like-for-Like
Revenue growth (based on the December 31, 2021 perimeter) for 2019, 2020 and 2021 fluctuated
significantly due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and were 2%, (9)% and 19%, respectively,
but we were able to maintain a gross margin of approximately 28% throughout this period. Flexible
staffing solutions proved instrumental in the global economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic,
resulting in a full recovery of our sales during the year ended December 31, 2021. During the Covid-19
pandemic, the retail, food retail and hospitality sectors were severely impacted across all our key
markets due to lockdowns and other restrictive measures, which led to a significant reduction in our
staffing activities in these sectors. Certain sectors, such as logistics and education, however, proved to
be less sensitive to the impacts of the Covid-19 pandemic, and clients in these sectors continued to seek
our services, particularly for high-skilled, specialized roles. In addition, demand for staffing services
from municipalities and government agencies during the Covid-19 pandemic increased due to, among
other developments, work related to the administration of government support measures, which we were
able to capitalize on given our specialization in this end-market provided by the Cohedron Powerhouse
in our engineering and consulting segment.

We were founded in 1995 by Philip Cracco and Conny Vandendriessche along with a financial sponsor
as a Belgium-based recruiting firm. Originally called Accent, we changed our name to House of HR in
2012. Over the course of 2012 to 2014, Naxicap, a French private equity firm, acquired a majority stake
in our business, and we have expanded significantly to become a leading provider of specialized HR
solutions in multiple European markets. On November 3, 2022, Bain Capital acquired a majority stake
in the Group, with Naxicap, Conny Vandendriessche and management maintaining stakes. See “The
_Transactions.”_

**Our Strengths**

We believe we benefit from the following key strengths:

**_Operating in highly resilient markets with favorable tailwinds and structural demand dynamics_**

The HR solutions market has historically shown quick recovery in demand following periods of
economic downturns. The general temporary staffing market, as a whole, has a long-term positive GDP
growth trajectory and tends to recover quickly after an economic downturn. Within this market,
specialized staffing companies, like us, also benefit from higher resiliency than generalist staffing
companies that rely on the low value-add mass labor market. Specialized staffing companies benefit
from lower cyclicality compared to generalist staffing companies due to specialty profiles. Specialized
staffing companies also benefit from increased penetration with clients compared to generalist staffing
companies due to more clients in these specialized sectors turning to staffing solutions providers like
us to assist them with candidate searches and provide them with higher value-add solutions. The below
graph demonstrates the relative resilience of the specialist temporary staffing companies:


-----

____________________________
Note: Specialists include Alten, Amadeus, Assystem, Page and Robert Half, and Generalists include Adecco, Manpower, Randstad.

European Union and national regulations applicable in the key countries in which we operate tend to
reinforce protection of permanent workers, which can lead companies to favor temporary work and
outsourcing solutions as employers often prefer to hire on a more temporary basis before offering an
employee a permanent contract. This trend is especially evident in recovery periods after a trough in
the economic cycle as companies seek to scale up their workforce. For example, we were able to quickly
recover from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, with our sales fully recovering to pre-Covid 19
levels during 2021. At the same time, legislation in the countries in which we principally operate allows
for multiple temporary staffing solutions, further supporting our business model.

We believe that high job vacancy rates offer us strong protection from a potential downturn in the nearterm as there would still be significant numbers of unfilled positions even with a reduction in vacancies,
which is similar to reductions that occurred during recent downturns. We offer our clients the ability to
recruit job candidates with specific profiles for jobs that are particularly difficult to fill, including from
abroad where needed, as we draw upon an international talent pool and provide required training. We
operate in markets where fundamentals for businesses such as ours are improving over time, supported
both by macroeconomic factors and positive structural demographic dynamics. Western Europe
generally is experiencing a large, chronic and growing supply and demand gap for skilled employees,
particularly related to technical engineering, specialized consulting and specialized blue-collar labor,
obliging companies to look beyond traditional job candidate sourcing and seek the help of specialized
staffing solutions providers like us. For example, unemployment rates in Germany were at 3.5% in
2021, as compared to 8.7% in 2007. In the Netherlands and Belgium, they were at 4.0% and 6.4%,
respectively, in 2021 as compared to a recent peak of 7.4% and 8.5%, respectively, in 2014. Job
vacancies in Belgium were at their highest in the second quarter of 2022 since 2012, and in Germany
and the Netherlands were at their highest in the second and third quarters of 2022, respectively, since
2007.

The staffing industry also benefits from a number of long-term underlying trends that have supported
our industry’s historical and projected medium- to long-term growth. Demand for the types of solutions
we provide is expected to continue growing in the future due to a number of positive secular trends,
including:

- Aging populations in our target markets and increasing competition for talent;

- Technological changes to job candidates’ search for employment opportunities, including the
switch to mobile technology, that are more challenging for employers to handle in-house;

- Workers increasingly prioritizing career mobility and focusing on smaller, entrepreneurial
opportunities;

- The need for workers to train or re-skill to adapt to changing work opportunities;


-----

- The desire of companies to address issues relating to diversity, inclusion and corporate social
responsibility;

- Workers placing an increased premium on quality of life and happiness at both a personal and
professional level, and an increased preference for job flexibility, especially since the Covid19 pandemic, leading to increased job rotation;

- Financial pressures resulting in increased outsourcing and offshoring; and

- Increasing use of artificial intelligence, data mining and robotization, as well as technological
change, all of which contribute to the skill supply-demand gap in labor markets.

- Especially for freelance workers, the prospect of better economics in spite of lower job security.

As a result of these secular trends, both employers and workers increasingly turn towards flexible
staffing models, driving demand for extended workforce solutions. According to an external consultant
analysis, in Belgium, Netherlands and France, the number of workers that are part of the extended
workforce (i.e., contractors and other freelancers) has grown from 2016 to 2021 at a CAGR of 3.9%,
2.5% and 4.4%, respectively. These growth rates are above those registered in the total working
population, which over the same period has grown at a CAGR of 1.0% in Belgium, 1.3% in the
Netherlands and 0.4% in France. This is also evidenced by the growth in penetration of the extended
workforce as part of the total workforce, with penetration rates in 2021 ranging from 7.2% in France to
10.2% in the Netherlands. We believe we are well positioned to capture penetration in specialized
extended labor.

These underlying trends contribute to the complexity of job searches and encourage companies to turn
to staffing solutions providers like us to help them fulfill their staffing needs. In addition, they make it
more challenging for new market entrants to effectively compete with established providers like us. We
have strategically positioned ourselves in geographic markets that are supported by macroeconomic
factors and positive demand dynamics in order to take full advantage of favorable trends. We believe
that the fundamentals of our Addressable Market remain strong in the medium-term and we believe that
we are poised to continue growing at or above the industry average growth rate in the future due to our
business model.

**_Increasingly diversified exposure to resilient and profitable end-markets targeting highly loyal and_**
**_less price-sensitive SME clients, with a focus on scarcity-driven specialist candidates_**

Our client focus is centered on SMEs and intermediate-sized enterprises that require high-touch local
service and operate in specialty niches that are in high demand. This focus supports our above market
growth and margins and provides us resilience as a result of the critical nature of the positions sought
by our clients. We believe that SMEs represent a particularly attractive client base as they are generally
more loyal customers and are less price sensitive. SMEs tend to be more reliant on each employee and
have lower workforce anticipation capabilities than large corporates, so the absence of a single worker
can be critical. As a result, when they need to hire someone, they need someone fairly quickly and place
a premium on the ability to source job candidates within their time constraints. As SMEs may have
more limited or no in-house recruiting capabilities, they are more willing to outsource many of their
staffing-related needs to providers like us who can provide a full service offering at all stages of the
recruitment lifecycle. SMEs often have limited employer branding and therefore may experience
difficulty in reaching the best job candidates without access to the talent pool of a staffing solutions
provider. SMEs also often have a faster decision-making process compared to large corporates and lack
purchasing departments, so we may face less pricing pressure from such companies. In addition, SMEs,
due to the smaller size of their employee pools, are less likely to lay off workers in a downturn and
typically maintain a more consistent level of employment than larger companies during a downturn.
The stability of employee levels at SMEs was evident during the global financial crisis as, based on
information from Accent, employment volumes were resilient at small companies and demonstrated
growth from 2008 to 2016.


-----

We have a track record of serving the attractive SME segment, with a focus on scarcity-driven specialist
candidates. We believe that the ability to find a specific candidate with the right cultural fit is important
for SMEs, since they typically have small teams and often seek a particular candidate who is not only
qualified for the job, but also matches the client’s corporate culture. Our ability to match such job
candidates results from our blend of human and digital touchpoints, with regular interaction with clients
and job candidates throughout the recruitment lifecycle (including our international recruiting
capabilities). HR staffing solutions also operate in a complex regulatory environment, and we provide
our clients with the required specific knowledge by sector, geography and even region. We believe the
ability to manage this complexity on a large scale increases the barriers to entry for the sector and
diminishes the risk for digital disruption or disintermediation.

In addition to our focus on SMEs, we focus on specialist candidates, which provides further resilience
to our business as skilled jobs are less cyclical. For example, in France, the unemployment rate for
unskilled jobs has had an approximately 8% variation between 2000 and 2020 as compared to a rate of
approximately 2% for skilled workers as demonstrated by the chart below.

We also have a strong track record of external growth through highly accretive acquisitions in a
fragmented market. We approach our growth through acquisitions with rigorous discipline. We focus
on acquiring successful, profitable companies rather than turn-around acquisitions. Our evaluation of a
potential acquisition target includes reviewing the opportunity through the rubric of a number of
stringent requirements designed to ensure fit with our overall strategy and culture. The target must fit
an identified strategic need to expand our geographic coverage, complement a specific specialty or fill
a niche skill gap. We also seek out targets with like-minded management teams with an entrepreneurial
spirit and long-term commitment in order to ensure a strong overall cultural fit. We also evaluate the
target’s profitability, historic growth and other performance metrics, and assess whether it is a leader in
its addressable markets. Once we have identified and then acquired a target, we have a well-defined and
proven integration process that involves consolidating the target into our Group reporting system and
sharing best practices. Local management teams are given the opportunity to invest at group level or to
continue to invest at the local level. We have completed 42 transactions since 2018, comprised of bolton acquisitions with lower multiples that enable growth at the local level, as well as platform
acquisitions through which we expand our solutions and enter new specialties or markets. We have an
excellent integration track record with our targets’ EBITDA and revenue growing by approximately 8%
per annum and 10% on average after we integrated them, as demonstrated by our acquisitions of
Abylsen, Covebo, Continu, TIMEPARTNER and Redmore. See “—Engineering and Consulting” and
“—Specialized Talent Solutions.”

**_Ability to pass through wage increases to customers, including through automatic contractual_**
**_mechanisms, and stable margins_**

We have the ability to pass through wage increases from inflation to customers in both our engineering
and consulting segment and our specialized talent solutions segment, which, coupled with our flexible
cost structure, has resulted in resilient gross margins. While our gross margins in both of our segments
fluctuate somewhat as a result of seasonality around holiday periods, they have remained largely stable
since January 2019 at approximately 22% to 28% (depending on Powerhouses and specialties) for our
specialized talent solutions segment and approximately 30% to 37% for our engineering and consulting
segment. Our revenues typically correlate with nominal GDP rather than real GDP due to our ability to
pass through wage increases in an inflationary environment and stable margins.

In our specialized talent solutions segment, price increases are automatically passed through to our
clients. For this segment, our contract model is centered on matching the length of our candidate’s
employment contract with us to the length of our placement contract with our client, the ultimate
employer, in order to prevent lag time between inflation of gross salary paid to the candidate and the
cost we charge to our clients, which results in an automatic pass-through of any salary increases. As
contracts expire, we renegotiate them, which has historically resulted in an ability to increase our prices
in line with wage inflation. We base our contract pricing on a candidate’s gross salary multiplied by a
coefficient factor, with the split typically being transparent to the client. Our coefficient factors tend to
remain relatively stable with slight fluctuations as a result of seasonality around holiday periods. For
example, Accent’s coefficient factor has remained relatively stable since 2020 at an average of 2.2.

The key pricing drivers for the coefficient factor are the scarcity of candidates and the value of any
additional services we offer. Key costs for us include salaries and work accident insurance. At the end
of the contract period, typically one week or one month in length, if salary increases, then we charge
the cost of the higher salary to the client. During the first half of 2022, we achieved average price
increases of approximately 5.0% (calculated as the numerical mean of the average price increases across
certain Powerhouses, weighted equally). Growth in euro-per-hour billed in our specialized talent
solutions segment is driven by increasing cost per hour paid and billed, as well as through increasing
bench costs. Our gross margin per hour billed remained highly stable at approximately 23% to 25%
(including bench costs) and approximately 29% to 30% (excluding bench costs) for each of the nine
months ended September 30, 2019, 2020, 2021 and 2022 as shown in the below chart.

In our engineering and consulting segment, price increases are typically passed through via negotiations
with clients. The contracts are typically time and material contracts with no obligations for any specific
result. Most of our candidates in our engineering and consulting segment are permanently hired by us
using employment contracts that typically have three- to six-week notice periods. We have placement
contracts with our clients that typically last nine to twelve months, which allows us to effectively
manage bench time and match our candidates with the upcoming mandates from clients. In most cases,
we plan for salary increases in advance and negotiate rate increases with our clients accordingly. Our
pricing model in our engineering and consulting segment centers on charging the client an hourly or
daily rate. Our billing rate is typically based on an hourly wage and a mark-up where the split is usually
not transparent to clients. Since 2021, we have been able to consistently increase our hourly rate in this
segment. For example, at Talent&Pro, one of our Redmore Boutiques that focuses on the finance
industry staffing, although our hourly rate fluctuated between €46.8 and €48.1 per hour during the
course of 2020, by the end of December 2021 we were able to increase it to approximately €49.6, and
have continued to increase it during the course of 2022, with an hourly rate of €53.5 as of September
2022.

Key drivers of the hourly or daily rates are skills, seniority and scarcity of candidates. Our key costs
include salary, potentially including a company car. At the end of a placement contract, renewal either
entails replacing the candidate with a new or more junior person at a new price or placing the same
candidate, who is now more senior, at a higher price. During the first half of 2022, we achieved average
price increases of approximately 6.6% (calculated as the numerical mean of the average price increases
across certain Powerhouses, weighted equally). Margin growth in our engineering and consulting
segment is driven by increasing the cost per hour paid and billed. Bench-time risk is effectively managed
by matching confirmed upcoming client assignments to candidates. Our gross margin per hour billed in
this segment also remained stable at approximately 32% to 34% (including bench costs) and
approximately 45% to 47% (excluding bench costs) for each of the nine months ended September 30,
2019, 2020, 2021 and 2022.

**_Robust financial profile supports cash generation with a highly variable cost base and proven ability_**
**_to deleverage_**

Our business model has supported strong EBITDA growth and profitability. We demonstrated our
financial resilience during the Covid-19 pandemic with strong EBITDA margins of 11%, 10% and 12%
for the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021, and 11% for the twelve months ended
September 30, 2022, respectively. We have limited capital expenditure requirements (primarily related


-----

to IT investments and expenditures for the purchase of property, plant and equipment and intangibles,
primarily related to our headquarters, furniture and infrastructure for our branch network,
accommodation for foreign job candidates, company cars) of approximately 1% of revenue in each of
2019, 2020 and 2021. As our key assets are the talent we provide to meet the temporary staffing needs
of our clients, we have limited fixed assets or cash tied up in inventory. Working capital largely consists
of receivables (client billings) and payables (job candidate wages, social security, etc.) tied to individual
job candidate placements. The receivable for each job candidate placement is typically higher than the
payable with the difference roughly representing the bill-pay spread or gross margin embedded in the
client service agreement and job candidate agreement. Working capital as a percentage of sales for the
twelve months ended September 30, 2022, was 4.9% of sales, compared to 2.1% for the year ended
December 31, 2021. The working capital dynamics and corresponding downside protection for our cash
flows are also evident in our recent performance. As volumes of job candidates reduce, for instance,
during period of economic downturns, we benefit from significant working capital inflows, which gives
us strong cash resiliency. In 2020, we experienced a positive change in working capital demonstrating
the counter-cyclical nature of our working capital profile. As a result, we experience high cash
conversion and cash flow growth, which has, in turn, supported our business growth, and has in the
past, allowed us to deleverage on a net debt basis following each of our refinancings. The following
chart shows our Pre-Tax Free Cash Flow and our Pre-Tax Free Cash Flow as a percentage of EBITDA
cash for the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021.

We also benefit from a flexible cost structure, with approximately 95% of our costs being variable or
semi-variable allowing for highly stable gross margins through the cycle. For 2021, approximately
65.1% of our total operating expenses were variable, 31.7% were semi-variable and 3.2% were fixed
costs. Our cost of services, which represented 79.1% of our total operational expenses (cost of services
and operating expenses together) for the year ended December 31, 2021, is comprised of mostly variable
costs related to our people at work (mainly payroll, social security contributions, housing, car fleet and
subcontracting costs). Our direct costs linked to our branches are primarily semi-variable and include
staff costs, including costs of managers and recruiters, and branch expenses, such as rents, car leases
and training, marketing and communication costs. Our overheads related to corporate functions at both
an operating company and Group-level, which represented less than 5% of our total operating expenses,
consists primarily of fixed costs. Further, due to our back-to-back contract model, we experience limited
bench risk in respect of people at work. In many of our jurisdictions, we are able to match the duration
of the employment of our job candidates and their placement, allowing us to be flexible in the
deployment of our job candidate resources. As costs generally track revenue, costs of service as a
percentage of revenue, and as a result, our margins, generally remain stable during downturns, as
demonstrated during the Covid-19 pandemic.

**_We are well-protected from disruption by other digital players and have developed an emerging_**
**_platform for excellent proprietary digital offering_**

We have an excellent proprietary digital offering and based on interviews with market participants we
believe we are well-protected from disruption from typical digital players that focus on a low-skilled,
higher volume business. We believe we are differentiated from such market participants because our
core offering is focused on specialty staffing and focused on SMEs that require customized services,
which are much more difficult to standardize or automate.

We believe that we are a thought leader and ahead of our larger peers in many respects as a result of
our development of digital initiatives in order to both address new markets with innovative business
models and improve our own and existing operations. To complement our physical network of branches
and reach new markets, we have pioneered several successful disruptor technologies that are revenuegenerating. Our NOWJOBS platform, which successfully competes in the low-skill, higher volume
segment, is primarily geared to students and other seekers of one-off temporary jobs, and is to date our
most successful digital initiative. Originally just available in Belgium where it launched in 2017, we
launched NOWJOBS in the Netherlands in 2019, in France in 2021 and in Germany in June 2022,
bringing on board big customers such as retail brands H&M and Picnic. For the year ended December
31, 2021, NOWJOBS handled approximately 1.1 billion requests and generated €54.1 million, €1.9
million and €0.2 million in revenues in Belgium, the Netherlands, and France, respectively. Following
our acquisition of StaffMe in July 2022, NOWJOBS will operate under the StaffMe brand in France
given the high level of StaffMe’s brand awareness in that country. In addition, we launched our SWOP
Recruiter application in May 2021, which is a free digital platform that helps Belgian SMEs with the
day-to-day management of their vacancies. The application is linked to our SWOP application, which
we launched in 2016 and further upgraded in 2020, and is now one of the largest Belgian apps to help
job seekers find a new permanent job. We launched SWOP in the Netherlands in October 2022 and plan
to launch SWOP in Germany in the near future. Our Gighouse app is a digital platform that matches
freelancers and independent job candidates with available projects at our customers. We aim to leverage
our experience as a disruptor in the market to expand successful initiatives to our broader Group.

In addition, we have also developed a number of complementary digital offerings that supplement our
core services. For example, in June 2019, we launched our MyAccent app, which allows potential job
candidates to interact via the Google Home assistant with Accent’s list of open positions. Book’u is our
planning tool, allowing customers to plan both their permanent and temporary workforce in one
solution, being in touch with this workforce to communicate when they should be available and
allowing to spot potential staffing shortages, immediately posting these shortages at their staffing
companies of choice. My Talents (Softskillz) testing has been developed together with the University
of Ghent, to test ‘who you are’ as a person and to test ‘what type of company do I want to work for.’
These tests will allow for better AI matching of jobs with candidates. Continu-Connect, which launched
in 2021 and had 756 registered contacts as of December 31, 2021, shows all available candidates in a
region for our customers. Our FYGI app brings together freelance HR recruiters with companies that
have a recruitment request. We have also other apps and platforms that assist with the recruitment and
other staffing processes, such as Dora, Ariad and CV Creator. All apps are developed taking into
account reusability across all House of HR operating companies, benefitting therefore from the
economies of scale House of HR has versus local competitors and increasing the barriers to entry for
our industry.

During 2021, we centralized all our digital assets in House of Invest, creating one platform to meet
current needs and invest in new needs as they arise. This enabled us to further invest in our digital
roadmap and internationalize our digital initiatives, bringing our digital and IT talents together to work
on multiple digital solutions. The main purpose of House of Invest is to roll out the digital initiatives
across all House of HR Powerhouses and Boutiques and to capitalize on a centralized knowledge base.
House of Invest now owns NOWJOBS, Gighouse, SWOP and SWOP Recruiter, Continu-Connect, CV
creator and My Talents (Softskillz), and holds minority ownerships in Dora and Ariad (a traditional
digital marketing staffing company) and a majority ownership in Book’u.


-----

For the year ended December 31, 2021, revenue from digital solutions amounted to 2.6% of total
revenue, compared to 1.6% for the year ended December 31, 2020. We have continued investing in IT
in 2022 and expect to continue prioritizing the digital venue going forward. We believe our digital
offering protects us from disruptions from digital players who focus on low-skilled, high volume
business, while our platforms continue to focus on high-skilled job candidates with a focus on SMEs.

We are also continuing to innovate our existing processes by identifying areas within our business that
could benefit from increased automation and zero-paper processes, including both job candidate- and
client-facing and internal processes, such as finance, procurement and marketing and communications.
Further, we continue to digitalize our processes and create a centralized repository designed to store,
process and secure large amounts of data across our different applications, which will enhance our
access to job candidates and improve our matching capabilities. We believe the efficiencies we can
realize through this digitalization will produce cost savings while allowing us to meet the everincreasing demands of clients and job candidates.

**_Entrepreneurial and invested management team with long-term incentive culture backed by a new,_**
**_highly supportive shareholder with deep industry knowledge_**

We benefit from a strong and committed management team that is highly motivated to deliver strong
performance over the long term. We believe our successful organic and external growth has been due
in part to the way in which we have been able to incentivize our managers. For example, our organic
“cell division” expansion strategy rewards our local managers with the opportunity to create and run
individual branches, fostering loyalty and encouraging the entrepreneurial spirit that has delivered our
success to date. For our engineering and consulting branches, our variable pay structure rewards
management down to the sales and recruitment consultants with variable pay linked to key performance
indicators such as attracting, matching and retaining job candidates and clients. While keeping a highly
entrepreneurial culture at the Powerhouse and Boutique levels, all strategic decisions with a significant
impact are made at House of HR level, and our local business units share in the centralized corporate
support and institutional knowledge.

We now also benefit from the market expertise, business relationships, knowledge and experience of
our new shareholder, Bain Capital. Bain Capital has a strong track record of investing in the business
services space with over 50 current or past investments. Bain Capital has invested in businesses in the
staffing and engineering consulting services, including Quest, a leading global engineering services
provider, MSX International, a BPO company focused on technical staffing solutions and managed
services, Inetum, an IT services provider in France, and Engineering, an IT systems and services
provider in Italy, as well as other investments in the business services space, including Autodistribution
and Bravida. Following the Acquisition, our management continues to remain invested in the equity of
the Group, having reinvested approximately 63% of the net proceeds received from the Acquisition in
the Group, totaling approximately €255.0 million, or between 20% to 25% of ownership of the Group.

**Our Strategies**

We and the Sponsor have developed the following strategies:

**_Make use of our agile, decentralized operating model to further focus on organic growth by grasping_**
**_additional market share while maintaining best-in-class profitability_**

Over the years, we have been highly successful in achieving incremental organic revenue growth under
our “cell division” approach in our specialized talents solutions segment as clients are mostly SMEs
who require high touch local services. In most of our markets, we expect to continue our strategy of
embedding ourselves in local communities through an extensive branch network. While our primary
operations are in Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and France, we have branches spread across
countries where we source job candidates. Our international recruiting network is key for our ability to
attract and retain job candidates for assignments in sectors where candidates are scarce. Our
decentralized structure places our Powerhouses and Boutiques in proximity to our primary stakeholders:


-----

our clients, our job candidates and our own employees, which allows us to gain local market knowledge,
understand local competition and remain informed of local staffing trends. In order to continue to grow,
we intend to expand our branch network where needed and to continue to leverage our success in
sourcing and retaining job candidates, focusing on those job profiles which are and will be increasingly
scarce in the market. We also believe our extensive branch network approach leads to enhanced
entrepreneurship and ownership due to the managerial responsibilities and opportunities allocated or
available to branch managers, reinforcing a key part of our values.

We also intend to continue to focus on, and leverage our positive track record in, our engineering and
consulting and specialized talent solutions segments to continue growing profitably. We have gradually
shifted our focus toward the engineering and consulting and specialized staffing model and away from
general staffing, benefiting from our growing network in the transition to deliver higher margins. The
specialized staffing and engineering and consulting segments tend to deliver higher margins than
general staffing due to the premium clients place on successful placement of the specific job candidates
that they seek. Specialization in turn aims to target those segments and skills that are more difficult to
find for our customers, which in the past has provided more stability to our revenue figures and
protected our margins, including during economic downturns. We further aim to deliver continued
improvement in our adjusted EBITDA margin through efficient cost control over operating expense and
strong cash conversion with rigorous management of capital expenditures and working capital.

We believe our agile organization and increased specialization will continue to promote flexibility for
our Powerhouses and Boutiques to refine recruitment approaches and conduct day-to-day activities that
best meet their respective local business needs and enable us to offer clients tailored staffing services.
We believe this will continue to translate into higher market penetration and additional market share to
propel our organic growth, as well as our ability to effectively staff specialized jobs that drive our bestin-class profitability given the scarcity and complexity of the job profiles we match.

**_Enhance our reputation as the partner of choice for SMEs and locally managed clients_**

We intend to continue providing critical end-to-end temporary recruiting and outsourcing services that
are tailored to the needs of SMEs and other locally-managed clients. We believe that in the future these
clients, in both our engineering and consulting segment and specialized talent solutions segment, will
continue to require the assistance of providers like us primarily for temporary HR solutions as they
grapple with limited resources, lower visibility on staffing needs and greater need for outsourced HR
functions, including as a result of the complexity of labor law and associated regulations. As the partner
of choice for our SMEs and locally managed clients, we are experienced in accommodating unique and
time-sensitive client demands, including matching specialized, “mission-critical” profiles for our clients
in the engineering and consulting segment that typically last for months, or deploying a large number
of blue-collar workers at short notice for our clients in the specialized talent solutions segment that often
last for weeks or sometimes just hours as the situations require. We plan to continue focusing on being
the partner of choice for SMEs and locally managed clients by leveraging the large pool of potential
job candidates at our disposal and the deep end-market knowledge we have gathered over the years by
having boots on the ground in proximity to our clients.

**_Ensure the smooth and profitable placement of job candidates with a reliable sourcing and reskilling_**
**_platform_**

Mastering the “human” aspect of human resources is key to success in our industry, and we intend to
continue to be a leader through our focus on being able to source the right job candidate for the right
position, including through offering reskilling services. We believe that our network of international
sourcing of job candidates is vital to our success, as we are better able to bridge the large gap between
the demand for qualified job candidates and the supply of such candidates, especially as the labor market
in our Addressable Market has tightened over the past few years, through having access to a wider pool
of quality job candidates than our peers. The location of our agencies (particularly in Poland, Romania,
Spain, the Czech Republic, Moldova and Portugal) and the support we offer to foreign job candidates


-----

(including housing, transport options, opening a bank account and other integration assistance) ensures
that we are able to tap into workforces that are skilled but that are eager to seek out opportunities to
earn higher wages than those that similar work would provide in their home countries. We intend to
continue to develop our network in other countries that meet these criteria. We also plan to continue
leveraging our large sourcing network to target the best job candidates and provide them with a wide
array of positions and support, including in-house training that equips them with skillsets that match
the profiles that our clients look for, administrative support, client knowledge and even transport and
housing for foreign job candidates to make their experience as smooth as possible. Finally, we plan to
focus on preparing job candidates for what we see as the jobs of tomorrow, such as white-collar
positions in big data and information technology, that are being driven by the digitalization of the
economy or provide training in order to teach blue-collar job candidates how to use digital tools.

**_Utilize digital initiatives to reduce cost and drive revenue diversification_**

Our digital strategy is focused on maximizing the impact of digital cost reduction initiatives, outpacing
smaller competitors who have more limited investment capabilities and opening new market segments.
In the near-term, we want to leverage digital tools to complement our physical networks to attract job
candidates and clients while also spreading awareness of our brands and services. We also intend to
continue digitalizing our processes to drive efficiency. For example, SWOP, our free digital sourcing
platform that assists SMEs with day-to-day management of their vacancies, strengthens our sourcing
capability and supplements the activities of our revenue-generating business units, such as NOWJOBS,
which facilitates the actual matching of job candidates with clients.

Over the longer term, we intend to pursue a four-pillared digital strategy. First, we aim to reposition the
offices we have in urban areas into “JobShops” that are easy to reach, convenient, one-stop shops where
job candidates can be tested, get certifications and be matched with potential positions through our
digital platforms that require limited involvement of our recruiting consultants. We also are continuing
to develop niche, specialized digital platforms that are tailored to meet the specific demands of the
various markets we address. Furthermore, we intend to utilize the data that we have generated through
our large network to deliver the best possible client and job candidate service through our candidate
data platform. For example, we are currently developing Mission Akira, a data-driven tool that helps to
train our consultants on the kind of information that they should ask candidates for in order to better
prepare them for placement. We are also developing a client version of the ‘Who do I want to work for’
test, which indicates the type of job candidates that fit best with a particular team leader, and the ‘My
brains’ test which attempts to indicate the intelligence level of a job candidate within their education
level. We also plan to develop more automated processes to free up our recruiting consultants’ time for
them to focus on growing ever closer to our client and job candidate base and gather the right
information that will lead to faster and better matching.

As part of our digital strategy, we are in the process of rolling out our digital platforms internationally
to enable us to get more structured and accurate information from job candidates, so we can match them
with the right clients in a more effective and flexible manner, which we believe will help introduce
brand loyalty and help us with client and job candidates retention. For example, NOWJOBS was first
launched in Belgium in 2017, and it was subsequently launched in the Netherlands in 2019, in France
in 2021 and most recently in Germany in 2022. We also acquired StaffMe in July 2022, a French digital
platform focusing on student employment and which is primarily active in the retail, health event and
hospitality sectors, supplementing our NOWJOBS offering. Through this acquisition, we also acquired
the other companies of the StaffMe group, including the StaffMe Academy, the first training
organization for young entrepreneurs, and the Accelerator, a program of integration through selfemployment for those who are far from employment. NOWJOBS will operate under the StaffMe brand
in France given the high level of StaffMe’s brand awareness in that country. We plan to continue to
develop our other digital platforms and roll them out beyond their current markets.


-----

**_Continue to target accretive acquisition opportunities to achieve European leadership_**

While our primary focus is to grow our earnings base organically and to improve both profitability and
Pre-Tax Free Cash Flow generation through our existing network and customer base, we will continue
to consider accretive and strategic platform and bolt-on acquisitions in both new and existing markets
to achieve our goal of European leadership. We do not consider acquisition opportunities aimed at
turning around a business, but only will consider opportunities that can reinforce our market positions
or expand our footprint, either in new geographical regions or niche areas in which we currently are not
present and that exhibit the following attributes: stable economies with low unemployment, high salary
level, high temporary staff penetration, a stable regulatory environment and supply and demand
mismatch for skilled labor. We will continue to focus on acquisitions of highly specialized businesses
(such as IT, legal and finance), business focusing on bottleneck jobs and engineering and consulting
services. We will also consider opportunities in digital tools that can improve the value chain or allow
us to better serve job candidates as well as clients and to develop new and complementary segments
that are also marked by labor market scarcity or that can demonstrate the prospect for high growth and
superior margins. We will continue to use our M&A assessment criteria, which requires that any
opportunity meets our own high quality standards, holds a leading position in its respective specialized
end-market, reflects a strong financial profile and represents a good cultural fit with us. While we
historically have focused on bolt-on acquisitions that can enhance our network and/or provide us with
exposure to complementary sectors of the economy, we also occasionally consider larger acquisitions
that are otherwise consistent with our investment criteria. We are also targeting, in particular, certain
new end-markets such as healthcare and pharmaceuticals and new geographic markets such as the
Nordic countries and other countries, such as Austria and Switzerland.

**Our History**

We were founded in 1995 by Philip Cracco and Conny Vandendriessche along with a financial sponsor
as Accent, a Belgium-based recruiting firm. We acquired Logi-technic in 2009 and Bekaert Technics
in 2010, expanding our operations within Belgium.

Over the course of 2012 to 2014, Naxicap, a French private equity firm, acquired a majority stake in
our business, and we have expanded significantly to become a leading provider of specialized HR
solutions in multiple European markets. Our business made its first cross-border acquisition in March
2015, acquiring the French staffing firm Abylsen, which became one of our Powerhouses and seconds
engineers through multiple offices across France, Belgium and Switzerland. From 2015, our expansion
accelerated through Organic Growth and through acquisitions, starting with two other major
acquisitions in 2015, which have since become Powerhouses: Covebo, a Dutch specialized temporary
staffing company sourcing Polish workers through a network in Poland and the Netherlands, and
Continu Professionals, a Dutch professional staffing company seconding white-collar technical
professionals in the construction, civil and industrial engineering end-markets. We have since acquired
firms that have become other Powerhouses of our Group, such as Redmore, GRITT, TIMEPARTNER,
Cohedron, SOLCOM and TMI. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition
_and Results of Operations—Acquisitions, Disposals and the Comparability of our Financial_
_Statements” for further information on our acquisitions._

In 2018, we implemented a legal reorganization which was completed in January 2019, as a result of
which our holding companies, House of HR NV and The House of Pledge NV, hold 100% of the equity
interests in each of the top entities associated with the Group’s ten Powerhouses (except for Abylsen,
which is held by Accent). We had historically structured our business across three segments:
engineering and consulting, specialized staffing and general staffing. In 2021, we integrated our legacy
specialized staffing and general staffing segments into the current specialized talent solutions segment,
and we now categorize our ten Powerhouses into one of the two staffing segments: engineering and
consulting and specialized talent solutions, which are also the Group’s financial reporting segments.


-----

On May 28, 2022, Bain Capital entered into the Acquisition Agreement to acquire a majority stake in
the Group. The Acquisition was completed on November 3, 2022. See “Summary—The Transactions”
for further details.

**Our Business Model**

Our business units serve as the intermediaries between job candidates (supply) and the client requiring
staffing solutions (demand). Our in-house employees include sales, marketing and recruiting staff, who
work to attract job candidates to our business units and to maintain and build new client relationships

We will typically enter into an employment agreement with the job candidate and a service agreement
with the client. The employment agreement is often entered into with the job candidate in connection
with us entering into a service agreement with the client. In these cases, the employment agreement is
for the duration of a particular client assignment, which duration will vary a great deal among our
business units due to the nature of the services offered and will also be impacted by the nature of the
services required by the client. In a number of our business units, in particular those in our engineering
and consulting segment, the employment agreement will often be an indefinite employment agreement
and for a longer duration than the service agreement with the client as a result of regulatory reasons or
to facilitate recruiting job candidates.


-----

Nearly all of the service agreements into which we enter with clients are time and materials service
agreements, which means we are compensated under the contract for the services and materials provided
by our job candidates. A small number of the service agreements we enter into with clients are projectoriented, which means we are compensated under the agreement only when our job candidates deliver
the project in accordance with the specifications in the agreement.

When we have a time and materials service agreement with a client, we typically bill the client for the
services performed by the job candidate and pay the salary and the applicable associated benefits, fees
and costs, such as social security, of the job candidate. The difference between what we bill our clients
and what we pay as salary, benefits and associated costs to the job candidates is referred to as the “billpay spread,” which is a key driver of our Group’s profitability. Our business units are organized around
a variety of staffing models which have varying degrees of specialization and scarcity, which impacts
the bill-pay spread. We focus on providing best-in-class service, matching excellence and investing in
digital initiatives to enhance our service offering as well as to automate processes and reduce costs to
maximize the bill-pay spread. Other elements that are part of our business model include a focus on
SME clients (who often lack in-house staff who can perform the staffing services that we provide),
providing training to our job candidates and including non-solicitation or minimum fees for a particular
period for job candidates in relation to the client for which they are staffed. For further information
about the pricing of our job candidates in our service agreements with clients, see “Management’s
_Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key factors affecting our_
_results of operations.”_

The nature of the employment agreement into which we enter with job candidates and its duration
(whether it is an open-ended contract for the length of an assignment or an indefinite contract that is in
place whether or not the job candidate is on an assignment) will depend primarily upon the regulatory
environment in which our business units operate and the type of contract needed to attract, recruit and
retain job candidates. The nature of the employment agreement will also impact the termination and
notice periods. Indefinite contracts typically provide for three to six month notice periods for us to
terminate the employment agreement (except in Germany where terminations can happen sooner, and
labor durations are also typically shorter). The flexibility of open-ended contracts typically allows us to
enter into an employment agreement with the job candidate in connection with an assignment with a
client and the notice periods in the service agreement will be aligned with the notice period in the
employment agreement. On the other hand, as a result of the indefinite employment agreements, we
experience “bench time,” which is the time for which job candidates are paid but cannot be billed to a
client assignment, for our job candidates with indefinite contracts. We carefully monitor the end date
of all such job candidates’ assignments and aim to line up the next assignment before their current one
comes to an end to minimize bench time. By minimizing a job candidate’s bench time, we aim to ensure
job candidates are being utilized on billable matters and generating revenue since we will be responsible
for the costs associated with employing them whether or not they are on assignment with a client.

In our engineering and consulting segment, employment agreements with job candidates are typically
indefinite due to the regulatory environment of the countries in which our business units in this staffing
segment operate or in order to attract and retain job candidates to fill staffing shortages. In certain
Powerhouses, such as Redmore, the employment agreement approach also facilitates longer and more
specialized training for job candidates and deepens the relationship between ourselves and these job
candidates. Within this segment, we also utilize a number of freelance job candidates (approximately
36% of job candidates at work as of September 30, 2022), primarily in the SOLCOM business, but also
in the Abylsen, Continu Professionals, GRITT and Redmore Powerhouses, whom we screen and match
with clients but who do not become our employees. In our specialized talent solutions segment, due to
the countries in which our business units in this segment offer services and our ability to attract and
recruit job candidates, we typically use fixed-term contracts with job candidates, except for our
operations in Germany, where we generally enter into an indefinite employment agreement with a job
candidate due to regulations on temporary staffing there. As a result, our specialized talent solutions
segment also faces bench time risk with respect to job candidates in Germany. The bench time risk in
the specialized talent solutions segment is, however, typically less than that in the engineering and


-----

consulting segment due to the shorter periods of services typically associated with these job candidates
and consequently the typically shorter notice periods required for our job candidates in this segment.

**The Recruiting Lifecycle: Facilitating Supply and Demand**

The recruiting lifecycle, which refers to the sourcing of job candidates, the identification of clients who
require our specialized HR solutions for particular jobs and then the subsequent matching, on-boarding
and payment or billing of such work, is a fundamental part of the operations of each of our business
units. Each of our business units is focused on the full spectrum of the recruiting lifecycle, which we
describe in more detail below. We also seek to align our in-house employees’ incentives, including sales
and recruiting teams, with the Group’s financial performance, with for example approximately 13% of
the Accent’s salaries being variable performance-based compensation as of December 31, 2021, which,
based on interviews with market participants, we believe is higher than the industry’s average variable
performance-based compensation.

**_Supply: Job Candidates_**

The following describes the typical elements of the recruiting lifecycle and the role we play in relation
to job candidates:

- **_Sourcing: Our business units define the job candidate requirements through their knowledge_**
of relevant end-markets, the needs of clients and, if applicable, any specific client requirements
provided, and then identify potential job candidates. We source job candidates through
databases, our presence at schools, universities and on job boards, our digital initiatives such as
SWOP, as well as through training for the skilling or reskilling of job candidates. We also make
use of foreign recruiting networks in certain of our Powerhouses, such as Accent, Covebo,
Redmore and TIMEPARTNER.

- **_Assessing:_** We assess job candidates by checking their education and skills (with additional
assessment for more specialized roles) and certify their capabilities.

- **_Matching: To match job candidates to clients’ opportunities, we check their fit with the job_**
position and company, including their mobility and availability for the location and duration of
the assignment. We then match a job candidate to a client and seek to ensure the job candidate
has a good understanding of the job and its requirements. All our digital initiatives aim to
improve data quality, which will lead to improved matching capabilities and results. For our
digital tools, such as SWOP and NOWJOBS, matching is all digitalized to the extent possible
to make the process more effective and efficient. We are also leveraging other different
matching engines to improve matching results based on specific criteria. In addition, we are
currently working to develop a candidate data platform (“CDP”) to further improve data quality
and management of job candidate information.

- **_Administrative management: We prepare the contract with the job candidate, whose terms may_**
vary based on the Powerhouse and the type of placement with which the job candidate is
matched, and we provide other administrative support throughout the assignment, including,
for example, the monitoring and management of vacation day requests and job candidate
payments, as well as the observation of sector agreements to ensure they are respected. We also
prepare the customer contracts and ensure all required information to commence the job is
shared with both the client and job candidate. We also follow up to ensure smooth contract
signatures are obtained initially and then upon renewal, if desired.

- **_On-boarding: We present the job candidate to the client, guiding him/her through interviews._**
We also follow up with job candidates in certain placements, such as within the engineering
and consulting segment, after candidates are placed in order to check their satisfaction with the
client and the assignment, whether the matching was accurate and to further understand any


-----

further wishes or objectives of the job candidate. Job candidates, especially in the engineering
and consulting segment, are also trained to fit certain job or project-specific tasks.

- **_Payroll and payments: We use digital timesheets and validate the timesheets, to facilitate the_**
correct payment of job candidates’ salaries. For our specialized talent solutions segment,
payments are generally made on a weekly or bi-weekly basis (but it is possible in some
instances on a daily basis), and client invoicing is done on a weekly basis.

**_Demand: the client and its HR staffing needs_**

The following describes the typical elements of the recruiting lifecycle and the role we play in relation
to the client’s HR staffing needs:

- **_Selling: We manage existing client accounts, identify potential clients and generate leads on_**
clients’ staffing needs.

- **_Publishing: We discuss general requirements with clients to gain an understanding of specific_**
job requirements and the required job candidates for such a job, and then publish offers via our
business units (including on their own websites), third-party applications or social media.

- **_Matching: We identify and present a short list of eligible job candidates for the position to the_**
client and organize meetings and interviews with the job candidates. Our digital initiatives, such
as Gighouse and NOWJOBS automatically match job candidates to clients, though we often
monitor our digital initiatives in order to facilitate the matching and engage with the job
candidates and clients when needed.

- **_Administrative management: We prepare the service agreement between ourselves and the_**
client.

- **_Invoicing and payments: We use timesheets and validate those timesheets to provide correct_**
and transparent invoicing to clients and correct salary payments to job candidates, with certain
of our staffing solutions utilizing digital timesheets. We can also manage the different legal
requirements in the jurisdictions in which we operate for clients, including the payment of
payroll taxes and other withholdings.

- **_After-sales: We follow up with clients after on-boarding job candidates to check if the matching_**
was accurate and to assess the client’s satisfaction with the job candidate and the recruiting
process.

**_Our International Recruiting Network_**

As mentioned above, certain of our business units also utilize their international recruiting networks to
source job candidates. We believe that best practice for job candidate sourcing from international
markets is managed through foreign recruiting-dedicated teams in local foreign offices which are joined
up with foreign recruiting teams in host countries to identify clients with long-outstanding vacancies.
A foreign recruiting team with a presence in both countries can then offer a full-service proposition to
the customer covering all steps from sourcing and recruiting to on-boarding and payroll. We also believe
Covebo and Accent, and since 2019, TIMEPARTNER, reflect best practices by having job candidate
integration teams in the host countries that are dedicated to placing and monitoring foreign workers,
providing in-house training and offering other comprehensive services to assist with their integration
(support in finding housing, health, transport, tax assistance and possibly host country language
support). Covebo is also available as an app, allowing job candidates to access its services on mobile
devices. We also utilize some digital tools to recruit in foreign countries, such as Dora in Romania,
Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany, France, the UK, Poland, Portugal, Bulgaria and Lithuania. Dora
is a chatbot, or a computer program designed to ask pre-set questions to screen job candidates before
engaging them with our live recruiters. Dora can be deployed through Facebook, Instagram and other


-----

social media platforms, targeting job candidates looking for job vacancies, and is available in Polish,
Romanian and English. The employment of foreign workers as our job candidates is conducted
according to the receiving country’s legal framework. See “Regulation” for information about the
regulatory environment in each of our primary geographic markets.

Each of our segments is composed of multiple Powerhouses which use various brands to promote their
specialized HR solution offering. Through these Powerhouses, each segment typically focuses on

and takes various approaches to employment terms and placement duration. A depiction of the typical

segment is laid out below:

We believe our “cell division” expansion strategy, which focuses on securing new sales before
committing to additional costs, is a key driver of organic growth for our specialized talent solutions
segment. We hire additional sales personnel at an existing branch to focus on developing opportunities
out of our existing offices as commercial activity increases over time as we identify clear expansion
opportunities. A new, dedicated commercial manager is appointed and given an agreed period of time


-----

in order to acquire new clients or a new customer segment in a prospective area. Once these new clients
have been secured and adequate revenue has been generated, the commercial manager opens a new
office to handle such clients and becomes an office manager hiring their own staff. This strategy has
allowed us to continually strengthen our geographic breadth and depth without pursuing acquisitions
and with minimal risk, thereby driving our organic growth. We also believe that our variable
compensation model, which rewards recruiters, sales consultants and office managers at our branches
for finding, matching and retaining job candidates, also drives our organic growth, particularly for our
engineering and consulting segment.

**_Geographic Presence of our Staffing Segments_**

Our clients’ HR staffing needs are typically local, requiring HR staffing for such clients’ local business
location(s). For most of our Powerhouses, having branches close to our clients and job candidates is
important to being able to find and match job candidates. As a result, our Powerhouses typically have
a number of existing branches spread throughout the applicable geographic regions and focus on
building scale and density by opening new branches throughout these areas in order to be closer to job
candidates and clients.

For the year ended December 31, 2021, Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and France represented
approximately 23.4%, 50.2%, 15.1% and 11.3%, respectively, of our Pro Forma Management Adjusted
EBITDA.
