**_Abylsen_**

Abylsen is an engineering and consulting Powerhouse headquartered in France, with operations in
France, Belgium, Switzerland, Italy and Luxembourg. Abylsen operates in a competitive but
fragmented market, where it is a relatively small company which challenges primarily large global
consulting or mid-sized global companies or brands, as well as regional companies or brands.

_End-markets served and contract framework_

We provide engineering and technology consulting services to clients, with the majority of sales revenue
from clients being from blue-chip or larger medium-sized companies. We also have a strong focus on
SME clients. In terms of end-market, Abylsen is a multi-specialist Powerhouse providing engineering
graduates to a wide range of end-markets. The largest end-markets served by Abylsen’s engineers are
energy, industry, telecommunications and pharmaceutical, though we also served a number of clients
in automotive, transport, aeronautics and defense and IT. Abylsen also serves these industries via its
Boutiques Pharmacos, Pharma Insights, Belgatech, Mykelson, Greenworking and ETA.

_Types of clients and job candidates_

Abylsen has a strong focus on balancing talent hiring and retention with wage control and turnover.
Furthermore, it uses engineers to recruit and match engineering job candidates to clients and to provide
in-house employees with end-market and job specialization and understanding.

The service agreements Abylsen enters into with clients will vary from client to client depending on
their end-market and staffing needs. For example, Abylsen also provided one of our clients, a leading
pharmaceuticals company, with a team to monitor the remediation of emergency lighting defects across
their expansive facilities.

_Financial performance and other operating metrics_

Since its acquisition in March 2015, Abylsen’s EBITDA has grown from €17.7 million for the year
ended December 31, 2015 to €20.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, with an EBITDA
growth of 2.4% per annum, and its revenue has grown from €75.7 million for the year ended December
31, 2015 to €124.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, with a revenue growth of 8.6% per
annum. As of September 30, 2022, Abylsen had 45 branches, 480 in house full time equivalent
employees and 2,151 qualified specialists at work with different expertise (including mechanical,
electrical and chemical engineering). For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, Abylsen had
_Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue of €206.2 million. The substantial majority of Abylsen’s_
revenue is generated in France, with the remainder of sales primarily being generated in Belgium. Bench
time was at 2.8% for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022.

**_Redmore_**

Redmore is a provider of specialized secondment and consulting services in our engineering and
consulting segment headquartered in the Netherlands, with operations in the Netherlands, Poland and a


-----

newly opened international branch in Spain (Triple A – Risk Finance) and Portugal (ITDS). We
typically provide consulting and secondment services to clients through job candidates with university
degrees or applied university degrees who are predominantly but not exclusively on indefinite term
contracts with us. Redmore and its Boutiques operate primarily in the banking and insurance sectors,
and also for governments and companies seeking financial staffing in enterprise recourse planning
(“ERP”) implementation, with competitors of a variety of sizes, including large global companies and
the “Big Four” accountancy firms.

Redmore has five complementary brands: Talent&Pro, Triple A - Risk Finance, Profource, ITDS and
Vialegis:

- **_Talent&Pro focuses on secondment of its own job candidates for the Dutch financial end-_**
market who are either on indefinite term contracts with us, temporary personnel or freelancers
(whom we have screened and assessed);

- **_Triple A - Risk Finance_** provides consulting services in the area of actuary and risk
management services and job candidates placed by Triple A - Risk Finance ordinarily have
actuarial and risk managements backgrounds;

- **_Profource provides secondment and consulting services through our job candidates who are_**
specialized in optimizing finance processes, the execution of enterprise resource planningrelated assignments and business processes outsourcing;

- **_ITDS provides specialist consulting for insurance companies, pension funds and banks; and_**

- **_Vialegis provides legal staffing solutions, including search and selection services, with a focus_**
on highly skilled white-collar job candidates primarily to the largest law firms in Belgium,
Luxembourg and Germany. Vialegis also offers, mainly in Belgium, interim legal counsels to
large corporates, for interim legal services and projects. Vialegis was one of our Powerhouses
in the engineering and consulting segment, but was sold to Redmore on September 30, 2021
and has since been operating as part of Redmore and is no longer a separate platform.

_End-markets served and contract framework_

While the majority of Redmore’s revenue comes from large corporates, SMEs and intermediate sized
enterprises also contribute a significant portion of its overall revenue. In terms end-market, Redmore is
a specialist Powerhouse providing financial consulting services to end-markets including insurance,
banking, government and health, as well as to other corporates.

Redmore, through its five Boutiques, is primarily engaged on time and material contracts. For the year
ended December 31, 2021, 92.5% by revenue of the contracts for the Boutiques under Redmore were
time and material contracts. Based on our periodic assessment of our contracts, we estimate that a
typical service agreement between these brands and a client will be a time and materials contract for an
average duration of six to ten months. Furthermore, our job candidates in Redmore are typically
employees on our payroll with an indefinite contract, meaning that bench time may occur. As a result,
this is a metric which is carefully monitored. Redmore also monitors the chargeability of its job
candidates since a number of its job candidates, primarily in its consulting services, will be engaged
periodically on non-chargeable activities such as training or pre-sale activities, which are expected to
benefit the Powerhouse’s sales in the long-run, but will result in periods where job candidates are not
generating revenue for the Powerhouse. Redmore’s revenue also stems from various other sources,
including fees relating to business process outsourcing for certain banks and insurance companies
performed via its service center in Utrecht, search and selection fees generated by Vialegis and Ctrl-F
for permanent placement at clients and fees relating to freelance placement.

_Types of clients and job candidates_


-----

Redmore has a strong focus on training, coaching and evaluating its job candidates and placing them in
assignments that develop their skills through experience. We typically recruit young professionals and
provide training to them from day one and over their years of employment with us as job candidates to
develop their financial expertise. The Powerhouse also offers an in-house academy with certifications
and qualifications, knowledge and competency frameworks to attract and retain job candidates and to
develop them with increasing market value for its clients. For many of the assignments for which our
Powerhouses’ job candidates are eligible, their market value (the bill value we can charge), increases
more quickly than the salary requirements (the payment we make to job candidates), which contributes
to the bill-pay spread and our Group’s profitability.

The service agreements that each of the brands under Redmore enters into with clients will vary from
client to client depending on a number of factors including their end-market and staffing needs.
Examples of service agreements entered into by each of Redmore’s brands are provided below:

- Talent&Pro provided a team of job candidates, comprising of a mix of junior and senior job
candidates, to one of our clients, a Dutch bank, to fulfil their need for compliance professionals
for a Customer Due Diligence Enhancement project involving approximately 30,000 KnowYour-Customer files related to SMEs. Talent&Pro designed and ran this project through an
outsourcing solution, including management, quality control and reporting. Talent&Pro placed
52 consultants through 2020 and 2021. This agreement generated a total revenue of €3.1
million, of which €2.8 million was generated in 2021.

- Profource was asked by one of its clients, a global e-commerce company, to implement and
rollout a new HR application, the Oracle HCM Cloud Time & Labor and Absence Management,
in 21 countries. Profource provided a team of eleven consultants and project managers to
successfully deliver this project, which generated a total revenue of approximately €0.4 million
in 2021.

- ITDS was asked by one of its clients, a term life insurance company, to assist with the selection
and implementation of a new core administrative system. In 2021, we placed four consultants
on this project, and this service agreement is expected to run until the end of 2023 and generate
a total revenue of approximately €2.0 million, of which we invoiced €0.2 million in 2021 and
€0.6 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022.

- Triple A - Risk Finance was selected by several insurance companies to help implement IFRS
17. At four major Dutch insurance companies, Triple A - Risk Finance placed 31 job candidates
at each company in 2021. These projects together generated a total revenue of €4.6 million.

- Vialegis, at the request of one of its longstanding clients, an independent Belgian law firm,
searched and successfully recruited a team of lawyers consisting of three partners and seven
associates to join the client from another independent law firm. This placement generated a
one-off fee of €0.1 million.

_Financial performance and other operating metrics_

Since its acquisition in December 2017, Redmore’s EBITDA has grown from €20.4 million for the year
ended December 31, 2017 to €36.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, with an EBITDA
growth of 15.3% per annum, and its revenue has grown from €108.1 million for the year ended
December 31, 2017 to €138.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, with a revenue growth of
6.6% per annum. As of September 30, 2022, Redmore had 20 offices, with 246 in-house full-time
equivalent employees and 2,040 job candidates at work. For the twelve months ended September 30,
2022, Redmore had revenues of €211.3 million. Nearly all of Redmore’s revenue is generated in the
Netherlands. Bench time was at 1.1% during the same period.


-----

**_Continu Professionals_**

Continu Professionals is a specialist in finding white-collar secondment solutions for the engineering
and construction markets in our engineering and consulting segment. It is headquartered in the
Netherlands, with branches throughout the Netherlands, two branches in Belgium and a branch in
Germany that was opened at the beginning of 2019. Continu Professionals provides secondment
solutions to clients through job candidates who are planners, foremen, superintendents, technical
designers, project managers, architects and a wide variety of engineers such as in manufacturing,
infrastructure and construction (including specialization in social housing corporations) research and
development, and mechanical.

_End-markets served and contract framework_

The substantial majority of sales revenue from clients comes from SME and intermediate sized
enterprises. In terms of end-markets, Continu Professionals was a mono-specialist Powerhouse
providing secondment services towards the construction end-market, but has been diversifying its
services to include the industrial, civil and mechanical engineering end-markets. It has also increased
its specialization within the construction end-market through its acquisition of mténv, which is focused
on social housing corporations, as well as with the acquisitions of TechMatch in January 2020 and
Solyne in January 2021, both generally on technical profiles, with Solyne focusing primarily on public
infrastructure projects.

Continu Professionals is primarily engaged on time and material contracts, with a focus on assignments
that provide opportunities for temporary placements to lead to permanent positions, or “temp-to-perm.”
Continu Professionals’ exposure to bench time is limited due to its use of back-to-back contracts
(meaning a contract is entered into between us and the job candidate in connection with a secondment
or other staffing assignment with a client for the same duration) and short notice periods towards
seconded job candidates. Furthermore, since 2016, Continu Professionals has been a member of the
Algemene Bond Uitzendondernemeningen (the “ABU”), which means the applicable CLA is the ABU
CLA. This allows Continu Professionals to enter into multiple consecutive temporary contracts within
five years with an employee (as opposed to three under provisions applicable to it before joining the
ABU) and has also allowed Continu Professionals to offer longer duration contracts. See “Regulation”
for further information. For the year ended December 31, 2021, all of the contracts for the Boutiques
under Continu Professionals were time and material contracts, with a typical service agreement between
Continu Professionals and a client being for an average duration of twelve months. Continu
Professionals also engages in executive search assignments, including providing assessment services,
for some of its existing customer.

_Types of clients and job candidates_

Continu Professionals provides nationwide coverage through the Netherlands, offering a high degree of
specialization through its job candidates. The Powerhouse is recognized among the Group for its best
practices with respect to job candidate retention, providing regular touch points with job candidates
throughout their candidate journey, starting from first contact through to satisfaction surveys while on
assignment, as well as scheduled touch points to recognize and celebrate key events such as signing a
contract and the job candidate’s birthday.

The service agreements Continu Professionals enters into with clients will vary from client to client
depending on their end-market and their staffing needs. For instance, Continu Professionals placed 78
job candidates at the world’s leading lithography company which generated approximately €2.5 million
in revenue in 2021. Continu Professionals also placed 42 job candidates in engineering and construction
roles as well as a sales manager on premises at one of our clients, a European construction services
business, in 2021. This engagement brought in approximately €2.2 million in revenue in 2021.


-----

_Financial performance and other operating metrics_

Since its acquisition in September 2015, Continu’s EBITDA has grown from €11.0 million for the year
ended December 31, 2017 to €11.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, with an EBITDA
growth of 1.3% per annum, and its revenue has grown from €68.7 million for the year ended December
31, 2015 to €97.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 (which includes the combined revenue
contribution from the bolt-on acquisitions of MT&V in June 2018, Hartd in December 2018, and
TechMatch in January 2020 of €38.0 million), with a revenue growth of 6.0% per annum. Continu’s
revenue growth was affected in 2020 and 2021 due to management issues and adverse regulatory
conditions, as well as due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. As of September 30, 2022, Continu
Professionals had 19 branches, with 240 in-house full-time equivalents and 1,845 job candidates at
work. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, Continu Professionals had revenues of €134.4
million. Nearly all of the Continu Professionals’ sales revenue is generated in the Netherlands. Due to
the open ended contracts and short notice periods possible with Continu Professionals’ job candidates,
bench time is not a primary key performance indicator for this Powerhouse.

**_Cohedron_**

Cohedron is a Dutch full-service staffing provider specializing in the government and public sector with
a goal to make a meaningful impact. With more than 3,000 qualified specialists and over 30 years of
experience, Cohedron supports and advises public authorities and non-profit organizations through its
offering of outsourcing of processes and secondment of qualified specialists, as well as consultancy to
organizations and public authorities in areas such as debt counselling, budget management and
administration to drive efficiencies and costs savings.

_End-markets served and contract framework_

The substantial majority of sales revenue from clients comes from governments and local authorities.
Cohedron focuses on assignments that serve municipalities, government and public sector companies.
Cohedron’s scope of services provided through its Boutiques include secondment services, spatial
communication, content management, job classification, compensation and benefits, interim HR
services, reorganization, social medical care consulting, social media administration, municipal
guardianship, debt counselling, budget management obligations, capacity issues and consulting on
government regulations.

_Types of clients and job candidates_

Cohedron’s Boutiques include Argonaut, Future Communication, Human Capital Group, Plangroep,
Plangroep Financiële Services, Sqiq, Wyzer, Zorg-Lokaal, Vanberkel Professionals and Bureau Brug.
Through these Boutiques, Cohedron provides support and advices clients in the government and public
sector to better serve their constituents by offering three services, namely outsourcing, secondment and
consultancy. All business lines in Cohedron have a well-educated workforce with experience in the
sectors they work for.

Most of Cohedron’s contracts are awarded through public tenders. The majority of the revenues of
Cohedron comes from municipalities, while other participants in the government and public sector, such
as police, universities, railway, tax authorities and ministries, and clients in the private sector such as
banking institutions, insurers and energy suppliers, also generate steady revenues.

Job candidates are generally placed on outsourced long-term contracts, secondment framework
agreements or consultancy with service contracts.

_Financial performance and other operating metrics_

As of September 30, 2022, Cohedron had 15 branches with 323 internal full-time equivalent employees
and 1,858 full-time equivalent professionals working at the client. For the twelve months ended


-----

September 30, 2022, Cohedron had Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue of €207.3 million. All
of the Cohedron’s sales revenue is generated in the Netherlands. The productivity rate was 86.8% for
the twelve months ended September 30, 2022.

**_SOLCOM_**

SOLCOM is a German specialist in contracting services covers primarily lucrative, highly specialized
IT and engineering segments across various industries within the DACH region. SOLCOM mostly
works with experienced freelancers only. SOLCOM facilitates and manages the process of matching
clients with experienced freelancers throughout the contracting period.

_End-markets served and contract framework_

The substantial majority of sales revenue from clients comes from Germany. SOLCOM’s invoice
service is primarily offered on a time and material basis, either via hourly or daily rates based on preagreed terms with client.

SOLCOM is primarily engaged in client and freelancer contracts, with a focus on projects in the
specialized IT and engineering sector. Each client contract is designed individually to ensure flexibility
and compliance with all relevant regulations, while we also use standardized contracts with certain
experts.

_Types of clients and job candidates_

SOLCOM’s client base is comprised of several blue-chip as well as mid-sized companies primarily in
the automotive and transport, aviation and aerospace, consumer, energy chemical and financial services
industries, who regularly seek support to fill positions with highly specialized expert support. Client
representatives are often from technical departments which requires matching of profiles to be efficient
and hassle-free. The diversification of industries is the foundation of SOLCOM’s stable and predictable
revenues generation.

SOLCOM has a network of over 100,000 experts who are highly experienced and educated, and a
majority of these experts possess an academic background in technical fields, such as computer
sciences, engineering, mechanical engineering and civil engineering.

_Financial performance and other operating metrics_

As of September 30, 2022, SOLCOM had 286 in-house full-time equivalent employees and 1,786
freelancers at work. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, SOLCOM had _Pro Forma_
Management Adjusted Revenue of €217.6 million. Nearly all of SOLCOM’s sales revenue is generated
in Germany.

**_Other Powerhouses and Boutiques of the Engineering and Consulting Segment_**

Our engineering and consulting segment also includes GRITT (which includes TEC and Logi-technic
and operates in Belgium and Luxembourg), as well as IBB and AERO, which are engineering and

Sales from the GRITT contributed 7.1% of the engineering and consulting segment’s revenue for the

**_Accent_**

Accent is a specialized staffing Powerhouse focused exclusively on the Belgian specialty market, with
operations in Belgium and offices in Poland, Romania, Moldova and Portugal for the sourcing of job
candidates from its international recruiting network. Accent operates in a competitive and consolidated
market where it challenges larger global staffing solutions companies or brands, as well as regional
companies or brands.

_End-markets served and contract framework_

Accent focuses on the more sustainable and profitable “temp-to-perm” contracts, with a focus on
different niches and with a strong network of local branches, specialized to serving a specific type of
job candidate profile and client end-markets. Nearly all of the sales revenue from this Powerhouse
comes from SMEs or intermediate sized enterprises who value speed and flexibility, a close customerrelationship and who are willing to pay a premium for Accent’s services, therefore quality over quantity.
In terms of end-markets, Accent provides primarily blue-collar job candidates, of whom approximately
25% are foreign workers, to a wide range of end-markets. The largest end-markets served by Accent’s
job candidates are the construction, transportation, food service and hospitality end-markets, though our
job candidates also serve a number of clients in the services, healthcare and transport markets.

Accent is mostly engaged on time and material contracts, with a focus on “temp-to-perm” assignments.
Pursuant to temporary worker legislation in Belgium, Accent is typically able to align its job candidates’
contract durations with its clients’ contract duration, resulting in no exposure to bench time. See
“Regulation.” For the year ended December 31, 2021, nearly all of Accent’s contracts were time and
material contracts, with an average duration of 40 days. Since 2018, Accent has also begun to offer
search and selection services via its Ctrl-F Boutique, which are invoiced on a fee basis and are primarily


-----

supported by an internal “digital talent hunter” recruitment team. Accent’s revenues also include those
generated by NOWJOBS and Gighouse in Belgium.

_Types of clients and job candidates_

Accent has a strong focus on developing best services for a fast-yet-high-quality candidate and client
matching, driven by strong digital initiatives for which Accent is being recognized as a pioneer in the
market. Since assignments are typically for a relatively short duration, being able to quickly match a
job candidate and client quickly is important. Accent combines strong intimacy in the front with a strong
efficiency in the back.

Accent assisted one of our clients, a sanitaryware wholesaler with its on-going demand to find
temporary job candidates and then hire them as permanent employees by co-creating a website for
applicants and helped to coordinate the required education for future sanitary technicians. Accent also
assigned a dedicated single point of contact to a large infrastructure company to assist, through one of
its Boutiques, Engie, in the recruitment of the more technical profiles.

_Financial performance and other operating metrics_

As of September 30, 2022, Accent had 384 branches, which branches reflect teams dedicated to specific
specialty job candidates, 1,166 full-time equivalent employees and 28,987 job candidates at work. For
the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, Accent had Pro Forma Management Adjusted Revenue
of €618.8 million. Nearly all of the Powerhouse’s sales revenue is generated in Belgium.

**_Covebo_**

Covebo is a blue-collar specialized staffing Powerhouse. It is focused on the Dutch specialty blue-collar
staffing market, with operations in the Netherlands, as well as its branches in Hungary, Lithuania, Spain,
Poland and Romania, which are part of its international recruiting network.

_End-markets served and contract framework_

Covebo focuses on temporary staffing for two primary end-markets: (1) construction and technical,
including technical, construction and infrastructure jobs; and (2) production and logistics, including
food, logistics and industry jobs. Nearly all of the sales revenue from this Powerhouse comes from
SMEs or intermediate sized enterprises, with certain exceptions relating to larger clients in the
production and logistics end-market. Covebo provides blue-collar job candidates to its clients, of which
typically approximately 80% are foreign workers. The most frequent end-markets served by Covebo’s
job candidates are the food production, retail, logistics, engineering and construction and infrastructure
end-markets.

Through its digital initiative Fygi, Covebo offers interim recruitment, search and selection and
recruitment marketing services. Independent freelancers will become recruiters for mostly white-collar
profiles at different companies, by using Covebo’s digital tools and platforms. Covebo takes a
commission on the revenue generated by these freelancers. Revenue of this initiative for the year ended
December 31, 2021 was €5.4 million.

Nearly all of Covebo’s contracts are typically flexible contracts, meaning that Covebo is not obligated
to pay any temporary job candidate not engaged in billable work for up to the first 52 weeks (depending
on the employment agreement entered into with such job candidate), with discretionary temporary
employment agreements permitted to be entered into (with up to a maximum of six employment
agreements) over the next three years (depending on the employment agreement entered into with such
job candidate) thereafter. Covebo’s exposure to bench time is thus limited due to the regulatory
framework and their ability to use of flexible contracts with job candidates. Some job candidates placed
by Covebo are freelancers, especially in the VNOM offices of Covebo. For the year ended December
31, 2021, the substantial majority of Covebo’s service agreements with clients were time and material


-----

contracts, with an average of 5.8 job candidates per client, with an average duration of approximately
41 weeks.

Covebo New Energy was launched at Covebo. Covebo New Energy is specialized in mediating
technicians in the sustainable industry, such as solar panel technicians, insulation technicians, electric
charging station technicians, air and heat pump technicians, windmill technicians and technicians who
specialize in other new energy sources.

_Types of clients and job candidates_

Covebo was one of the first dedicated blue-collar foreign recruiting based staffing companies in the
Netherlands. It offers a full-service foreign recruiting process for job candidates and clients by
facilitating and organizing housing, transportation and insurance (including health insurance) and
offering social guidance and support. In 2018, Covebo launched an in-house education program, the
Covebo Craftsman School, to support its full-service proposition which offers foreign job candidates
education on Dutch tools, materials and ways of working. The program trains and tests candidates on
various skills such as masonry, plumbing, electrics and painting. It also facilitates quick onboarding
since job candidates have been assessed as part of the training program and familiarized with customerspecific standards.

_Financial performance and other operating metrics_

Since its acquisition in June 2015, and including the contributions of Accent NL, Covebo’s EBITDA
has grown from €5.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 to €17.9 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021, with an EBITDA growth of 21.4% per annum, and its revenue has grown from
€117.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 to €311.6 million for the year ended December
31, 2021, with a revenue growth of 17.7% per annum. As of September 30, 2022, Covebo had 8,095
beds for job candidates, 1,365 cars for people at work and 7,788 health insurance policies for its foreign
temporary job candidates. As of September 30, 2022, Covebo had 40 branches, 831 full-time equivalent
employees, 12 international recruiting offices and over 12,156 job candidates at work. For the twelve
months ended September 30, 2022, Covebo had revenue of €540.7 million. Nearly all of the
Powerhouse’s sales revenue is generated in the Netherlands.

**_TIMEPARTNER_**

TIMEPARTNER specializes in the staffing of high-demand blue-collar profiles in Germany and offers
tailor-made and integrated flexible HR-solutions in the field of temporary staffing, personnel placement,
provision of temporary workers and on-site management. In June 2021, we acquired avanti, which
complements TIMEPARTNER’s service portfolio by adding a presence in the medical and healthcare
segment. Following the acquisition of LP Personalvermittlung, avanti will operate under our new
Powerhouse, House of Care Talents Germany. In addition, Zaquensis, previously a Powerhouse in our
legacy general staffing segment, is now part of the TIMEPARTNER operation following the partial
merger between TIMEPARTNER and Zaquensis in the second quarter of 2021. TIMEPARTNER also
has operations in the Czech Republic.

_End-markets served and contract framework_

TIMEPARTNER typically provides low- to medium-skilled job candidates who are from general
backgrounds to clients from a diversified group of end-markets, with the greatest concentration of
clients typically being from the industry, logistics, construction, aviation, food and automotive endmarkets. The job candidate placements by TIMEPARTNER (except IBB and AERO) are typically
short- to medium-term (with a maximum duration of 18 months), unless agreed otherwise by company
unions (approximately 48 months). In general, the contract framework for temp employees are
indefinite duration, making it a core task for TIMEPARTNER to perfectly match the job assignments
with the contract duration. That means it is crucial to make sure the (very short) notice period of client
agreements corresponds to the assignment duration and matches the notice periods of the employees,


-----

or otherwise to staff temp employees on new assignments. TIMEPARTNER also provide specialized
services through avanti in relation to the provision of medical and care personnel to hospitals, special
clinics, rehabilitation clinics and nursing homes.

_Types of clients and job candidates_

TIMEPARTNER’s clients particularly value the ability to place job candidates quickly (particularly for
short-term staffing needs), quality candidate pools, assistance and peace of mind regarding our ability
to help them comply with and navigate complicated regulatory and compliance landscapes, and good
value for money. Additionally, customers are using our competence as a master vendor to manage all
their temporary workforce, or, to a less extent, as a recruiting partner.

TIMEPARTNER’s job candidates are often looking for an HR staffing company that can find them a
job quickly, treat them well, provide opportunities for clients to take them on as permanent employees
and have a good pool of local job opportunities. TIMEPARTNER facilitates these interests from clients
and job candidates by having good industry knowledge in the markets that we serve, making decisions
quickly, having a quality pool of candidates available (and working with our international recruiting
network, where needed, to ensure we can help staff shortages) and job candidates for management
positions with good experience and skills.

_Financial performance and other operating metrics_

Since its acquisition in 2016 (based on the combined performance of Zaquensis and TIMEPARTNER
following their merger in 2021 and including the contributions from the bolt-on acquisitions of Mach
in 2017 and Weiderer in 2018), TIMEPARTNER’s EBITDA has grown from €28.6 million for the year
ended December 31, 2016 to €33.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, with an EBITDA
growth of 3.1% per annum, while its revenue has decreased from €425.6 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016 to €420.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 due to the impact of the
AüG regulatory reform and the dynamics in the aerospace segment. As of September 30, 2022,
TIMEPARTNER had 190 branches, 555 full-time equivalent employees and 10,264 job candidates at
work. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, TIMEPARTNER had Pro Forma Management
Adjusted Revenue of €356.6 million. Nearly all of the Powerhouse’s sales revenue is generated in
Germany.

**TMI**

On March 3, 2022, we acquired TMI, our new Powerhouse in our specialized talent solutions segment.
TMI specializes in providing staffing service for the healthcare sector in the Netherlands, assisting with
the recruitment of candidates for healthcare providers such as hospitals, public care institutions,
ambulance staff and nursing homes. TMI also supplies temporary staff, intermediates for freelancers,
and offers flexible jobs. Their job candidates usually include doctors, nursing staff, psychologists, and
pharmacists.

_End-markets served and contract framework_

TMI provides services primarily to clients in the healthcare sector, such as hospitals, public care
institutions, ambulance staff and nursing homes. Services rendered include providing temporary staff
(flex, 0-hours and secondment) in times of peaks or sickness, as well as general recruitment. Placements
in this segment are typically short- to medium-term, unless agreed otherwise by the client. Most clients
have a framework contract with TMI for a period of one to three years with yearly indexation or
collective employment raise.

_Types of clients and job candidates_

TMI provides services to a broad array of healthcare clients, who particularly value the high quality
candidates, broad pool of professionals and the “one stop shopping” service model offered by TMI.


-----

TMI is well recognized as the leading healthcare staffing company in the Netherlands that helps clients
to ensure continuity of healthcare services despite an ever-increasing shortage of qualified personnel in
the industry.

TMI’s job candidates are often looking for a staffing company that provides a broad selection of clients
and placement opportunities without the restrain of irregular rosters, and offers good financial benefits
and the opportunity for further education (such as through the TMI Academy).

_Financial performance and other operating metrics_

As of September 30, 2022, TMI had 16 branches, 123 full-time equivalent employees and 3,114 job
candidates at work. We estimate TMI contributed €56.0 million to Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA for
the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. See “Summary consolidated other financial and Pro
_Forma information—Pro Forma Adjusted Historical Information of the Company.”_

**Digital Initiatives**

We develop digital initiatives with a dual purpose: (i) to support growth initiatives for our operations
by enabling us to reach additional job candidates or serve new end-markets in a fully digital manner,
and (ii) to introduce cost efficiencies to our processes to remain competitive against technological
developments. By producing tools for our business units to meet business needs where no applicable
tool exists, we aim to disrupt the existing staffing market and to expand our market share by developing
new solutions or end-markets. Our digital initiatives are typically not directly revenue-generating, with
the exception of SWOP Recruiter, NOWJOBS and Gighouse, but instead indirectly contribute to
revenue generation by assisting us with identifying additional job candidates or matching them with
clients. Such initiatives can also help us reduce our expenses by automating or introducing other time
efficiencies into certain time-intensive aspects of the recruiting lifecycle. Once a digital initiative has
been developed and tested, it is typically launched by one of our Powerhouses. Any revenue generated
by the digital initiative, whether directly or indirectly, would be accounted for as part of the revenue of
the staffing unit to which the Powerhouse belongs.

During 2021, we centralized all our digital assets in House of Invest, creating one platform to meet
current needs and invest in new needs as they arise. This enabled us to further invest in our digital
roadmap and internationalize our digital initiatives. The main purpose of House of Invest is to roll out
the digital initiatives across all House of HR Powerhouses and Boutiques and to capitalize on a
centralized knowledge base. House of Invest now owns NOWJOBS, Gighouse, SWOP and SWOP
Recruiter, Continu-Connect, CV creator and My Talents (Softskillz), holds minority ownerships in Dora
and Ariad (a traditional digital marketing staffing company) and a majority ownership in Book’u. For
the year ended December 31, 2021, revenue from digital solutions amounted to 2.6% of total revenue,
compared to 1.6% for the year ended December 31, 2020.

We strive to keep our digital development team lean and operationally independent, which we believe
promotes an entrepreneurial, start-up-like culture within the team. Re-usability of our developments is
key, so applications can be exchanged across different geographies and our operating companies. We
have in the past and expect in the future to use acquisitions as another means to acquire additional digital
technologies that will complement our digital initiatives strategy or instill a more rapid growth of our
sales through the digital platforms, particularly NOWJOBS. Currently, we are developing a CDP to
consolidate all candidate data and leverage this data to gain better access to job candidates and improve
our matching capabilities. We also invest in AI tools to improve matching accuracy. Our philosophy
for job applications is “mobile-first,” meaning we are developing our digital platforms in a way that
clients and job candidates can match easily on mobile phones.

**_Mobile technology_**


-----

Our Group is strategically committed to mobile-based recruiting solutions to reach a larger pool of
potential candidates and increase user engagement. We have several live projects, including the
following mobile apps:

- **_SWOP and SWOP Recruiter: Inspired by Tinder, SWOP provides a mobile platform for job_**
candidates to “swipe right” to indicate interest on job opportunities they wish to pursue. SWOP
was downloaded 17,596 times in 2019, 46,540 times in 2020 and 14,753 times in 2021. SWOP
has enabled the placement of 60.75 job candidates per month on average as of September 30,
2022. The app was updated in early 2020 in order to include not only Accent or Ctrl-F
vacancies, but also include vacancies that are aggregated from other company websites, thus
allowing it to show approximately 60,000 vacancies (of which approximately 23,000 come
from Accent) in the Belgian market and 72,000 vacancies in the Dutch market as of October
2022. Candidates swiping on non-Accent vacancies are also contacted in order to help provide
them with the necessary support if they do wish so. In May 2021, we launched SWOP Recruiter,
which consists of a free digital platform that helps Belgian SMEs with the day-to-day
management of their vacancies. The application is currently linked to our SWOP application,
and includes a job board multi-poster tool that allows SMEs to post vacancies simultaneously
on multiple platforms.

- **_NOWJOBS: NOWJOBS is a mobile platform aimed at reaching student job candidates and for_**
flexible jobs (such as short-term part-time jobs), historically a difficult market to serve due to
low margins. By implementing a mobile, app-based platform, NOWJOBS has matched over
3,100 active companies with more than 30,800 job candidates in 2021 on a low cost basis for
our Accent Powerhouse. NOWJOBS was launched in the Netherlands in late 2019 and in
France in 2021. We also recently launched NOWJOBS in Germany in June 2022. Since
NOWJOBS mostly services the entertainment, hospitality and retail segment, it was heavily
impacted during the lockdown period during the Covid-19 pandemic, especially in the second
quarter of 2020; however, it still managed to reach a revenue in 2020 that was only 8.4% below
its 2019 revenue. It has complemented its offering now also towards food retail and food
production companies, as well as home delivery models, such as Take-Away.com and Hello
Fresh. We acquired StaffMe in July 2022, a French digital platform focusing on student
employment and which is primarily active in the retail, health event and hospitality sectors,
supplementing our NOWJOBS offering. Through this acquisition, we also acquired the other
companies of the StaffMe group, including the StaffMe Academy, the first training organization
for young entrepreneurs, and the Accelerator, a program of integration through selfemployment for those who are far from employment. NOWJOBS will operate under the
StaffMe brand in France given the high level of StaffMe’s brand awareness in that country.

- **_Gighouse: Gighouse is a mobile app designed to reach freelance or independent job candidates_**
and match them with clients. We add value by screening the freelancers or independent job
candidates to check their qualifications and experience to provide a narrower pool of suitable
options for clients. We also monitor the customer assignments to ensure freelance job
candidates are assigned to legitimate projects.

- **_FYGI:_** FYGI is a mobile platform that connects freelance recruiters to Covebo’s staffing
network and job candidate pool on a commission basis. FYGI focuses on providing freelance
recruiters access to a larger pool of potential job candidates than they would independently be
able to access in order to fill permanent positions.

Additionally, we have a full team dedicated to creating a Group framework and data platform for each
Powerhouse to develop tailored mobile solutions for its end-markets.

We have also developed CV Creator, a service that allows job seekers to create professional résumés
quickly and easily. CV Creator is available as a free web service. We developed together with the Ghent
University the MySkillz tools, through which job candidates can perform tests and get insights about


-----

themselves. One of such tests is ‘Who am I,’ which allows job candidates to better understand how they
function in their professional lives. Another test is ‘Who do I want to work for,’ which helps to indicate
the types of companies that fit best for a particular candidate. We are also developing a client version
of the ‘Who do I want to work for’ test, which indicates the type of job candidates that fit best with a
particular team leader, and the ‘My brains’ test which attempts to indicate the intelligence level of a job
candidate within their education level.

**_Chatbot technology_**

Through our investment in Happy Recruiter, we developed Dora, a recruitment robot, to leverage
chatbot technologies to perform recruitment services. Recruiters get a fully customizable chatbot
colleague that screens and communicates with job candidates located anywhere around the clock. Dora
speaks seven languages and can work side-by-side with live recruitment team as the first line of
interactions with job candidates. Dora is capable of reengaging existing job candidates on any marketing
channel, including website, database, social media channel, job board and applicant tracking system.
Dora held approximately 63,000 interviews in 2021. This technology helps find passive and active job
candidates and creates efficiency in the reaching and screening process.

**_Matching technology_**

Matching candidates to open positions is a critical component to our business and we are developing
solutions to optimize the matching processes using data analysis and AI. Such matching technology
projects focus on improving the quality of the data, including by encouraging individuals to update their
information directly on our platforms and mobile applications. Additionally, we are developing and
experimenting with AI-enabled speech-to-text tools, including for the MyAccent app, an app that is
connected with Google Assistant (for instance via smartphone or Google Home) to engage in a job
search. By converting the job candidate’s speech into text on such platforms, we will be able to develop
and test methods to automatically detect job candidates’ skills, interests and personality traits and to
better prepare our job candidates for interviews for consultant positions, so we can then more efficiently
and effectively match job candidates to appropriate job opportunities. These initiatives aim to increase
the quality and efficiency of matching and to identify skill set needs in order to develop appropriate
training. Together with the Ghent University, we developed soft skills testing to allow candidates to
discover their personal preferences as to the type of companies they wish to work for or as to their own
personality.

**M&A Process and Criteria**

M&A has been a key strategic pillar to strengthen our Group, reinforce our market positions, enter new
market segments and countries, achieve above-market growth and profitability and reinforce the
offerings of our Powerhouses. Since 2015, we have added the Abylsen, Covebo, Continu Professionals,
TIMEPARTNER (including Zaquensis), Redmore (including Vialegis), GRITT (formerly the TEC
Alliance Group), Cohedron, SOLCOM and TMI Powerhouses to the Group, as well as acquired
minority stakes in multiple companies. Beginning in 2018, we have also been focusing on bolt-on
acquisitions to enhance the platforms of our existing Powerhouses, including most recently signing the
purchase agreements for the bolt-on acquisitions in the Netherlands, France and Germany. Bolt-on
acquisitions allow our Powerhouses to either expand geographically or gain expertise in a certain endmarket or job profiles. While the growth of our Addressable Market slowed down during the Covid-19
pandemic, the economies in our primary markets have fully recovered in 2021, and according to SIA,
our Addressable Market is expected to grow at an annual rate of approximately 5% from 2021 to 2023.
We believe that we are poised to continue growing at or above the industry average growth rate in the
future. See “—Our History” and “—Our Strategies—Continue to target accretive acquisition
_opportunities to achieve European leadership.” for further information about our history and our current_
M&A strategy, respectively.

We have built and follow a structured process to assess M&A opportunities, from deal sourcing to
support for newly acquired companies, which are supported by our in-house capabilities. We also


-----

believe our approach to M&A has created an attractive value proposition for company owners at target
companies who wish to continue to develop their businesses while being supported by a larger group
and contributed to our success in closing M&A opportunities that we identify.

Our typical selection criteria, M&A assessment and integration process, value proposition and our
current M&A activity, are described further below.

**_Selection criteria_**

We use an initial set of criteria to identify targets. These criteria examine the historic growth, geographic
location, staffing segments, growth and margin prospects, end-market specialization and cultural fit to
investigate M&A opportunities. Targets that are determined not to fit the selection criteria are
eliminated from consideration.

Our criteria include:

- **_Geographic location: We look for targets in countries that have a stable economy with low_**
employment, high salary level, high temporary staff penetration, a stable regulatory
environment and supply and demand mismatch for skilled labor. Our current key areas of focus
include countries where we are already present, particularly Germany, the Netherlands,
Belgium, France and Switzerland, as well as new geographic or other development areas,
including Austria, the Nordic countries and targets in other countries where the target offers
digital technology that complements our strategy.

- **_Staffing segment: We look for targets in both our engineering and consulting and specialized_**
talent solutions segments. By targeting the same staffing segments as our Powerhouses, we can
reinforce their expertise areas or geographic coverage through bolt-on acquisitions. We can also
look at new areas of expertise or areas in which we want to grow more extensively, such as the
healthcare, life science, IT sectors and the digital, financial and strategic consulting profiles.

- **_Growth and margin prospects: We seek targets where we see above-market growth and margin_**
prospects. To that end, we look for targets (1) offering specialist services, focusing on attractive
specialties, which we believe drive higher price points for services (see “—End-market
_Specialization” below), (2) having competitive positioning with a high relative market share_
and demonstrated track record and experience and (3) displaying operational excellence with
well-structured commercial processes, lean cost structures and entrepreneurial ability.

- **_End-market specialization: We look for targets that are staffing end-markets with significant_**
levels of job shortages. Currently, the core end-markets we believe face such shortages include
engineering, financial services, IT, pharmaceuticals, life sciences and healthcare. Furthermore,
our current operations in Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands provide HR solutions that
meet most of the top critical job shortages in those markets. We have identified nursing,
healthcare life science, IT sectors and the digital, financial and strategic consulting profiles as
areas where we still have expansion possibilities. These are specializations that we may develop
to fill our specialization gaps and meet the critical job shortages in those geographic markets
but also acquisitions may be one way to move into these end-market specializations. Expanding
each Powerhouse across our core geographies is also part of our acquisition strategy. We also
consider opportunistic acquisitions of targets that do not serve these end-markets, but which
show high growth and margin prospects.

- **_Cultural fit: We look for targets that have like-minded management teams. Since our Group_**
operates in a people business, finding targets that are a good cultural fit is critical. We also
generally invite the active members of the management teams to stay on board after an
acquisition.


-----

- **_Valuation: Historically, we have acquired bolt-on acquisitions in the range of 5x to 8x, and_**
platform acquisitions in the range of 8x to 9x LTM EBITDA.

**_M&A assessment and integration process_**

Our structured process helps us identify opportunities, investigate and assess the targets that meet our
selection criteria and support the target company once it has been acquired. Three levels of our
organization are involved in deal sourcing: our central Group (especially our M&A Department, which
includes M&A analysts and an M&A legal counsel), our Powerhouses, and our shareholders. Each level
evaluates opportunities through the rubric of our selection criteria. Opportunities identified which meet
the selection criteria are considered on a weekly basis via the M&A team and are then evaluated by our
investment committee and an opportunities file is maintained. Our investment committee includes
representatives from each of the three constituencies (our central Group, our operating companies, and
certain of our shareholders). To further assess an opportunity that meets our selection criteria and
undertake due diligence, we typically try to have a brief meeting with management or advisors before
we sign a non-binding indicative offer letter and then undertake due diligence on the target, including
meeting with its founders and management team, and prepare a short file that summarizes our
assessment of the target company, its market and its key financial and other metrics. The investment
committee will evaluate the opportunities and, if recommended, they are presented to our Board for a
go/no go decision. Opportunities may be approved or rejected, or the Board may recommend that more
time needs to be taken for further assessment. If approved, we will submit a binding offer and determine
which entity in the Group will acquire the target and discuss the target operating model. Typically for
deals that are closely related to one of our Powerhouses, the acquisition will be undertaken by that
Powerhouse, with deals less closely related or very large being acquired at the central Group level. The
assessment process from initial sourcing to closing takes an average of six to nine months to complete.

Once a deal closes, our central support team assists acquired companies. The central team provides
performance support by sharing best practices, financial guidelines and reporting templates and assists
with regulatory compliance issues. The time required to integrate the target into our Group varies
depending on the size of the target, but typically takes six to nine months from closing. Financial
integration is prioritized and is typically completed within 90 days of closing.

**_Our value proposition for target company owners_**

We believe our approach to M&A has created an attractive value proposition for company owners at
target companies which have contributed to our M&A track record. We believe four aspects of our
M&A approach contribute to our appeal to targets and our track record at closing transactions where
we have submitted a binding offer:

- **_Financial incentives: As part of our M&A approach, we generally either offer our management_**
team and individual platform or bolt-on managers a local minority investment (typically for
smaller acquisitions that may need to continue on a standalone basis), and/or we will offer
ordinary shares, often combined with access to the Management Incentive Plan (“MIP”), which
is linked to the performance of their respective companies. This equity type of ownership allows
us to continue to align the incentives of those at the Powerhouse level with both the performance
of our Group and their individual Powerhouse. Typically for smaller acquisitions, we may
continue to acquire only a stake in the target company, but immediately include a mechanism
to roll over shares at group level, exchanging local shares for ordinary and MIP.

- **_Operational freedom:_** For platform acquisitions that are broadening our base of services
offered, we typically offer target companies the option of retaining their full autonomy at the
level of their entities’ operations. We also typically preserve the brand identity of the acquired
companies, which are not consumed into the House of HR brand or the brand of any
Powerhouse. Bolt-on acquisitions may retain less operational autonomy, depending on the


-----

nature of the acquisition and how it is integrated into our Group, but we also typically preserve
their identity and branding.

- **_Support on critical issues:_** Companies joining the Group benefit from support on complex
regulatory and compliance topics from our central teams, and IT security and financing and
financial reporting immediately begin to integrate. These companies are also provided with
access to our foreign staffing recruiting network and experience, our digital platforms (though
they may require adaptation and implementation for their local markets) and the possibility of
accessing our credit lines at a Group level.

- **_Our reputation: We are a leading company for specialized HR solutions with a strong Organic_**
Growth track record and a reputation for operational excellence and quality. We also have a
track record of successful acquisitions.

_Employee compensation_

Up to 50% of the total compensation of our business unit managers, branch managers, sales consultants,
and recruitment consultants is variable and linked to performance:

- **_Business unit management: The performance targets for business unit managers are generally_**
tied to business unit level KPIs, such as business unit EBITDA, EBITDA growth, new clients,
people at work and productivity. Additionally, managers at the business unit level are often
entitled to participate in equity compensation schemes at the Group level, which links their
compensation to our performance as a whole.

- **_Branch managers: The performance targets for branch managers are generally tied to branch_**
level KPIs, such as new clients, people at work and productivity. Branch managers are
compensated with bonus cash incentives, and successful achievement of KPI targets often
impacts promotion decisions. Some of the most successful, long-serving branch managers may
also gain access to the MIP.

- **_Sales consultants: The performance targets for sales consultants are generally tied to individual_**
sales KPIs, such as the number of daily sales, customer calls, customer visits, customer offers,
prospects offers, new customers, and total active customers. Sales consultants are compensated
with bonus cash incentives, and successful achievement of KPI targets often impacts promotion
decisions. Additionally, top performing sales consultants may have the opportunity to open new
branches.

- **_Recruitment consultants: The performance targets for recruitment consultants are generally_**
tied to individual recruiting KPIs, such as the number of candidate calls, candidate interviews,
and successful placements. Recruitment consultants are compensated with bonus cash
incentives, and successful achievement of KPI targets often impacts promotion decisions.


-----

Additionally, the top performing recruitment consultants may have the opportunity to open new
branches.

Additionally, managers at the Group level receive substantial performance-based compensation.

We believe that our emphasis on performance-based compensation contributes to an entrepreneurial
culture throughout the Group and aligns the incentives of our business unit-level employees with that
of the central Group.

**Marketing, Communication and Digital**

Our marketing teams operate on both the Group and local business unit level. Our Group’s marketing
efforts are led by our Group’s chief marketing officer and chief digital officer. Each of our Powerhouses
typically has its own chief executive officer and/or marketing manager lead its local marketing
initiatives. The role of our Group chief marketing officer is to facilitate the two-way exchange of
information and best practices and to oversee press and public relations on a Group level and the
development of thought leadership strategies. Our Group chief digital officer is responsible for guiding
and training our local business units and for integrating the Group’s experience in digital recruiting
strategies into the practices of our business units.

Our marketing team’s primary focus is to efficiently attract new job candidates and clients for our
business units. Each of our local business units also focuses on building brand awareness of its particular
service offering. We apply a four-channel approach to marketing:

- **_Our Own Websites: Our Powerhouses’ and Boutiques’ own websites are a key aspect of our_**
marketing strategy. We use them to attract active jobseekers. Our Group marketing team
provides trainings on search engine optimization to enhance our ability to use the websites for
marketing and sourcing job candidates and clients.

- **_Commercial Job Boards:_** We also make use of commercial job boards, but are gradually
shifting away from them and rely increasingly on the digital initiatives that we have been
investing in, such as search engine and social media marketing, which includes connecting our
jobsites to Google’s application programming interface.

- **_Social Media: We believe that social media is an important channel to reach out and source_**
passive jobseekers. Social media platforms such as LinkedIn, Facebook, Instagram and TikTok
are core advertising platforms in our recruiting and targeted advertising strategy, especially
given the structural shortage of skilled workers in the current market. Every Boutique has its
own social media presence to cater to the job candidates and communities in the respective
sectors that they focus on.

- **_Digital Innovation:_** Our strategy is to constantly look out for new innovation ideas and
technologies that we can leverage to improve our recruitment efficiency. This strategy has led
to the development of many successful tools, apps and digital platforms, such as SWOP,
NOWJOBS, Gighouse, Book’u and many others. We believe that these tools provide us with a
competitive edge and help to keep our recruiting strategy future-proof. See “—Digital
_Initiatives” for further information._

We seek to maximize our total return on marketing spend by frequently analyzing and adjusting our
budget and chosen advertising channels to those that are most effective.


-----

**Information Technology and Innovation**

Our Group’s IT capital expenditure budget for the year ended December 31, 2022 is approximately
€21.0 million. Our IT expenditure has increased in recent years in connection with our digital initiatives
strategy and the growing size of our operations, though we believe that our level of IT expenditure is
still below the industry average for the professional services sector due to our lower expenses for the
development of technology as a result of our targeted combination of in-house resources and off-theshelf IT solutions. Furthermore, we have created a centralized and specialized development team, House
of Invest, to develop reusable different applications for our Powerhouses. House of Invest is able to
integrate and reuse certain concepts that were developed in the past when designing and developing
new applications, which helps to lower our internal development cost.

Among our Powerhouses, Accent has the largest concentration of our IT assets and employees, in large
part due to Accent’s historical role as the original member of our Group and its development team for
the MyTools application, a proprietary ERP platform that executes a wide range of functionalities
supporting Accent’s business operations. Additionally, Accent’s IT staff also supports services that
Accent provides to other Powerhouses and Boutiques. With respect to our other Powerhouses, Covebo
also employs an internal IT team, with the remaining Powerhouses largely relying on the Group’s IT
services or external IT service providers for their IT needs. These and other third parties that we use
typically work alongside our Powerhouses or other Group entities under service level agreements, with
appropriate relationship management.

Our IT infrastructure is built around a clear cloud strategy based on a strong security layer.

Our Group’s IT platform is organized around three pillars: data security and privacy; integration; and
innovation. A description of each of these pillars is provided below:

- **_Data security and privacy_** encompasses all processes and initiatives aimed at ensuring the
security of our Group’s IT infrastructure, the prevention of the loss of sensitive or private data
and relevant regulatory compliance.

- **_Integration and infrastructure_** encompasses all efficiency and cost-related initiatives,
including identifying Group-wide best practices and common infrastructure, software platforms
and processes and security. All companies within the Group are part of our Central Active
Directory, and all servers and infrastructure are hosted on Microsoft Azure, a cloud computing
service.

- **_Innovation encompasses the development of new technology and markets for the Group. All_**
our development efforts and IP rights are centralized under House of Invest.

**_Data Security and Privacy_**

We operate in countries with numerous data security and privacy laws. Our IT systems and processes
are critical to our business operations and strategy, and it is therefore imperative that we maintain
policies and procedures to comply with such laws, such as GDPR. Our Group’s IT professionals
implement systems (AI-based security monitoring and dual-back solutions) and practices to protect
against the loss of sensitive or confidential information, for example through running penetration and
vulnerability testing on a periodic basis. Additionally, our Group’s IT professionals run awareness
campaigns aimed at embedding protection and security of information into our operational business
culture.

**_Integration_**

Our Group has undertaken several integration initiatives aimed at driving synergies across Powerhouses
and their constituent entities and creating efficiencies from economies of scale. We also maintain a set
of IT guidelines that relies on a mandatory/recommended/allowed (“MRA”) framework, which enables


-----

operational flexibility for our Powerhouses while maintaining commonality across the Group where
critical. Under the MRA process, our IT managers discuss and identify a list of mandatory,
recommended and allowed applications, processes and technologies on a Group-wide basis. Mandatory
items include, for instance, a common email platform, Office 365, a disaster recovery plan and securityrelated software, such as password vault and spam, multi-factor authentication and phishing protection.
This MRA process aims to lower operational costs, improve price negotiation positions, enhance
specialized IT knowledge and support available across our Group and facilitate synergies across
Powerhouses. It also assists our Powerhouses with staying attuned to modern applications and software
advancements.

Under the revised Group guidelines, local servers are no longer allowed and must be transitioned as
soon as possible to our central cloud server on Microsoft Azure. Powerhouses are required to use at a
minimum a Tier 3 data center (which is a data center that provides redundancy, dual-powered servers,
network links and other IT components) until such transition is complete. We are aiming to complete
the consolidation of our data centers on the cloud for the entire Group. Migration to the cloud by our
Belgium data centers has been completed and full migration of production servers towards Azure was
completed in the first quarter of 2021. In addition, an updated data and cyber security program has been
rolled out throughout the Group. As part of our data strategy, a project to create a CDP to enhance
candidate user experience in Belgium was launched in 2022.

**_Innovation_**

We continue to improve and innovate our IT platforms, both within Powerhouses and across the Group.
We have one central unit for the Group which centralizes our digital expertise and competence. This
central unit focuses on how to digitize and deploy artificial intelligence (“AI”) in our core business and
experiments with new technologies. See“—Digital Initiatives” for further information.

**Insurance**

The principal risks that we insure against are directors’ and officers’ liability, cyber, general third-party
